In the Philippines this is a widespread species occurring on most major islands (Leviton et al. 2018), as well as smaller islands these authors don't map including Basilan (a record from the early 20th Century) and Dinagat (E. Maglangit pers. comm. 2021). No records exist from much of coastal Mindanao (E. Delima pers. comm. 2021), but has been recorded from the Cotabato coast (K. Pitogo pers. comm. 2021). In Vietnam recent records only exist from parts of the country's south (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2011). It may be more widespread in this country, but surveys in the far south of Vietnam are lacking (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2011).
useTrade: The species was historically used for leather in the 1970s and 1980s. It has also been collected for the pet trade. The species is used in snake wine in Vietnam (Somaweera and Somaweera 2010) in very small numbers, with this study reporting just five individuals in trade. There is some local use for food in Indochina, but this is on a small scale (Q.T. Truong pers. comm. August 2011), and it is not among the more heavily-harvested species around Tonle Sap (T. Neang pers. comm. August 2011).Yuwono (1998) recorded the trade of this species from Java, and that it was always available in adequate numbers. There is no known trade in New Guinea. It is heavily legally traded in the Philippines for leather, both domestic and international, and the domestic pet trade (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2021).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. In view of the species' extensive geographic range, it occurs in protected areas in both marine areas or freshwater lakes (including Ramsar sites), and it is presumed to occur within local Marine Protected Areas throughout its range. Most coastal waters in the Philippines are locally managed protected areas. It is not known to be present in any protected areas in Viet Nam. No direct conservation measures are currently needed for this species as a whole. While it is subject to some commercial collection, the species is not currently listed by CITES. Further details are needed into the impact of collection of animals for use in the leather and pet trade, and on the effects of habitat degradation.

rationale: Centropomus medius is broadly distributed on the Pacific Coast of North America, Central America, and South America from the Gulf of California to central Ecuador. Limited sampling suggests that this species occurs at relatively low abundance in many parts of its range. While there is no indication of major range-wide population decline, the localized and regional impacts resulting primarily from fishing pressure, shrimp pond aquaculture, environmental pollutants, and coastal development may be causing decline and need further evaluation. Given its wide range, large number of locations, and lack of evidenced population decline, C. medius is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This demersal species is found in bays, estuaries, mangroves and in the lower reaches of freshwater streams (De La Cruz Agüero 1997, Vega and Castillo 2002, Miller et al. 2005). It enters freshwaters in large rivers to feed on fish and crustaceans, and has been found to occur in streams at an altitude of at least 250 m elevation, and a distance of 20 km from the coast (Bussing 1998). This species occurs in coastal waters, but is more abundant in estuaries, which are thought to be important sites for nesting and not reproduction (Chicas 1995).

Centropomus medius has the greatest trophic spectrum when compared to its co-occurring congeners C. nigrescens, C. robalito, and C. viridis (Macal Lopez et al. 2013). Spawning occurs annually from April to October (Vergara-Chen 2014).
threats:
On a range-wide scale, there are no known major pervasive threats to this species. The regional impacts of artisanal and small-scale commercial harvest on the total population size of C. medius are unknown. Coastal pollution of heavy metals and metalloids from mining operations and nutrient and pesticide runoff from intensive agricultural and pond aquaculture, including associated harmful algal blooms (HABs) have been documented in the Gulf of California (Paez-Osuna et al. 2017). However, the impacts of environmental pollutants on C. nigrescens range-wide requires further research.

Localized coastal development and mangrove destruction has the potential to reduce suitable habitat. Intensive shrimp aquaculture in coastal areas (especially in Sinaloa) may lead to destruction of mangrove habitat, and increase nutrient loading in adjacent lagoons (Alonso-Perez et al. 2003, Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2005). In Guatemala, Honduras, and Panama, coastal mangrove forests are threatened by the expansion of aquaculture infrastructure, coastal development, and exploitation as firewood and charcoal (Recio et al. 2016).
population:
On a range-wide scale, the total population size and population trend of this species are unknown.

This species is considered abundant in the Gulf of Montijo, Panama (Vega 2004). However, it is considered uncommon in the Gulf of California. Approximately 50 individuals were collected in Golf of Nicoya, Costa Rica, where it is considered a transient species (Rojas et al. 1994). Limited sampling in the San Pedro River reports a 2% relative frequency of C. medius (Gonzalez-Diaz et al. 2015). Within La Encrucijada Biosphere Reserve in Chiapas, this species is reported at low abundance (Velazquez Velazquez et al. 2008). Recent sampling in El Salvador suggest that this species is fairly uncommon (Fuentes et al. 2015). In Panama, it was reported from only one of nine sampling localities (Vega et al. 2006). In Malaga Bay, Columbia, density in medium salinity zones was less than 0.002 ind/m-3 (Castellanos-Galindo and Krumme 2013).

Overall, this species is relatively data-poor (Jara Baquero 2018). More detailed estimates of total population size and population trend on regional and range-wide scales are needed to inform accurate stock assessment.
range: Centropomus medius is distributed throughout coastal waters and rivers on the Pacific coast of North, Central, and South America from Magdalena Bay in the Gulf of California, southwards to Ecuador (Miller et al. 2005, Vergara-Chen 2014, Coello and Herrera 2017).
useTrade: Centropomus medius is targeted by subsistence, artisanal, and small-scale commercial fisheries throughout much of its range (Fernandez et al. 2011, Vergara-Chen 2014, Jara Baquero 2018). However, a range-wide quantitative evaluation of total fisheries take has not been conducted (Jara Bacuero 2018). Given uncertainty in total population size, population trend, and fishing pressure, detailed stock assessments are not possible.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures directed towards C. medius. The range of this species includes several protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2018).

More information on the population size, population trend, and impacts of regional threats would be useful in accurately determining conservation status.

rationale: Centropomus robalito is widely distributed in the eastern Pacific Ocean from the Yaqui River in the Gulf of California southwards to Peru. Total population size and population trend are unknown. Regional or localized threats to this species include potential overfishing, coastal development and destruction of mangrove habitat resulting from shrimp aquaculture and extraction of mangroves for use as firewood and charcoal, coastal pollution from agricultural runoff and industrial discharge, and unintentional mortality as bycatch in commercial-scale shrimp trawling vessels. However, on a range-wide scale, there is no indication of major population decline. As such, C. robalito is listed as Least Concern. Given the importance of this species in artisanal and small-scale commercial fisheries, population and habitat monitoring are conservation priorities.
habitat:
This species is found in bays, estuaries, lagoons and the lower parts of freshwater streams (Cooke 1992, Vega 2004). It is also found offshore (Vega 2004), but exhibits a greater preference towards less saline coastal lagoons and estuaries than its sympatric congeners C. viridis and C. medius (Diaz-Jaimes et al. 2007).

Diet is comprised primarily of shrimp and crustaceans (Bussing 1998, Moreno-Sanchez et al. 2015), but also includes small fishes (Macal-Lopez et al. 2013). Length at first maturity is approximately 21 cm total length (TL) (Alvarez-Lajonchère and Tsuzuki 2008).
threats:
On a range-wide scale, there are no known major pervasive threats to this species. Anecdotal reports from fishermen in the Gulf of Fonseca, El Salvador, suggest harvest reductions resulting from fishing pressure (Campbell 2015). However, the regional impacts of artisanal and small-scale commercial harvest on the total population size of C. robalito are unknown. Heavy metals and metalloids (including cadmium and lead) from mining operations, nutrient and pesticide runoff from intensive agricultural and pond aquaculture, and associated harmful algal blooms (HABs) have been documented in the Gulf of California (Gil-Manrique et al. 2017, Paez-Osuna et al. 2017). However, the impacts of environmental pollutants on C. robalito range-wide require further research.

Localized coastal development and mangrove destruction has the potential to reduce suitable habitat. Intensive shrimp aquaculture in coastal areas (especially in Sinaloa) may lead to destruction of mangrove habitat, and increase nutrient loading in adjacent lagoons (Alonso-Perez et al. 2003, Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2005). In Guatemala, Honduras, and Panama, coastal mangrove forests are threatened by the expansion of aquaculture infrastructure, coastal development, and exploitative use for firewood and charcoal production (Recio et al. 2016).

Centropomus robalito comprises a significant portion of commercial-scale shrimp fishery bycatch in the Gulf of California, and on the coasts of Sinaloa and Nayarit, Mexico (Madrid-Vera et al. 2007, Aguilar Ibarra 2017).

These potential threats are ongoing and expected to continue, especially in Mexico and parts of Central America where fisheries and aquaculture practices may be unsustainable, or where coastal natural resource governance is lacking (Mondoux et al. 2008, Campbell 2015, Gonzalez-Bernat and Clifton 2017).
population: The total population size of C. robalito is unknown. Range-wide population trend is unknown. In La Encrucijada Biosphere Reserve, this species is widely distributed and fairly common (Velazquez-Velazquez et al. 2007, 2008). In the Presidio River, it was reported from 2 of 10 sampling localities (Sanchez-Gonzales et al. 2018). In the San Pedro River, Gonzalez-Diaz et al. (2015) report a 5.9% relative abundance. In the Gulf of Tehuantepec, this is one of the most frequently encountered species (Romero-Berny et al. 2018). Similarly, this is a dominant resident species in Chacahua Lagoon, Oaxaca (Mendoza et al. 2009). In a coast-wide survey of El Salvador, it was found at low relative abundance (Fuentes et al. 2015). In the Palmar and Javita rivers in Ecuador, this species was found at low relative abundance and density (Shervette et al. 2007).
range: Centropomus robalito is widely distributed in the eastern Pacific Ocean from the Yaqui River in the Gulf of California southwards to Peru (Hendrickson et al. 1980, Robertson and Allen 2008, Coello and Herrera 2017). Some reports suggest that the southern range extent terminates at Panama, Columbia, or Ecuador (Miller et al. 2005, Alvarez-Lajonchere and Tsuzuki 2008, Vergara-Chen et al. 2014).
useTrade:
Centropomus robalito is targeted by subsistence, artisanal, and small-scale commercial fisheries throughout much of its native range (Fernandez et al. 2011, Campbell 2015, Gonzalez-Bernat and Clifton. 2017). However, fisheries statistics are frequently reported as a species complex, which includes several Centropomus spp. (Diaz-Jaimes et al. 2007). Therefore, species contributions to the total fishery are uncertain. At Isla Isabel in the Gulf of California, this species comprises a minor portion of artisanal fishery harvest (Torrescano-Castro et al. 2016).

This species has been suggested as a potential aquaculture candidate (Alvarez-Lajonchere et al. 2008, Vergara-Chen et al. 2014). However, to date there has been no successful ex-situ culture of C. robalito.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures directed towards C. robalito. The range of this species includes several protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2018).

Successful ex-situ culture of C. robalito would likely reduce fishing mortality on wild stocks. Given that this is an economically important fisheries species in much of its range (Fernandez et al. 2011, Campbell 2015, Gonzalez-Bernat and Clifton 2017), more information on population size, population trend, and population monitoring are conservation priorities.

rationale: Dormitator latifrons is widely distributed throughout the Eastern Pacific from southern California southward to Ecuador, including the Gulf of California and the Galapagos Islands. Where it occurs, it often comprises a dominant portion of relative fish abundance and biomass. There are no known major threats to this species, and no current indication of major population decline. Therefore, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This amphidromous fish inhabits estuaries, stagnant ditches or creeks of low current velocity, and intertidal rocky habitat (Miller et al. 2005, Gonzalez-Murcia et al. 2016). It is a benthic species and is most abundant on sandy and muddy substrate (Rojas et al. 1994). It ingests mud, detritus and small fishes. This species is found typically in freshwater, but high salinity tolerance (Miller et al. 2005) enables it to move freely into the sea and it can be regularly found in middle estuaries, mangroves, bar-formed lagoons and upper estuaries along the tropical eastern Pacific coast (Cooke 1992).
threats:
On a range-wide scale, there are no major pervasive threats to this species.

Coastal pollution of heavy metals and metalloids (including cadmium and lead) from mining operations and nutrient and pesticide runoff from intensive agricultural and pond aquaculture, including associated harmful algal blooms (HABs) have been documented in the Gulf of California (Gil-Manrique et al. 2017, Paez-Osuna et al. 2017). Localized coastal development and mangrove destruction has the potential to reduce suitable habitat. Intensive shrimp aquaculture in coastal areas may lead to destruction of mangrove habitat and increase nutrient loading in adjacent lagoons (Alonso-Perez et al. 2003, Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2005). In Guatemala, Honduras, and Panama, coastal mangrove forests are threatened by the expansion of aquaculture infrastructure, coastal development, and small scale extraction for firewood and charcoal production (Recio et al. 2016). The impacts of these potential threats on habitat extent and population status require further study.
population:
Total population size is unknown but presumably large. This species is abundant throughout much of its range. In estuaries in central Mexico, it comprised the most biomass of any other sampled species (Sandoval-Huerta et al. 2014). Similarly, it is a dominant species in the coastal Presidio River, Sinaloa (Sanchez-Gonzales et al. 2018) and lagoons within Encrucijada Biosphere Reserve, Chiapas (Velazquez-Velazquez et al. 2008). It was moderately abundant in the coastal Mezquital River, Nayarit (Gonzalez-Diaz et al. 2015). In intertidal rockpool habitat on the coast of El Salvador, it was present at 10.4% relative abundance (Gonzalez-Murcia et al. 2016).

There is no indication of major population decline. Therefore, the population trend is suspected to be stable or declining at a rate that precludes this species from being assessed under a threatened category.
range:
This species is widely distributed in the eastern Pacific Ocean from southern California, USA and the Gulf of California, Mexico southward to Ecuador, including the Galapagos Islands (Miller et al. 2005, Vega et al. 2006, Matamoros et al. 2009, Angulo et al. 2015, Galvan-Quesada et al. 2016, Velazquez-Velazquez et al. 2016, Del Moral-Flores et al. 2017).

There are no reports of this species on the Atlantic coast of Panama. However, the close congener D. maculatus has reportedly spread from the Atlantic slope to at least one coastal river on the Pacific slope of Panama, likely due to migration mediated by the construction of the Panama Canal (Smith et al. 2004).
useTrade: This is a commercial species that may be used for aquaculture and has now begun to be semi-cultivated in marshes. It has proven extremely tolerant of variations in salinity, and traditionally has been used for food. Its ability to withstand long periods of transportation (up to three days) without refrigeration makes it attractive for marketing in isolated communities where logistical facilities are inadequate (FAO 1987). This species quickly accepts commercial feed diets and produces high quality filets (Lopez-Huerta et al. 2018).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species. However, this species distribution falls partially into a number of Marine Protected Areas in the Eastern Pacific region (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019).

rationale: This species is widespread in the eastern Tropical Pacific, and is common throughout its range. Coastal development and removal of mangrove habitat within its range may pose a threat to this species. Although there is no current indication of widespread population decline, this species and its habitat should be carefully monitored. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This benthic species inhabits intertidal zones on mud substrate, and can enter freshwater. Abundance is strongly correlated with the availability of mangrove habitat (Shervette et al. 2007).
threats:
Coastal pollution of heavy metals and metalloids from mining operations and nutrient and pesticide runoff from intensive agricultural and pond aquaculture, including associated harmful algal blooms (HABs) have been documented in the Gulf of California (Paez-Osuna et al. 2017). However, the impacts of these environmental pollutants on E. minutus require further research.

Mangrove habitat in the tropical eastern Pacific and specifically along the coast of Central America has declined considerably since the 1980’s, with an estimated global loss of mangrove habitat of 1% annually (Polidoro et al. 2010). Localized coastal development and mangrove destruction has likely reduced habitat availability and quality. Intensive shrimp aquaculture in coastal areas (especially in Sinaloa) may lead to destruction of mangrove habitat and increased nutrient loading in adjacent lagoons (Alonso-Perez et al. 2003, Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2005). In Guatemala, Honduras, and Panama, coastal mangrove forests are threatened by the expansion of aquaculture infrastructure, coastal development, and extractive use for firewood and charcoal (Recio et al. 2016).
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown.  However, it appears relatively common throughout its range where suitable habitat exists. In La Paz Bay, Gulf of California, this species occurred at a density of 1.6 ind/hectare (Gonzalez-Acosta et al. 2005). In Palmar, Ecuador, it was the most dominant species sampled and comprised 28% relative abundance (Shervette 2006, Shervette et al. 2007). In other studies on eastern Pacific mangrove fish fauna, it is not reported as a dominant species (Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2013).
range: This species is endemic to the Eastern Pacific, ranging from the southeastern Gulf of California (Mazatlan) to Colombia (Van Tassell 2011, Gonzalez-Diaz and Sorria-Barreto 2013, Angulo et al. 2015, Velazquez-Velazquez et al. 2016), and including the Galapagos Islands (Valencia-Mendez et al. 2019). This species is strongly correlated with the presence of mangrove habitat (Shervette et al. 2007), suggesting that distribution on a local scale is likely patchy and dependent on the availability of suitable habitat.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species. However, the range of this species includes several Marine Protected Areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019), which may provide indirect protection against habitat degradation. More information regarding distribution, population trend, and the effects of mangrove loss on distribution and population status would be useful in guiding future conservation actions.

rationale: This species is widespread in the Eastern Pacific, and is relatively common throughout its range. There are no known major threats to this species, and no current indication of population decline. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits rivers, creeks and lakes from the brackish swamps to sea level to 115 m elevation. Uvenilles are very abundant near the coast, suggesting reproduction in marine or brackish waters (Bussing 1998). According to Cooke (1992) this species is occasionally found in middle estuaries and mangroves, while regularly found at bar-formed laggons and upper estuaries along the tropical eastern Pacific coast.
threats: There are no specific major threats known for this species. However, localized coastal development and aquaculture may affect habitat quality.
population: This species is relatively common within its range.
range: This species is endemic to the Eastern Pacific, and is found from the tip of Baja California and the mouth of the Gulf of California, Mexico to northern Peru, including the Galapagos and Cocos Islands.
useTrade: The species is not utilized
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species. However, this species' distribution falls partially into a number of Marine Protected Areas in the Eastern Pacific region (WDPA 2006).

rationale: This species is widespread in the eastern tropical Pacific. While it is reported at low abundances in many parts of its range, a wide distribution suggests that the total population size and number of locations where it occurs are likely large. Regional and localized threats are primarily associated with land-use changes for aquaculture infrastructure and coastal development. However, on a range-wide scale there are no major pervasive threats and no current indication of major population decline. As such, G. microdon is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits estuaries and brackish mangrove creeks. It has also been recorded from rivers (Uribe-Alcocer and Díaz-Jaimes, 1996) and from intertidal rock pools (Gonzalez-Murcia et al. 2016). Individuals in the Gulf of Tehuantepec were collected in salinity ranging from 5.9-32.6 parts per thousand (Romero-Berny et al. 2018).
threats: On a range-wide scale, there are no specific major threats known for this species. However, localized coastal development and mangrove destruction has the potential to reduce suitable habitat. Intensive shrimp aquaculture in coastal areas (especially in Sinaloa) leads to destruction of mangrove habitat, and potentially eutrophication of adjacent lagoons (Alfonso-Perez et al. 2003, Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2005). In Guatemala, Honduras, and Panama, coastal mangrove forests are threatened by the expansion of aquaculture infrastructure, coastal development, and exploitation as firewood and charcoal (Recio et al. 2016).
population:
The total population size of G. microdon is unknown, but likely large given a wide distribution.

Low relative abundances are reported from the Presidio River (Sanchez-Gonzales et al. 2018), Encrucijada Biosphere Reserve (Velazquez-Velazquez et al. 2008), the Gulf of Tehuantepec (Romero-Berny et al. 2018), the coast of Michoacan (Sandoval-Huerta et al. 2014), El Salvador (Gonzalez-Murcia et al. 2016), and Ecuador (Shervette et al. 2007).

Population trend is unknown, but likely stable or declining at a rate that precludes this species from being assessed under a threatened category.
range: Gobionellus microdon is widely distributed throughout the eastern Pacific from the southwestern and eastern Gulf of California to Ecuador (Pezold, 1984). This species has been specifically reported from the Presidio River in Sinaloa (Sanchez-Gonzales et al. 2018), the lower San Pedro Mezquital in Nayarit (Gonzalez-Diaz et al. 2015), Michoacan (Sandoval-Huerta et al. 2014), Oaxaca (Tapia-Garcia et al. 2005, Moral Flores et al. 2017), throughout Encrujida Biosphere Reserve, in the Costo-Istmo and Costa-Soconusco drainages, and throughout the Gulf of Tehuantepec in Chiapas (Velaquez-Velazquez et al. 2007, 2016, Romero-Berny et al. 2018), El Salvador (Mcmahan et al. 2013, Gonzalez-Murcia et al. 2016), the Tusubres River drainage in Costa Rica (Angulo et al. 2015), and Ecuador (Shervette et al. 2007).
useTrade: There is no information about the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for G. microdon. The range of this species includes a number of coastal protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2018) that provide indirect protection against habitat destruction.

rationale: Rhamdia quelen is widespread from Mexico to southern Argentina and southern Brazil. Population status is suspected to be stable, but it faces threats from invasive Heptapterid fishes, large amounts of herbicides, fungicides and pesticides used in areas for crop protection, and is a known host of the infectious trematode Clinostomum sp. While it is possibly declining in parts of its range due to these threats, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable, given the various populations throughout its range are not directly connected. Therefore, the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Rhamdia quelen is a bottom dwelling species spread out through the freshwater habitats of central and southern America, and is found in lakes, rivers and reservoirs and in Brazil in particular, is commonly used in aquaculture within artificial ponds and small lakes. This species can be identified with having barbels in the chin and they also have jaws with a sensory function and dorsal pectoral fins with defensive spines (Kreutz, et al. 2008). In addition to this, this species is a fast growing species, favoured to the aquaculture industry for its hardiness, and resistance to low temperatures that are typical of winters in the southern regions of its range (Carneiro, 2004; Garcia et al., 2008). This species highest mean swimming activity mainly occurs within the morning and at nightfall, as several studies describe Rhamdia quelen as a predominantly nocturnal species (Winemiller, 1989; Gomes et al., 2000). This species is known to favour areas within rivers characterised by steep banks that provide shelter in the current and large debris travelling downstream. Rhamdia quelen occurs within the upper 2 m of the water as this provides favoured higher temperatures and higher dissolved oxygen concentrations (Schulz and Leuchtenberger, 2006).

Rhamdia quelen is known to be omnivorous with a tendency to also be carnivorous, depending on the habitat it is found in, otherwise it feeds on zooplankton, Artemia, fish and crustaceans, and feeding intensity increases in the autumn and winter (Meurer and Zaniboni Filho, 1997). It has been observed that this species in the upper Uruguay river, conducts spawning activities most frequently during the spring, continuing throughout the year but with less intensity and that premature fish were seen to perform a lateral migration into the affluents of the main river system, where the final gonadal maturation occurred (Cassini, 1998). The lateral migrations seemed to be triggered by an increase in water temperature and by flood events (Zaniboni Filho and Schulz, 2003). Sexual maturity is reached in the first year of life, and this species is ovuliparous and in the natural environment the schools spawn in clean and calm waters with rocky bottoms.
Rhamdia quelen is known to be an intermediary host of the trematode Clinostomum sp. (Fortes and Hoffmann 1980). The courtship behaviour of this species involves the male circling around the female, with the circulation becoming closer at the time of ovulation, proceeding the male to press the flanks of the female to activate her ovulation.
threats: Rhamdia quelen is threatened by the herbicides, fungicides and pesticides pollution run off from the agriculture industry of rice, soybean, corn and wheat production, as as well as some pesticides might be added directly to water to control macrophytes and predatory insects (Szarek et al., 2000; Van Der Oost, et al., 2003). Also this species is threatened by invasive heptapteridae fish (Kreutz, et al. 2008) and potential habitat alteration and degradation by the aquaculture industry targeting this species (Marchioro and Baldisserotto 1999; Carneiro et al., 2002; Silva, Oliveira1 and Bicudo, 2009).
population: Considering the widespread distribution of this species and it's popularity in maintaining fish numbers for the aquaculture industry (Marchioro and Baldisserotto 1999; Oliveira Filho and Fracalossi, 2006), this species population is considered stable and large in number, although its size is unknown.
range: Rhamdia quelen (common names: Randiá in Argentina or Jundiá cinza in Brazil) is a wide spread species found in freshwater habitats ranging from Central America to the south of Brazil in South America. This species occurs within Yucatan and Oaxaca regions within in Mexico (Eschmeyer, 1998; Silva, Oliveira1 amd Bicudo, 2009), Guatemala, Belize, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama, Colombia, Ecuador and in Peru and Bolivia. It is also found through to both the north and central regions of Argentina, and across to the Urugary river (Cassini, 1998) in southern Brazil (Garcia et al., 2008; Kreutz, et al. 2008).
useTrade: Rhamdia quelen is of great economic importance in Rio Grande do Sul in Brazil and across most of south America, since it is a native species that demonstrates high adaptability to different environments and thus widely used in aquaculture (Carneiro et al., 2002). Given its fast growth speed and resilience, this makes this species hold a widespread, good market acceptance (Marchioro and Baldisserotto 1999), resulting in an increase in cultivation in southern Brazil (Silva, Oliveira1, Bicudo, 2009). It is also an important species in sport fishing (Carneiro et al., 2002; Oliveira Filho and Fracalossi, 2006).
conservationActions: No conservation actions for Rhamdia quelen are known, but given its wide distribution throughout multiple countries, it is likely to include multiple conservation areas within its range. More information would be useful on the actions related to the threats across its range.

rationale: Gymnotus carapo is a freshwater fish species from Central and South America. It occurs from southern Mexico to Paraguay, including Trinidad, Argentina and Brazil. This fish is known to be a commonly used bait fish that also occasionally appears in the aquarium trade. The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Gymnotus carapo is known to inhabit turbid, slow moving or standing waters (Kenny, 1995), and can be found also in shallow edges of streams (Loureiro and Silva, 2006). It is known to survive dry-outs in ditches, canals and small ponds (Kenny, 1995) and will be found to feed mainly at night, on worms, insects (e.g. odonate larvae), shrimps, fish (preferably small characids, e.g. Ctenobrycon and Curimata) and plant matter (Mills and Vevers, 1989; Møller, 1995). It is an oviparous fish (Breder and Rosen, 1966) and mouth brooding by males has been observed (Crampton and Hopkins, 2005), with males providing parental care in nests excavated for eggs and larvae (Crampton and Hopkins, 2005). This species is a neotropical teleost that swims by means of an elongated ventral anal fin and can distinguish between a `friendly neighbour' and a potentially `threatening stranger' based on electric organ discharge (EOD) waveform alone (Møller, 1995). The maximum size of this species is 76 cm TL (unsexed).

Gymnotus carapo are nocturnal predators of fishes and other small aquatic animals, and most are territorial (Crampton 1998).
threats: This species is largely used in professional and sportive fishery, as live bait it is preferred by higher predator fish species (Vergilio, et al. 2013), and is also used in aquaculture for production. Other threats to Gymnotus carapo, found in Argentina, include being parasitized (Arredondo and Gil de Pertierra, 2010) by three species of proteocephalidean cestodes (Gil de Pertierra 2003; 2005), and by the acanthocephalan P. omarsegundoi. While in the Upper Paraná River in Brazil it is parasitized by the following adult helminths: one species of proteocephalidean cestode, one undetermined species of Digenea, one undetermined species of Nematoda and the acanthocephalan Quadrigyrus machadoi (Takemoto et al. 2009; Arredondo and Gil de Pertierra, 2010).
population: More information is needed about the population size and population trend of Gymnotus carapo.
range: This freshwater species is known to be native central and south America, from southern Mexico to Paraguay, including Trinidad and Brazil but more specific information is needed about the geographical range of Gymnotus carapo. Within Brazil it is known to be found within the Corrego do Feijao, municipality of Sao Carlos in the state of Sao Paulo and also within Cima Lake in the northern part of Rio de Janeiro state (Vergilio, et al. 2013). From Argentina this species is known from the Paraná River and Colastiné River that is a tributary to it.
useTrade: This species is largely used in professional and sportive fishery, as live bait it is preferred by higher predator fish species (Vergilio, et al. 2013), and is also used in aquaculture for production.
conservationActions: No conservation actions for Gymnotus carapo are known.

rationale: Pimelodella papariae é conhecida apenas de sua localidade-tipo, Lagoa Papari, Rio Grande do Norte. O gênero apresenta problemas taxonômicos associados a possíveis sinonímias e ao reconhecimento de suas espécies. A dificuldade de identificação taxonômica gera incertezas na determinação destes táxons, que modificariam as informações sobre distribuição e abundância e, por conseguinte, a identificação dos níveis de ameaça a que a espécie estaria submetida. Esforços de coleta recentes não lograram a captura da espécie. Além disso, o entorno da Lagoa Papari está altamente descaracterizado pela expansão desordenada de viveiros de piscicultura. Portanto, Pimelodella papariae foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie.
threats: O entorno da Lagoa Papari está altamente descaracterizado em função da expansão desordenada de viveiros de piscicultura.
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis.
range: Pimelodella papariae é endêmica do Brasil e conhecida apenas de sua localidade-tipo, Lagoa Papari, Rio Grande do Norte (Bockmann e Guazzelli 2003). A espécie é possivelmente endêmica da ecorregião Nordeste Médio-Oriental (Rosa 2004, Rosa et al. 2003).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não há nenhum programa de conservação dessa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. É necessária a promoção de inventários da ictiofauna nas bacias hidrográficas da região da caatinga, que em grande parte encontram-se subamostradas (Rosa 2004). Também são necessários estudos a respeito da taxonomia, limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia de Pimelodella papariae.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: Amphiprion bicinctus is distributed in the Red Sea, Gulf of Aden to Socotra, and the Chago Archipelago. It is common in parts of its range and can be locally abundant. It is harvested for the aquarium trade, but there is no evidence of population declines from harvesting. Its distribution overlaps with a number of marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Amphiprion bicinctus is found in coastal, lagoon, and outer reef habitats. It is a commensal inhabitant of sea anemones (Entacmaea quadricolor, Heteractis aurora, H. crispa, H. magnifica, Stichodactyla gigantea, and S. mertensii) on coral reefs in depths between about 1-40 m (Allen 1991). This species is oviparous and monogamous, with elliptical eggs (Thresher 1984, Whiteman and Côté 2004), and has been reared in captivity (Young 1990). Sex reversal is completed in 26-145 days (Sadovy and Shapiro 1987). In a field test, a functional male laid eggs in 26 days after removal of the female from the area (Thresher 1984).
threats: This species is a minor component of the aquarium trade, and there is localized degradation of water quality from fish farms; however, no major threats are currently known.
population: This species is common in the Red Sea, and can be locally abundant (G.R. Allen and R.F. Myers pers. comm. 2010).
range: Amphiprion bicinctus is located in the western Indian Ocean: in the Red Sea, Gulf of Aden and Chagos Archipelago (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2010). It has also been recorded from Socotra (Zajonz et al. 2000).
useTrade: This species is a minor component of the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species; however, its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range.

rationale: Lagocephalus laevigatus is widely distributed in the eastern and western Atlantic, where it appears to be common in parts of its range. L. laevigatus is found at depths ranging from 1 to 180 metres. Adults of this species are pelagic, generally inhabiting the continental shelf, while juveniles tend to be found inshore. This species is taken as bycatch in shrimp and fish trawls. It is also taken in some small-scale artisanal fisheries. There have been no documented population declines in L. laevigatus. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for L. laevigatus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Habitat and ecology
Lagacephalus laevigatus inhabits inshore and near-shore areas, including estuaries and mangroves, over sand or mud bottoms. Off the coast of Ghana, this species was characteristic of the assemblage of fishes found to depths of 40 m over soft bottoms (Koranteng 2001). In Brazil, it was found in the Curuçá River Estuary, northeastern Amazonian Coast during the rainy and dry season (Barros et al. 2011), a mostly marine estuary. It is usually found alone or in small, loose aggregates. Adults are pelagic, but are typically found near continental margins. Juveniles are commonly found on coastal and offshore banks (Robins and Ray 1986), and it is thought that this species utilizes estuaries as a nursery area (Denadai et al. 2012). The diet of L. laevigatus consists mainly of, in order of frequency of occurrence, the sea whip Leptogorgia setacea, followed by various crustaceans, teleosts and amphipods. Lesser utilized food options for Lagocephalus laevigatus include polychaetes, bivalves, algae, gastropods and isopods, all of which comprise very small volumes in the puffer diet (polychaetes, bivalves, algae, gastropods and isopods comprise > 5% in their total food intake). Considering the volume of the items ingested by L. laevigatus, the sea whip L. setacea is most consumed, followed, with much less importance, by fish, amphipods and unidentified crustaceans (Denadai et al. 2012). The toxicity of the smooth puffer may be derived by the Cnidaria that it ingests (Denadai et al. 2012).

Life history and reproduction
In Brazil, Lagocephalus laevigatus probably spawns from August through November (i.e. the end of winter and beginning of Spring). There tends to be more males than females in wild populations (Fall et al. 2013). The length of first maturity for males is 24.5 cm and for females is 27.5 cm (Fall et al. 2013). Off the coast of Senegal, there are two spawning periods: The first during the hot and rainy season (July to October), and the second during the dry and cold season (December to January). Size at first sexual maturity is 24.5 cm for males and 27.5 cm for females (Fall et al. 2013).

Additional information
Puffers of the genus Lagocephalus are globally distributed in warm shallow waters, however classification at the species level in Lagocephalus has not yet been studied in depth, causing confusion in the status of several species including L. cheesemanii, L. gloveri, L. spadiceus, and L. wheeleri (Matsuura et al. 2011).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: Lagocephalus laevigatus is taken as bycatch in longline and trawl fisheries. It is also taken as bycatch in penaeid trawl fisheries. Lagocephalus laevigatus is harvested by small-scale artisanal fisheries in parts of its range (Denadai et al. 2012). This species is a component of the "trash fish" fishery of Ghana. This illegal fishery is comprised of discard species taken by industrial trawlers, pair trawlers, shrimpers, and artisanal fishers, which are transferred at sea for re-sale on land (Nunoo et al. 2009) and are consequently not monitored or regulated.This species of fish may be experiencing population decreases due to loss of mangrove habitat. Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction. (Polidoro et al. 2010). In the Caribbean, approximately 24% of mangrove area has been lost over the past quarter-century (FAO 2007).
population:
Lagocephalus laevigatus is considered fairly abundant and common in both its eastern and western Atlantic ranges.

In the Eastern Atlantic, this species is currently utilized as food at the local level off the coast of West Africa. It is among the most common Tetraodontid species encountered off the coast of Senegal (Fall et al. 2013). It is worth noting that Tetraodontids in general were considered undesirable in the region until the late 1970s and 1980s, and only began to be utilized as food sources as other species (groupers, breams, barracudas, snappers, etc.) became rare. In Senegal, this species is intensively fished throughout the Dakar region year-around (Fall et al. 2013). Off the coast of Ghana, L. laevigatus accounted for 2.53% of the composition of "trash fish" species taken at the Elmina landing site (Nunoo et al. 2009). In Nigeria, this species was considered under-exploited, and there is interest in further development of the fishery (Ogamba and Abowe 2012). Changes in minor up-welling and other environmental factors have been implicated in shore lived increases of biomass and catch of L. laevigatus in the Gulf of Guinea (Koranteng 1998). This species was not associated with the upwelling season until the 1990s (Koranteng 2001).

In the Western Atlantic, the mean annual catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) caught in the Southeast Area Monitoring and Assessment Program (SEAMAP) during the fall and summer trawl surveys from 1987 to 2010 indicate no clear trend (NOAA unpub. data). Off the coast of Brazil, in the Caraguatatuba Bay, L. laevigatus is considered rare (Denadai et al. 2012). However, in another study conducted on the effect of grid spacing in shrimp fishery bycatch off the coast of Brazil, L. laevigatus was not overwhelmingly common, but did not seem rare, either (Silva et al. 2012). In a study published in 2011 and conducted by the Gulf of Mex­ico Fishery Management Council (GMFMC) and abiding by the mandates of the Reef Fish Fishery Management Plan, the commercial fishing industry and the GMFMC, the National Marine Fisheries Ser­vice’s (NMFS) Southeast Fisheries Science Center (SEFSC) collaborated and assessed the status of commercially viable Gulf of Mexico reef fish populations. In this study, Lagocephalus laevigatus was rarely seen on Gulf of Mexico's reefs (Scott-Denton et al. 2011).

Lagocephalus laevigatus is extremely well represented in museum collections around the world, with 535 records in FishNet2 (retrieved 13 March 2014).
range: In the eastern Atlantic, L. laevigatus is found in the tropical eastern Atlantic Ocean, from Mauritania to Namibia (Bianchi et al. 1999). Its range may extend to the Cíes Islands, northwestern Spain (Bañón and Sántas 2011) and Portugal, however these are unlikely to be established subpopulations. In the western Atlantic, it is known from the northern United States to Argentina (Denadai et al. 2012). It is found at depths ranging from 10 to 180 metres.
useTrade:
Lagocephalus laevigatus is harvested by small-scale artisanal fisheries in parts of its range (Denadai et al. 2012). In Senegal, this species and Lagocephalus lagocephalus are the most commonly consumed tetraodontids in households, and are often prepared in rice-based dishes (Fall et al. 2013). This species is a component of the "trash fish" fishery of Ghana. This illegal fishery is comprised of discard species taken by industrial trawlers, pair trawlers, shrimpers, and artisanal fishers, which are transferred at sea for re-sale on land (Nunoo et al. 2009). In Brazil, this species is consumed on a small-scale in the São Sebastião channel area (Oliveira et al. 2003).

Species of the genus Lagocephalus are, on the other hand, the more consumed fish within households, restaurants and hotels in Senegal. For example, a crate of products of  about 35 kg, can easily be assigned between 8,000–15,000 FCFA, that is to say 12–23 Euro. Once captured, all those fish are generally skinned, eviscerated and slashed, the heads being reserved for artisanal  processing as “guedj”, a famous dried, salted and fermented product particularly appreciated in the “thiébou dieune”. The remaining part (flesh) is consumed through miscellaneous rice-based preparations, braised, grilled, transformed into pellets or added to the Cantonese rice (Fall et al. 2013).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for L. laevigatus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas. The use of the Nordmøre-grid (one of the most effective bycatch reduction devices (BRDs) used worldwide) in shrimp fisheries can reduce bycatch of L. laevigatus by as much as 54% (Silva et al. 2012).

rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Atractosteus tropicus is a freshwater species known to inhabit rivers and bodies of water with abundant aquatic vegetation (Miller et al. 2005, Nelson 2006). Found in various habitats from large lakes and rivers to sluggish tributaries, backwaters and pools, and can surive in both fresh and brackish waters, but shows a preference for large rivers and swamps with extensive associated floodplains. The maximum size of this species is 100 mm SL (unsexed).
threats: Atractosteus tropicus is threatened by high levels of over exploitation and alterations of its habitat. Distribution and populations have decreased considerably as a result of these activities (Bussing 1998, Aguilera et al. 2002).
population: More information is needed about the population size and population trend of Atractosteus tropicus.
range: Atractosteus tropicus is a freshwater species with a wide distribution. Found in both Caribbean and Pacific-slope drainage basins in Central America, from southern Mexico through Belize, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua, and into Costa Rica (Wiley 1976, Bussing 1998, Miller et al. 2005, Nelson 2006).
useTrade: Atractosteus tropicus is known to be over exploited and as a result natural populations have declined considerably (Bussing 1998, Aguilera et al. 2002).
conservationActions: No conservation actions for Atractosteus tropicus are known.

rationale: The species is native to Lake Pátzcuaro in Michoacán, Western Mexico (Miller et al., 2005). Given its economic value and captive-breeding success the species has been introduced in several Mexican States, including: Chihuahua, Coahuila, Hidalgo, Puebla, Nuevo León, San Luis Potosí, Sinaloa, Veracruz and other localities in  Michoacán (Contreras Balderas & Escalante Cavazos, 1984). Recent genetic studies suggest that C. grandocule is genetically the same as C. estor, therefore the taxonomy needs to be reviewed (Omar Dominguez, Pers. Comm., 2018). The species is assessed as Data Deficient until the taxonomy is resolved.
habitat: Open waters of clear to turbid lakes (Miller et al. 2005). It prefers lentic waters, temperate, without vegetation, with depths of 6 to 10 m; clear or medium turbid, sandy or gravelly bottoms, neutral or alkaline waters (Rosas-Moreno, 1976). Zooplankton has a preference for cladocerans. It spawns in the months of February to June, when the lake reaches a temperature of 18 to 22 ° C (Rosas-Moreno, 1976).
threats: The species is thretened by overfishing, habitat loss and degradation caused by water pollution as a result of urban sewage, agricultural run-off and industrial discharges in Lake Patzcuaro. The species is also threatened by hybridisation with species of the same genus such as C. attenuatum and C. patzcuaro (Soria-Barreto et al. 2016).
population: The fishing of charales in the Lake of Patzcuaro has reduced from 523 tn / year in 1985 to 157 tn / year in 1998 (Orbe-Mendoza and Acevedo, 2002). Chirostoma spp. are particularly susceptible to environmental change. It is also heavily fished for human consumption. Some evidence that average size has decreased and population has declined. In 1985 total annual catch was 523 tons and in 2003 it had decreased to 14 tons, likely with the same fishing effort (Rojas-Carrillo 2006).
range: The species is native to Lake Pátzcuaro in Michoacán, Western Mexico (Miller et al., 2005). Given its economic value and captive-breeding success the species has been introduced in several Mexican States, including: Chihuahua, Coahuila, Hidalgo, Puebla, Nuevo León, San Luis Potosí, Sinaloa, Veracruz and other localities in  Michoacán (Contreras Balderas & Escalante Cavazos, 1984). Recent genetic studies suggests that C. grandocule is genetically the same as C. estor, therefore the taxonomy needs to be reviewed (Omar Dominguez, Pers. Comm., 2018)
useTrade: The species is targeted by fisheries and introduced in multiple states
conservationActions: Chirostoma grandocule fishing has been regulated under the NORMA Oficial Mexicana NOM-036-SAG/PESC-2015, Pesca responsable en el Lago de Pátzcuaro ubicado en el Estado de Michoacán. Especificaciones para el aprovechamiento de los recursos pesqueros.

rationale: Chirostoma humboldtianum is a benthopelagic endemic freshwater fish species widely distributed in isolated basins of Central Mexico. The collection records show a clear increase in the number of C. humboldtianum records in parts of its range as a result of their establishment during the last decades in various artificial reservoirs. Many of these populations are numerous and sustain fisheries, as would be the case of the dams: del Bosque and Tepuxtec in Michoacán; Villa Victoria and Huapango in the State of Mexico and Requena in Hidalgo. However, an overall population decline of approximately 30 % has been observed in the Rio Lerma Basin and Lago de Cuitzeo-Río Grande de Morelia basin of Michoacán and Guanajuato in Central Mexico based on survey data. Additionally, a decline has been inferred due to a reduction in the extent/quality of its natural habitat in the Valley of Mexico. Therefore the species is assessed as Vulnerable under Criterion A.
habitat: Chirostoma species require lentic habitats, such as reservoir and lakes, and are thought to feed on zooplankton, specifically Bosmina species (Soto-Galera et al. 1999, Salgado et al. 2006). This species shows intermediate tolerance to the environmental conditions that prevailed in the Lerma River basin at the end of the eighties, with the following tolerance intervals: temperature of 13-28 ° C, concentration of dissolved oxygen from 2.4 to 15 mg/l, turbidity from undetectable (ND) to 600 UFT, suspended solids ND-580 mg/l, pH from 6.3 to 9.4, hardness from 19 to 280 mg/l of CaCO3, sulfates ND-170, phosphates ND-6.0 and nitrates ND-35.2 (Díaz-Pardo et al. 1993).
threats:
The main threats facing the ichthyofauna of the Lerma river basin are associated with pollution (urban, industrial, agricultural, livestock and mining), the construction of hydraulic works, the extraction of water. In the particular case of lake species, pollution, siltation, drying, overfishing and introduction of invasive species are the main factors that explain the decline of their populations (Díaz-Pardo et al. 1993, Soto-Galera et al. 1998).

The species is of potential use for aquaculture, given that it is a member of the genus that is the main animal protein source in these regions since pre-Hispanic times, leading to a threat of overfishing. This species is also threatened by pollution, sedimentation in addition to the subsequent drying and hypereutrophication of its lake and river habitats. An example of such is the city of Morelia located along the middle reaches of the Río Grande de Morelia (Soto-Galera et al. 1999). The city of Morelia is growing rapidly and is a major commercial, industrial and agricultural centre, that discharges large amounts of largely untreated wastes into the river, as well as surrounding forests being cut down to expand agriculture, leading to soil erosion (Soto-Galera et al. 1999). The combinations of these problems and the inadequate management of procedures have led to reductions in the amount and quality of tributary inputs, leading to a reduction in species number and losses from the Río Grande de Morelia (Soto-Galera et al. 1999).
population:
Habitat alteration had reduced the range of distribution and led to the local extinction of the species in some basins. During the Miocene these basins were connected, allowing dispersal and colonization of new hydrological systems. Later on, tectonic, volcanic and climatic events of the Plio-Pleistocene promoted continuous periods of isolation and re-connection, allowing the species evolve through continuous cycles of expansion and contraction of its distribution. Therefore, it is expected that these events have left signals in the geographical distribution and genetic diversity and divergence of existing populations. Although the analysis of genetic diversity and genetic structure in the population becomes an important factor for the conservation of a species, few studies have been made in this taxon (Rosa et al. 2015).

A population decline has been observed in the Rio Lerma Basin, Lago de Cuitzeo-Rio Grande de Morelia basin of Michoacan and Guanajuato in Central Mexico (Soto-Galera et al. 1999). Additionally, a decline has been inferred due to a reduction in the extent/quality of its natural habitat in the Valley of Mexico (Álvarez del Villar and Navarro 1957). The collection records show a clear increase in the number of C. humboldtianum records in the Lerma river basin, as a result of their establishment during the last decades of the last century in various artificial reservoirs (Díaz-Pardo et al. 1993, Soto-Galera and Alcántara-Soria 2016). Many of these populations are numerous and sustain fisheries, as would be the case of the dams: del Bosque and Tepuxtec in Michoacán; Villa Victoria and Huapango in the State of Mexico and Requena in Hidalgo (SAGARPA 2004, Soto-Galera and Alcántara-Soria 2016).
range: Chirostoma humboldtianum is a benthopelagic endemic freshwater fish species widely distributed in isolated basins of Central Mexico. The species has been observed in lakes and rivers within the Valley of Mexico and also in the upper portion of the Lago de Cuitzeo-Rio Grande de Morelia basin of Michoaca and Guanajuato. It has also been observed in the Cointzio reservoir, the La Mintzita spring and the Insurgente Morelos stream (Soto-Galera et al. 1999).
useTrade: Used for human consumption since pre-Hispanic times and hence are of economic importance.
conservationActions: No conservation actions for the species are known.

rationale:
The Bulldog Splitfin is difficult to find and very shy. It was historically distributed over a large area in Mexico, reaching from the Chapala lake in the west to the Río Laja in the east. Throughout the decades, it disappeared from many of the big lakes and dams and has reduced in numbers where it once was common. In the Pátzcuaro lake, it was an important part of the hauls of the local people, but due to low population numbers, it is no longer used for consumption. Different threats, often specific for certain habitats, eliminated the species or led to a decrease in numbers. Predation by Black Bass extirpated Alloophorus robustus from the Zirahuén lake, while competition from Xiphophorus variatus occurred in Río Laja. Water pollution was the reason for the disappearance of the species from the Chapala lake and Río Grande de Santiago, also causing very low numbers in the Pátzcuaro lake. Only three out of nine original subpopulations now exist.

With our state of knowledge (the two lineages of the Bulldog Splitfin might be seen as separate species in the future), the worst case scenario for AOO (112 km2) meets the threshold for Endangered (500 km2), while the EOO (11,400 km2) meets the threshold for Vulnerable (20,000 km2). Finally, considering the number of locations (8), the above mentioned threats, severe declines in AOO, EOO, locations and subpopulations along with quality of habitats, the Bulldog Splitfin is assessed Vulnerable.
habitat:
Though the Bulldog Splitfin has a historically large distribution, although the species is not common. It lives concealed in vegetation and waits for prey of mainly small fish, crayfish, shrimps, tadpoles and larges invertebrates. Alloophorus robustus is a predatory species; it is quite aggressive as a juvenile of just a few centimetres in length, but bigger individuals seem to be more placid. The habitats of this species vary, encompassing ponds and lakes of different sizes, in addition to springs, channels, creeks and rivers, as long as there is submersed vegetation, reeds or shaded areas between roots of trees. The following passages describe some of the habitats where this species occurs, but it is generally thought to be rare.

La Mintzita is a marshy spring–fed lake of about 80 m diameter that drains into the Río Grande de Morelia and hence into the Lago Cuitzeo. The Río Grande de Morelia/Cuitzeo basin is endorheic, although its fauna indicates that it was once connected to the adjacent Río Lerma basin. Most of the Río Grande de Morelia/Cuitzeo system has been greatly degraded, and La Mintzita is one of the last remaining high-quality sites in the basin. A few hundred metres below the lake the outlet canal receives waste from a large paper mill (Bio Papel Scribe S.A. de C.V.) and no longer has the capability to support fish life, so La Mintzita is isolated from other fish populations in the basin. Lyons (2004) sampled the outlet canal just below the lake with a backpack electroshocker and the lake itself just above the outlet with a seine. The canal was about 8 m wide and 0.5 - 1 m deep with a fast strong current and gravel bottom. In 80 m of sampling, they collected the following Goodeids: 3 Alloophrous robustus, 30 Goodea atripinnis, about 100 Xenotoca cf. variata, 5 Skiffia lermae, and about 15 Zoogoneticus quitzeoensis. They also caught 10 Poeciliopsis infans (Poeciliidae; native) and about 25 Xiphophorus helleri (an exotic Poeciliid), plus 10 Yuriria alta (Cyprinidae; native) and 10 Scartomyzon austrinus. They then pulled the seine over about 300 m2 in the lake, which averaged about 1 m deep with a sand and clay bottom and clear water at 15-19 °C temperature. They captured 3 A. robustus, 5 G. atripinnis, 30 X. cf. variata, about 100 S. lermae, 3 Z. quitzeoensis, plus at least 1,000 P. infans, 5 X. helleri, and 30 Y. alta (Lyons 2004).

The spring in Chapultepec, Lago de Pátzcuaro drainage, is egg shaped and fenced in with two effluents, one on the south end, one on the west end. The size is approximately 100 x 50 m, the depth from observations outside of the fence is at least 1.5 m. The effluents are channels from about 80 cm (south-channel) to more than 1 m (west-channel) width. Both channels have a sandy ground with gravel and several rocks on the borders. In recent years (2014-2017), submerse vegetation in the channels occurred in form of some floating water hyacinths directly after the outlet in the south and areas with dense Egeria sp. stocks. Grassy riparian vegetation covered the borders and hang over the surface, the west-channel was partly covered by trees. At the west-outlet, some exotic Zantedeschia sp. grew along with the borders and shaded it partly. This part of the channel was densely planted with Egeria and deep to 1 m. After 120 m from the outlet, it is dammed, leaving the subsequent part of the channel with a varying depth between 15 and 40 cm. The current in both channels was fast to moderate, the water looked characteristic milky blue, probably due to some dissolved minerals. The vegetation in the spring itself was composed of Egeria sp. and Potamogeton sp. The water parametres taken in March 2017 were: water temperaturea 19.5°C; pH, 7.22; conductivity, 1,180 μS. Only a single juvenile male was found in the west channel during a survey by Köck et al. in 2017, and two individuals during a survey by Lyons et al. in 2014 at the same place; other fish species recorded were Allotoca diazi, Goodea atripinnis, Skiffia lermae and Allotoca dugesii. A survey by Mexican students in 2018 was not successful in finding any Alloophorus.

The Cuitzeo lake is the oldest and second largest Mexican lake and covers an area of about 500 km2 including the marshy grass surrounding it. It is irregular shaped with northern, western an eastern sections, connected by marshland in the middle. The western section is divided into an east and a west part by two north-south dams, built for HW's 43 and 43B. The lake is astatic and very shallow (about 0.5 m deep), consisting of muddy ground with murky water. In dry years, the western part of the west section is isolated completely from the east part by closing the passages under the roads to save the west section from drying up completely. With this method, at least the east part of the west section keeps water. The lake is surrounded by partly dense and large reed areas. In one reed area directly at the HW43B dam, Köck et al. collected a juvenile male on a survey in November 2014 (wet season).

The Presa Verduzco or Presa de La Luz east of Jacona de Plancarte is shaped like a cake slice with the effluent in the sharp angle in the north. The circular arc has a length of about 400 m, the radius a varying length between 210 and 280 m. The arc is mainly bordered with reeds and trees, providing some small coves and reed islands. In one of the coves under riparian vegetation, Köck et al. collected a group of young fish about 3 cm long on a survey in 2016. The ground of the Presa is made of sand, gravel and silt, with parts showing bigger rocks and stones. The ground of the reed-areas is mainly made of silt, sand and mud.
threats:
The Bulldog Splitfins suffers from different threats and, in some cases, threat scenarios are typical for a certain habitat, like the total loss of the species from the Zirahuén basin by predation and competition though non-native Black Bass species (Micropterus salmoides and punctulatus).

The main threats to the type subpopulation (Lago de Pátzcuaro subpopulation) are water pollution and urban development in the area, including expanding tourism, and exposed exotic fish species since the early 1930's. Introduction of Black bass (Micropterus salmoides) in 1933, and Common carp (Cyprinus carpio) and Tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus) since the 1970's, has almost completely eliminated the species from the lake. The common water hyazinth is also a threat; by covering the surface it reduces the flow of the channels and interferes with gas exchange. Additionally, as a carnivorous species, increasing turbidity of the habitats reduces chances to find food, especially for fry (Hernández-Chávez et al. 2014, for Allotoca catarinae). It's estimated that the water infiltration rate for Humedales del Lago de Pátzcuaro has been reduced from 12% to 8%, but assuming the potential presence of a new period of dry years in the region, the hydraulic contribution of the basin will be critical to maintain the balance of the water level. In addition, erosion and loss of the soil will carry on as the basin continues its process of ecological deterioration; this is expected to cause greater reduction in the water entry into the lake due due to the decrease in the infiltration rate and the lack of recharge of surface aquifers. Its waters, exploited since pre-Columbian times, are also effected by the use of surrounding land for agricultural activity. This covers just over 40% of the basin and approximately 30% of the total area consists of grasslands used by cattle and horses. The Río Angulo subpopulation also suffers from common carp competition and increasing sedimentation of the Lago Zacapú. Water pollution, increasing turbidity and urban development threatens the Río Cupatitzio subpopulation in and south of Uruapán. Additional threats come from a trout farm in Uruapán that might impact the native fish via escaped carp. These three subpopulations have to be regarded as Critically Endangered: the Laguna de Zirahuén subpopulation due to Black Bass, the Laguna Yuriría subpopulation through water pollution and the Middle Río Lerma subpopulation (by severe water pollution everywhere and competition through non-native Xiphophorus variatus in the Río Laja) may even be Possibly Extinct. The threats to the Río Grande de Morelia subpopulation vary by location. The Lago Cuitzeo stock is threatened by pollution, nutrients, sedimentation and severe droughts, which increase predation by waterbirds, including American white Pelicans (Pelecanus erythrorhynchos) that overwinter here from the United States. The areas providing water for the lake, such as La Mintzita spring and Presa Cointzio dam are not effected by droughts or visited by bigger birds. Pollution, urban sewage, water extraction for human consumption, nutrients and non-native fish are threats to these stocks. La Mintzita remains in good condition, but its future is uncertain. Settlement and use of the adjacent lands around the lake have increased in the last 10 years, as has runoff of domestic wastes into the lake. More ominously, the city of Morelia is considering pumping water from the lake for municipal uses, which could reduce the lake level and perhaps even eliminate the springs that feed the lake, destroying this unique habitat. This subpopulation has to be regarded Endangered. The Lago de Chapala/Río Grande de Santiago subpopulation is almost completely gone due to reduction in habitat quality. The only known extant stock inhabits the isolated Lagos Los Negritos east of the Chapala lake, covering an area of approximately 0.3 km2. The fish are threatened by habitat loss, agricultural influences, non-native fish competition (Lepomis sp.) and recreational activity. Samples in 2017 were not successful. This subpopulation is regarded Critically Endangered. The Cotija subpopulation is threatened by agriculture, sedimentation, habitat loss, competition through non-native fish, urban sewage, human activities. The Río Duero subpopulation has been partly affected by Black Bass introduction (Lago de Camécuaro), partly by competition through non-native fish (Xiphophorus hellerii, Poecilia mexicana), through pollution, urban sewage, urban development and habitat loss. Due to at least two habitats in each subpopulation, they are regarded Endangered.
population:
In contrary to other bigger species of Goodeids - like Goodea atripinnis or Chapalichthys spp. - it is hard to gain information on population status and development of Alloophorus robustus, mainly because of its secret way of life. As an ambush predator, hunting mainly at dusk and dawn (at least from obersvation in aquariums), it is often hidden at daytime and derived from aquarium observations shy and cautious. Nevertheless, some statements can be made taking in consideration fishery information. So was the Bulldog Splitfin once a species targeted by fishermen due to its size and obviously also due to its number. Reports from the development of fish populations in the Pátzcuaro lake talk about descreasing stocks the way stocks of Tilapia and common carp increased since the 1970's. Additionally, looking at the situation within the Zirahuén lake and the spring in San Francisco del Rincón, where this species has been extirpated by Black Bass, a reduction of the Bulldog Splitfn stocks by Black Bass being introduced in the Pátzcuaro lake in 1933 (but becoming extinct again) can be inferred. So despite of the size, the Bulldog Splitfins seems to be not able to compete with Micropterus spp. Even smaller non-native species, but being competitors for prey, might be a problem, Alloophorus is not able to solve. So the introduction of Xiphophorus variatus, a Platyfish, in dams along the Río Laja, seems to had a dramatic impact on the local Bulldog Splitfin population, which became extirpated (Lyons 2011). Finally can be said, that the population of Alloophorus robustus shrinked dramatically, and it is sometimes entirely gone from bigger lakes, but also with decreasing numbers in other habitats known to be strongholds. The situation of the different subpopulations and their status is illustrated under "Threats".

Another factor might have a big influence on the threat status of the population in the future: Phylogenetic studies gave a hint, that the Bulldog Splitfin might be comprised by two species with the original Alloophorus robustus being originally distributed from the Río Turbio system, a northern Río Lerma affluent, and the Río Angulo drainage S of the Lerma river eastwards. Then the second species by contrast would have been distributed from the Río Duero drainage westwards, including the Chapala-Río Grande de Santiago system and the Río Balsas headwaters. In that case, the reduction of AOO, EOO and number of locations simply by splitting in two species would directly lead to an upgrading of the threat status of both species.
range:
The Bulldog Splitfin belongs to a few Goodeid species with a large distribution range. It is historically known from the federal states of Guanajuato, Jalisco and Michoacán and occured at the type location, the endorheic Lago de Pátzcuaro, with surrounding springs and tributaries, the adjacent endorheic Laguna de Zirahuén including the Estanque Las Condembas (Lago de Opopeo), and the likewise endorheic Río Grande de Morelia basin with the Lago Cuitzeo, several springs of the Río Grande de Morelia, the Presa Cointzio, the Laguna de Yuriría and several affluents of the Cuitzeo lake. The historical range also includes the ríos San Antonio (Río Santa Bárbara) and Cupatitzio in Uruapán, Río Balsas drainage, the Río Angulo drainage with the Lago Zacapú, and several northern tributaries of the middle Río Lerma like the ríos Laja, Turbio and Guanajuato. More collection sites are known from the Río Duero drainage (a lower Río Lerma affluent) including several spring areas (Presas Orandino and Verduzco), the Lago de Chapala with the isolated Lagos Los Negritos east of the lake and subsequent sections of the Río Grande de Santiago, and finally the Presa San Juanico and other habitats in the Río Grande headwaters in the Cotija region, Río Balsas drainage. 

Lyons (2011) reported that this species disappeared from the Lago de Chapala, the adjacent Río Grande de Santiago and the Río Lerma and most of its tributaries. It no longer inhabits the Laguna de Yuriría and lost its last stronghold north of the Río Lerma in a spring in San Francisco del Rincón; as a result, there are potentially no remaining habitats in the states of Jalisco and Guanajuato (except for northern shores of the Cuitzeo lake). It has become rare in many other habitats; larger stocks can only be found in some springs of the Río Duero drainage, the spring at the Molino Viejo de Chapultepec (Lago de Pátzcuaro drainage), the Lago Zacapú and the La Mintzita spring (Río Grande de Morelia drainage).

In 2008, the Bulldog Splitfin was estimated to have disappeared from more than the 50% of its historical range (Domínguez-Domínguez et al. 2008).

The river and lake names above are officially used by the Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía (http://antares.inegi.org.mx); nevertheless, other names may be used more often or better known and therefore preferred.
useTrade: The species was targeted by local commercial fisheries in Lake Pátzcuaro but, due to increasing stocks of Oreochormis niloticus and Common carps causing competition, it almost completely disappeared from the lake. It is no longer used for consumption and is not a target species for the ornamental fish trade.
conservationActions:
The conservation efforts for the Bulldog Splitfin concentrate on Ramsar Sites, with the hope of a positive effect on species inhabiting these sites. However, there are no conservation plans for native fish in these areas, so the successes are negligible. The Alloophorus robustus - fishing has been included under the sustainable fisheries regulation for Lake Pátzcuaro approved in 2015 (Norma Oficial Mexicana NOM-036-SAG/PESC-2015: Pesca responsable en el Lago de Pátzcuaro ubicado en el Estado de Michoacán. Especificaciones para el aprovechamiento de los recursos pesqueros.). Anyway, due to ongoing competition through common carps and Tilapia, and due to predation by Black Bass in historical time, the species has disappeared from the lake almost entirely and plays therefore no more a role in consumption and fisheries.

Humedales del Lago de Pátzcuaro within the Pátzcuaro lake, is surrounded by mountains and rugged topography with a steep slopes. The lake is an endorheic and eutrophic system, meaning it has no outlet to the sea and is shallow and turbid, with a high concentration of nutrients. In the southern area of ​​the lake from Pátzcuaro, there is an average annual water temperature of 19.2 °C and a total alkalinity of 165 mg/l. As a closed system without significant tributaries, this lake may be more sensitive to hydraulic imbalance, with the annual volume variations being mainly determined by the precipitation, evapotranspiration, surface runoff and infiltration water through internal springs. It is also occasionally fed by temporary surface streams during the rainy season, such as the San Gregorio rivers and the Santa Fe and Soto streams in the north. In the extreme southwest it receives water from agricultural discharges of the Chapultepec channel (Ramsar Secretariat, Site No.1447, 2005).

La Mintzita is a reservoir formed by a series of springs. The site is home to species that are protected under Mexican legislation, some of which are threatened, such as the Zoogoneticus quitzeoensis and Skiffia lermae. The site counts more than a hundred bird species, including Anas platyrhynchos diazi and Bubo virginianus, in addition to the endangered Buteo jamaicensis and Regulus calendula. This wetland plays an important role in the retention of sediments from higher altitudes of the catchment area, as well as filtering nutrients produced in the Cointzio Resort. Threats to this Ramsar Site, such as the overuse of water resources, illegal domestic drainage, the deforestation of the gallery forests and human encroachment activities should be regulated once the Management Programme for the State Protected Area is finalized. The area is already designated as a Zone Subject to Ecological Preservation and a management plan is currently being prepared to regulate, limit and sanction illegal activities. The plan is expected to be finalized by the end of 2010 (Ramsar Site No.1919. Most recent RIS information: 2009).

The Lago Zacapú is fed by approximately 20 cold water springs (19 °C), which emerge at the southwestern end of the valley of Zacapú, some of which are used for human consumption and recreation (Ramsar Secretariat, Site No.1465, 2004). Due to the confluence of fish species, migratory birds, plants and endemic amphibians (Ambystoma andersoni), it can be considered as a broad transitional zone, giving it great ecological importance. The two main sections of Lago Zacapú differ: one has depths of between 4 to 6 m, and the other ranges from 12 to 90 m deep, bedded by soils and alluvium (Ramsar Secretariat, Site No.1465, 2004).

There is an ongoing monitoring and ex-situ breeding project run by the Laboratorio de Biología Aucatica in Michoacan University, Morelia, Mexico

rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of  its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is  likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable.  Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Poecilia mexicana is a known cave dwelling species, with the example of a distinct population present in the Cueva del Azufre system in the Mexican state of Tabasco (Tobler, et al. 2008), this species also is known to occur within the shallows of rivers too (Miller, 1983; Schlupp et al., 2002). Unlike other cave fish species, although it can live in complete darkeness Poecilia mexicana still has functional eyes which are thought to be linked to sexual preference choice, with large males favoured by females (Bisazza and Pilastro, 1997) given they are superior in dyadic conflicts as well (Ribowski and Franck, 1993).
