Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough, scaleless skin often covered with small spicules, beak-like dental place divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single short dorsal fin, a single shore anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or injured, and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, or liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are no major threats known to this species. However, due to its affinity with seagrass beds and coral reefs, it may be experiencing population declines. As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, south and southeast Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008).

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

In the Persian Gulf, T. flavimaculosus is caught as bycatch in trawls and traps (Carpenter et al. 1997).
population: There is no population information available for this species. However, it does seem to be fairly common, but not abundant. Although there have been no confirmed population declines with this species, it may be in decline due to its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds. In the Persian Gulf, this species is fairly common in museum collections and has been recorded with abundance from Israel (Accessed through the Fishnet 2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2014–02–12).
range: Torquigener flavimaculosus is a reef-associated species found at depths of three to 57 metres in the western Indian Ocean, from east Africa to the Seychelles, in the Red Sea and Persian Gulf (Randall 1995). It has also been recorded in Madagascar (Gillibrand et al. 2007). This species is a Lessepsian immigrant to the eastern Mediterranean via the Suez Canal (Golani et al. 2006). It was first recorded in Haifa Bay in Israel in 1987 (Golani 1987), along the Turkish Mediterranean coast (Golani et al. 2006) at Fethiye, Turkey (Bilecenoğlu 2005), and at Yalissos, Trianda Bay, Greece (Corsini-Foka 2006).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species' wide range most likely overlaps several marine protected areas. The current known range for this species is undergoing expansion through the Red Sea and up through to the eastern Mediterranean and Aegean seas. This is one of many species being introduced to the Mediterranean Sea after the construction of the Suez Canal.

rationale: Lagocephalus guentheri is known from the  Red Sea eastward to Pakistan and southwestward to South Africa at depths ranging from 1 to 237 metres. It inhabits the continental shelf, and is found over sandy or muddy substrates. There are no known major threats. This species is harvested for food in parts of the Red Sea but is not a targeted species. It is assessed as Least Concern
habitat:
Adult L. guentheri inhabit the continental shelf and are found over sandy or muddy bottoms (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). Specimens purportedly of this species have been recorded in mangroves off the coast of Tanzania (Berkström et al. 2012). In the Gulf, individuals ranging in size from 7.6 to 18.4 cm were taken in the intertidal zone over muddy substrates (Zare et al. 2013). Lagocephalus guentheri is a demersal, marine species that occurs in tropical waters. Maximum total length for this species is 26.0 cm male/unsexed (Matsuura pers. comm. 2014).

Puffers of the genus Lagocephalus are globally distributed in warm shallow waters, however classification at the species level in Lagocephalus has not yet been studied in detail, causing confusion in the status of several species including L. cheesemanii, L. gloveri, L. spadiceus, and L. wheeleri (Matsuura et al. 2011).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are no major threats known to this species. Lagocephalus guentheri may be taken as bycatch in shrimp trawls in South Africa and the Persian Gulf (Fennessy et al. 1994, Carpenter et al. 1997, K. Matsuura  pers. comm. 2011). Although no population declines have been observed, loss of habitat in mangrove forests may be adversely affecting the population numbers of this fish. 

Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction. (Polidoro et al. 2010). In the Caribbean, approximately 24% of mangrove area has been lost over the past quarter-century (FAO 2007).
population:
There is little information available on the population status of this species (K. Matsuura pers comm. 2011). Specimens of L. guentheri are uncommon in museum collections, and are represented by at least seven lots (FishNet2 searched 30 April 2012). Due to its affinity with mangroves, L. guentheri may be undergoing population decreases due to loss of habitat.

Due to previous taxonomic confusion, population trends and rescue effects for this species are unknown.
range: Lagocephalus guentheri is found the Red Sea eastward to Pakistan and southwestward to South Africa (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014). It has also has been recorded from the eastern Mediterranean (Matsuura et al. 2011, K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2012). This species occurs in shallow waters. The maximum depths of 274 m reported for this species is in error and most likely reported for L. spadiceus (Matsuura pers. comm. 2011).
useTrade: Lagocephalus guentheri is a component of artisanal fisheries in some countries bordering the Red Sea, however it is not explicitly targeted (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). There is little to no commercial interest in the Persian Gulf. In Tanzania, it is not considered a commercial species (Lugendo et al. 2007). This species is caught as bycatch in trawls (Carpenter et al. 1997).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for L. guentheri, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Polyspina piosae is a subtropical species distributed from Western Australia to South Australia. It is a nearshore, demersal species which is typically found over sandy bottoms, either singly or in small groups, at depths ranging from one to 37 metres. Although there have been no documented population declines in this species, it may be taken as bycatch in trawl fisheries operating in Australia, and is part of the Australian specialty marine aquarium trade. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for P. piosae; however, its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Polyspina piosae is a subtropical, demersal species which generally inhabits sandy bottoms in coastal waters, including surf zones and areas with sparse seagrass. It is also found on sand near reefs and in protected coastal bays (Gomon 2008, B. Hutchins, W.A. Museum pers. comm. 2006, S.A. Museum record 1982, cited in OZCAM database 2004, R. Foster and S.A. Museum, pers. comm., 2006). Polyspina piosae typically occurs singly or in small groups (Kuiter 1996). It may graze on seagrass (White et al. 2011).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Polyspina piosae may be vulnerable to capture in prawn trawls, in the northern, central and southern Spencer Gulf. Similarly, given the habitat and depth range of this species, it is likely that P. piosae may be (or may have been) part of the pufferfish bycatch in eastern Great Australian Bight and Gulf St. Vincent (Baker 2009). Due to its affinity with seagrass beds and reef structures, this fish may be experiencing population declines due to loss of habitat, although no measurable decreases have been observed.

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and Southeast Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008)

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).
population: Polyspina piosae is not frequently encountered but is sometimes spotted in moderate sized schools (Gomon et al. 2008).  In one survey study in Western Australia, 645 individuals of this species were found, and comprised about 1% of total individuals taken (Hyndes 1999). Specimens of P. piosae are moderately common in museum collections (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2013-09-13). Although no measurable declines have been observed, this species of fish may be experiencing population decreases due to loss of habitat in sea grass beds and reefs.
range: Polyspina piosae is known in the eastern Indian Ocean from the Western and South Australian territories, occurring as far eastward as Kangaroo Island (Hardy, in Gomon et al. 1994). It is found at depths ranging from zero to 37 m.
useTrade: This species is likely a component of the South Australian specialty marine aquarium trade (Baker 2009).
conservationActions:
The distribution of P. piosae overlaps with several marine protected areas.

Polyspina piosae was evaluated as Data Deficient by Baker, 2009 in "Marine Species of Conservation Concern in South Australia", due to its limited distribution, the scarcity of published records, its preference for shallow water, nearshore habitats including coastal reefs which may be vulnerable to anthropogenically-induced habitat modification, it's known depth range (at which prawn and fish trawls are known to operate), the site-specific reproductive habits of pufferfishes in general, the unquantifiable threat of collection for the aquarium trade faced by this species in Southern Australia, and the lack of information about it's biology, population dynamics, or relative abundance (Baker 2009).

rationale: Sphoeroides nephelus has a wide range in the tropical western Atlantic, from northeastern Florida to the eastern Gulf of Mexico. It is primarily associated with coastal and estuarine habitats in shallow waters to depths of 20 metres. It appears to be common and abundant in parts of its range. There are no major threats known to this species, its known range overlaps with several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Sphoeroides nephelus is a coastal, demersal species which is often found to inhabit bays, estuaries, and protected coastal waters (Shipp 1972), including hypersaline lagoons (Peralta-Meixueiro and Vega-Cendejas 2011). It can be found in salinities ranging from five to 45 ppm (Hoese 1960). In Florida, where it appears to be abundant, it is found in habitats characterized by mangroves or emergent wetland vegetation, such as Spartina spp. (Johnson et al. 1999). It is known to form loose aggregations around man-made structures such as bridges and piers etc. (Shipp 2003). The diet consists mainly of invertebrates, principally molluscs and crustaceans (Shipp and Yerger 1969). This species is known to accumulate saxitoxin (Abbott et al. 2009), and has been responsible for poisoning events. Due to morphological variation in colouration and prickles throughout its range, S. nephelus has been frequently misidentified (Shipp and Yerger 1969). Sphoeroides nephelus coexists with S. spengleri and S. testudineus in parts of its range (Palacios-Sánchez and Vega-Cendejas 2010).

Sphoeroides nephelus reaches maturity at 165 mm (Shipp and Yerger 1969) and commonly reaches a total length of 200 mm (Shipp 1978). It feeds primarily on shell fish and crustaceans but also sometimes of finfish (Shipp 2002).

The genus Sphoeroides was found to be paraphyletic, and it is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are no major threats known to this species. Although no measurable decrease in population numbers has been observed, S. nephelus may be undergoing population decreases due to loss of habitat. One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction (Polidoro et al. 2010). In the Caribbean, approximately 24% of mangrove area has been lost over the past quarter-century (FAO 2007).
population:
Sphoeroides nephelus appears to be the most common and abundant tetraodontid in the shallow coastal lagoons of northeastern Florida (Johnson et al. 1999, Turtora and Schotman 2010). It uncommon in the coastal hypersaline lagoons of the Yucatan Peninsula, and appears to be replaced by S. testudineus in this part of its range (Peralta-Meixueiro and Vega-Cendejas 2011). Mean annual catch per unit effort (CPUE) caught in the Southeast Area Monitoring and Assessment Program (SEAMAP) during the summer trawl surveys from 1987 to 2010 indicate stable trends. Fall trawl surveys only have two records, for 1990 and 2010 (NOAA unpub. data). In contrast, S. nephelus was identified as a species of concern in Louisiana based on declines in mean CPUE after 1991; this species appeared to have once been abundant in Louisiana's estuaries and coastal waters, and its abundance appears to have drastically decreased there (Sandy 2010, based on Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries data). However it is worth noting that S. nephelus is generally more abundant in the eastern half of the Gulf of Mexico (Sandy 2010).

Due to its affinity with mangroves and sea grasses, this fish may be experiencing population decreases due to loss of habitat.

In a recent study conducted by the Gulf of Mexico Reef Fish Industry, only five individuals were taken (all by vertical line and none by longline buoy gear) over the course of a one year study (Scott-Denton and Williams 2013).
range: Sphoeroides nephelus is found in the Western Atlantic, from northeastern Florida (between Jacksonville and Marineland) throughout the majority of the Caribbean Sea and in the eastern Gulf of Mexico, and south to the Yucatan Peninsula (Shipp and Yerger 1969). It is typically found at depths ranging from zero to 11 metres (Lieske and Myers 1994), but can be found to 20 metres (Shipp 2002).
useTrade: This species was historically caught in mixed catches with the previously targeted S. maculatus, a fishery which peaked in the 1970s and has since declined. Sphoroides nephelus is easily and unintentionally caught by recreational fishers, and occasionally consumed despite several reports of saxitoxin poisoning (Deeds et al. 2008).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. This species range overlaps several marine protected areas.

rationale: Takifugu stictonotus is distributed in the North West Pacific, where it is common and locally abundant in parts of its range. It inhabits sandy and rocky habitats in ranging from very shallow waters to 30 metres, and is also associated with river mouths. Takifugu stictonotus is not targeted, however it can be incidentally harvested. There are no known additional species-specific threats, however the extent to which T. stictonotus is impacted by environmental degradation resulting from large-scale anthropogenic activity within its range is largely unknown. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. stictonotus. However, it is found in marine protected areas, and fishery management strategies implemented within its range are likely to offer a degree of protection. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takifugu stictonotus is a demersal species which can be found in the lower mouths of rivers (Obsyuzyan and Sokolovsky 2003).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are no confirmed species-specific threats to T. stictonotus. It may be threatened by coastal habitat degradation and overfishing in parts of its range.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). This species does not appear to be explicitly targeted by fisheries, and  the  species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. stictonotus are unknown. It may be taken as bycatch.

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). As culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aquacultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefor likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
There is little species-specific population information available for T. stictonotus. Takifugu stictonotus is common and locally abundant in Japan, however it is considered rare in Chinese waters. During collections of Takifugu spp. from the Pacific Coast of Tohoku area of Japan for analysis of tetrodotoxin (TXX) content, this species represented three out of 164 specimens collected, and was the least frequently collected Takifugu species (Kodama et al. 1983).

Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Takifugu stictonotus is common in museum collections. It was represented by 17 lots in searches of the FishNet2 database.
range: In the Northwest Pacific Takifugu stictonotus is distributed from southern Hokkaido, Japan to the East China and Yellow seas to Taiwan (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014). It is found at depths ranging from one to 30 metres.
useTrade: Takifugu stictonotus is incidentally caught but does not appear to be targeted. The Japanese name of this species is Gomafugu.
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. stictonotus, however it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. stictonotus.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations (UN) Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012). Following the ratification of the UN Convention of the Law of the Sea, Japan implemented the Total Allowable Effort (TAE) system in Ise Bay and Mikawa Bay (Hoshino 2010). Stock enhancement programs exist for this species in Japan using hatchery raised fingerlings (Fushimi 2001). Optimal release locations have been determined (Nakajima et al. 2008), however it has been found that hatchery-reared juveniles were more easily preyed upon than wild juveniles due to differences in swimming depth and TTX concentrations (Shimizu et al. 2008).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2009), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Takifugu snyderi is distributed in the northwestern Pacific from South Korea, Japan to China. It is typically found at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 20 meters. Juveniles have been recorded from near shore surfzones. Takifugu snyderi appears to be common in parts of its range, and can be locally abundant. Takifugu snyderi may be impacted by over-exploitation and habitat degradation in parts of its range. It is a commercial species which is targeted for the Fugu trade. It is marketed as "shosaifugu" in Japan and is caught primarily by longline. The extent to which T. snyderi is impacted by the Fugu trade is unknown. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. snyderi. However, it is found in marine protected areas, and fishery management strategies, including seasonal closures and size limits, implemented within its range are likely to offer a degree of protection. Takifugu snyderi is therefore assessed as Least Concern. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takifugu snyderi is a subtropical, demersal species. In Japan, juveniles have been recorded from nearshore surfzones (Suda et al. 2004).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Fugu fishery
Takigufu snyderi is commercially targeted for the Fugu trade (Kawata 2012). Harvesting levels at the present time do not suggest that population declines approaching threatened thresholds (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). 

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). As culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aquacultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefor likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
There is little species-specific population information for T. snyderi. Takifugu snyderi is common and locally abundant in Japan (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). It is common in museum collections (13 lots).

Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).
range: In the Western Pacific, T. snyderi is distributed from Japan, with northernmost records located off the Tohoku district, to the southern Korean Peninsula (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014). This species is found at depths ranging from one to 30 metres.
useTrade: Takifugu snyderi, also known as "shōsai-fugu" in Japan, is commercially targeted for the consumptive pufferfish trade. In Japan, pufferfish are caught primarily using modified longlines which are attractive to novice fishermen due to their ease of use (Kawata 2012). The Japanese name of this species is Shōsai-fugu.
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. snyderi, however, it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. snyderi.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012). Following the ratification of the UN Convention of the Law of the Sea, Japan implemented the Total Allowable Effort (TAE) system in Ise Bay and Mikawa Bay (Hoshino 2010). Stock enhancement programs exist for this species in Japan using hatchery raised fingerlings (Fushimi 2001). Optimal release locations have been determined (Nakajima et al. 2008), however it has been found that hatchery-reared juveniles were more easily preyed upon than wild juveniles due to differences in swimming depth and TTX concentrations (Shimizu et al. 2008).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50 m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing  areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2009), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Takifugu basilevskianus was described as endemic to the Shandong Peninsula in China. There is some doubt as to the taxonomic validity of this species, however pending revision this species is accepted as valid. This species may have undergone severe population declines, as it was historically fished but is no longer reported in landings. It is closely related to T. rubripes, T. pseudommus and T. chinensis, geographically sympatric species which have experienced varying degrees of population decline. Given the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within the genus and the existing doubt concerning the distribution, population, and habitat/ecology of this species species, conclusions about population trends cannot currently be made. Therefore T. basilveskianus is listed Data Deficient. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
There is little species-specific habitat and ecology information available for T. basilevskianus. 

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough, scaleless skin often covered with small spicules, beak-like dental place divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single short dorsal fin, a single shore anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or injured, are and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, or liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are anecdotal accounts of population decline in T. basilevskianus, the magnitude of which cannot currently be quantified. Given that this species' closest genetic relatives (T. rubripes, T. pseudommus, and T. chinensis) are geographically sympatric, are highly-commercialized, and have undergone varying degrees of decline, we infer that the T. basilevskianus is likely to be impacted by the following threats:

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000's had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). Although the species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. basilevskianus are unknown, it is likely that populations of this commercially important species are impacted by this fishery.

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Because culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aqua-cultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefore likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
Population Structure
Molecular analyses of the whole mitochondrial genome of the genus Takifugu revealed that the genetic differences between T. basilevskiannus, T. pseudommus, T. chinensis, and T. rubripes are not significantly different from the genetic differences between individuals within the species T. basilevskiannus, reinforcing the need for further taxonomic studies of the genus using molecular and morphological techniques (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Other population information
Takifugu basilevskianus was historically taken as bycatch together with other puffers within its geographic range. However, it has not been reported in recent years (Matsuura pers. comm. 2011).

 Takifugu basilevskianus is rare in available museum collection records, and was absent from a FishNet2 Database Search (FishNet2 Database searched November 2013).
range: Takifugu basilevskianus only occurs in the Bohai Sea and north Yellow Sea. It is endemic to China since it is only known from the Yantai, Qingdao, Longkou and Dayu islands along the coastal waters of Shandong Peninsula, off the Shandong Province (Su and Li 2002). It has been reported to occur at depths ranging from zero to 40 metres. This is a doubtful species (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade:
Takifugu basilevskianus is consumed as a food fish, but is not explicitly targeted. However, it is worth noting that this species is genetically very similar to T. rubripes, which is a highly-commercial species in the east Asia region. Takifugu basilevskianus, like other Fugu species, is primarily caught by bottom long-line fishing, a method which is highly effective at landing Takifugu spp. pufferfishes (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011).

Aquaculture
There is no evidence that T. basilevskianus is artificially cultured. Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Takifugu pufferfishes, principally represented by the tiger puffer, T. rubripes, are raised in floating net pens in Japan, Korea, and China (Belle and Nash 2009). The total wild catch of pufferfish species in Japan has been relatively stable, ranging from 7,800 to 11,000 tonnes from 1995 to 2002. The four most common species consumed in Japan are T. rubripes, T. snyderi, T. chinensis, and T. porphyreus. Aquaculture efforts focus on T. rubripes, which ranks fifth among marine aquacultured species (the top aquacultured species in Japan are: Yellowtail (Seriola quinqueradiata), Red Sea Bream (Pagrus major), coho Salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) and Japanese flounder (Paralichthys olivaceus). Although highly valuable (the market price of T. rubripes is 1.5 times that of Japanese flounder, three times that of yellowtail or seabream), the value began to decrease rapidly from the late 1990s onwards due to the importation of Tiger puffer from China. In Japan, the majority of fingerlings produced in commercial hatcheries are then raised in floating net cages for direct consumption. About 15 million fingerlings are produced by commercial hatcheries for aquaculture, 1.5 times higher than the amount produced for release for stock enhancement by semi-governmental hatcheries in 1999. One of the most serious problems in the net cage aquaculture of tiger puffer is high (>50%) mortality from outbreaks of parasitic diseases (Ogawa and Inouye 1997).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Takifugu basilevskianus, however, it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. basilevskianus. 

Fugu Fishery
This species may be taken as bycatch in the Fugu fishery. The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007). This species is found in marine protected areas including the Changdao Nature Reserve (53 km2) and Rongchengtianee Nature Reserve (105 km2) (Wood 2007).

Further Research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Marilyna darwinii is found in the western central Pacific Ocean from Papua New Guinea, and northern Western Australia to northern Queensland. It is associated with a variety of habitats, including mangroves and estuaries, and is known to occur at depths ranging from zero to 10 metres. It can be locally common and is the dominant bycatch species in the mud crab fishery in north Queensland. There have been no documented population declines in M. darwinii. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for M. darwinii, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Marilyna darwinii is a demersal species found in shallow marine and brackish waters. It is known from a variety of habitats, including trawling grounds, sandy bottoms, and mangroves.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: Marilyna darwinii is taken as bycatch in mud crab fisheries.This species may be experiencing population decreases due to its affinity for mangrove forests. Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction (Polidoro et al. 2010).
population:
There is little information available on the population status of this species. Most abundance records or surveys are from Australia and only presence or absence is noted. Marilyna darwinii is the dominant bycatch species in the mud crab fishery in north Queensland (FRDC Project 2000/142, Fishery Report Number 80). It can be locally common (Hardy pers. comm. 2011).

Specimens of M. darwinii are common in museum collections (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2012-08-05). Although no measurable decreases have been observed for this species of fish, it may be undergoing a population decrease due to its affinity with mangrove forests and the loss of habitat.
range: Marilyna darwinii is found in the western central Pacific Ocean from northern Western Australia to northern Queensland, and Papua New Guinea (Kailoya 1991). It is found at depths ranging from zero to 10 metres.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for M. darwinii, however, its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Takifugu alboplumbeus is distributed throughout the coastal waters of China at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 50 metres. Juveniles are found in mangroves and estuaries. This species appears to be common in parts of its range. There are no known species-specific threats, however the extent to which T. alboplumbeus is impacted by environmental degradation resulting from large-scale anthropogenic activity within its range is largely unknown. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. alboplumbeus, and its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takifugu alboplumbeus is found on hard or sandy substrates in shallow waters to depths of 50 metres. It is usually solitary, but larger fishes sometimes form small aggregations in large crevices. While the flesh has sometimes been considered innocuous, it is toxic. Additionally, the liver and ovaries are extremely toxic, and the testes, skin and intestine are highly toxic (Nakabo 2002). The annual spawning season of this species in Hong Kong waters is from December to February (Yu and Yu 2002, Yu 2003). Juveniles are typically found in estuaries and mangroves (M. Liu and J. Liu pers. comm. 2011). In an experiment, the ovaries of this species were less toxic during its spawning season (Yu 2003).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single, usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in T. alboplumbeus. However, it is likely to be impacted by the following:

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). Although the species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. alboplumbeus are unknown, it is likely that populations of this commercially important species are impacted by this fishery.

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). As culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aqua-cultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefore likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time, the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea, all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Takifugu alboplumbeus is one of the two most common species of pufferfish found in Hong Kong waters, and although traditional fisheries resources have declined drastically in the past decades, T. alboplumbeus can still be easily caught along the seashore (Yu and Yu 2002, 2003). Yu (2003) reported that juveniles are found swimming and feeding in large numbers along the seashore of Hong Kong in March every year immediately following the spawning season from December to February (Yu 2003).

It is also common in the waters of Guangdong Province.

Takifugu alboplumbeus is uncommon in available museum collection records, and is only represented by six lots (FishNet2 Database searched November 2013).
range: Takifugu alboplumbeus is found along the coast of China, from Liaoning in the north to Guangxi (Gulf of Tonkin). This includes the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, East China Sea, and South China Sea (Nakabo 2002). It may occur in the Indian Ocean, however this remains to be confirmed (Yamanoue et al. 2009, Nakabo 2002). It is found at depths ranging from one to 50 metres.
useTrade:
Takifugu alboplumbeus is not considered to be a food fish in Hong Kong (Yu 2003). However, there has been expressed interest in utilizing this resource, and in rearing this species in floating fish cages (Yu 2003). Individuals may occasionally appear in markets. This species is marketed as "Komon-damashi" in Japan (Nakabo 2002).

Aquaculture
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Takifugu pufferfishes, principally represented by the tiger puffer, T. rubripes, are raised in floating net pens in Japan, Korea, and China (Belle and Nash 2009). The total wild catch of pufferfish species in Japan has been relatively stable, ranging from 7,800 to 11,000 tonnes from 1995 to 2002. The four most common species consumed in Japan are T. rubripes, T. snyderi, T. chinensis, and T. porphyreus. Aquaculture efforts focus on T. rubripes, which ranks fifth among marine aquacultured species (the top aquacultured species in Japan are as follows: Yellowtail (Seriola quinqueradiata), Red Sea Bream (Pagrus major), coho Salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) and Japanese flounder (Paralichthys olivaceus). Although highly valuable (the market price of T. rubripes is 1.5 times that of Japanese flounder, three times that of yellowtail or seabream), the value began to decrease rapidly from the late 1990s onwards due to importation of Tiger puffer from China. In Japan, the majority of fingerlings produced in commercial hatcheries are then raised in floating net cages for direct consumption. About 15 million fingerlings are produced by commercial hatcheries for aquaculture, 1.5 times higher than the amount produced for release for stock enhancement by semi-governmental hatcheries in 1999. One of the most serious problems in the net cage aquaculture of tiger puffer is high (over 50%) mortality from outbreaks of parasitic diseases (Ogawa and Inouye 1997).

Additionally, the toxic viscera of pufferfish (mainly ovaries and liver) produce tetrodotoxin, which is valued for its many pharmaceutical applications (Yu 2003).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Takifugu alboplumeus, however it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. alboplumbeus.

Fugu Fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further Research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Takifugu pseudommus is endemic to China, where it is found in the Yellow Sea and the northern East China Sea. It inhabits estuaries and is found over sandy or muddy habitats in shallow waters at depths ranging from one to 20 metres. There is some question as to the taxonomic validity of T. pseudommus, however differences in anal fin color between this species and T. rubripes make it unlikely that they are the same species. It is inferred that T. pseudommus is taken in fisheries targeting the commercially important T. rubripes and T. chinensis. Both T. chinensis and T. rubripes have undergone population declines due to overfishing, and it is inferred that due to its shallow depth range and resemblance to T. rubripes, T. pseudommus is also likely to have undergone population declines in parts of its range. The population of T. pseudommus is also likely to be impacted by coastal habitat degradation. There is little species-specific population information available for T. psuedommus. In the absence of reliable species-specific population information in the presence of likely threats, this species is assessed as Data Deficient. We recommend research on its taxonomy, monitoring of its habitat, population status and habitat status. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takifugu pseudommus is a temperate, demersal species which is morphologically similar to T. rubripes. Takifugu pseudommus has been known to hybridize under culture conditions and can produce morphological intermediaries which are difficult to distinguish from one another (Song et al. 2001). Wild hybrid populations have also been identified in Laizhou Bay, in the Bohai Sea (Xiaoqi 1999).

Adults form aggregations in shallow waters for feeding and spawning, and juveniles often enter estuarine and rivers. The species enters the Bohai Sea to spawn in spring. Juveniles grow in estuaries in the summer and enter the Yellow Sea to overwinter. The ovaries are highly toxic, the liver, skin, and intestine are slightly toxic, and the testes and flesh are innocuous (Nakabo 2002).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Takifugu pseudommus may be threatened by coastal habitat degradation and overfishing in parts of its range. The East China Sea and South China Sea have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004), and large areas, including the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished.

Takifugu pseudommus is morphologically similar to T. rubripes, a highly commercialized species which has undergone population declines due to overfishing in the region (Nagai 2003). It is inferred that T. pseudommus is taken in fisheries targeting the commercially valuable T. pseudommus, however population declines from harvesting cannot be quantified at this time.

In the lower Yangtze River basin it is also likely to be impacted by anthropogenic activities including dam construction and other hydrological alterations, land reclamation, exotic species introductions, eutrophication, rapid sedimentation, deforestation and land erosion (Fu et al. 2003). Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses in this area, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004).
population:
Takifugu pseudommus can be common in China (J. Liu pers. comm. 2011).

There is question as to the validity of T. pseudommus, and it may be the same species as T. rubripes (Song et al. 2001). Skull structure of the two species is identical, however, and therefore further taxonomic studies are required. Molecular analyses of the whole mitochondrial genome of the genus Takifugu revealed that the genetic differences between T. chinensis, T. pseudommus, T. basilevskiannus, and T. rubripes are not significantly different from the genetic differences between individuals within the species T. pseudommus, reinforcing the need for further taxonomic studies of the genus using molecular and morphological techniques (Yamanoue et al. 2009). Takifugu chinensis and T. pseudommus were previously proposed to belong to the same species as T. rubripes, based on analyses of nuclear and mitochondrial DNA (Song et al. 2001, Reza et al. 2008). Additionally, the analysis of 49,647 simple sequence repeats revealed that the genetic differentiation between wild T. rubripes and wild T. pseudommus was less than that between wild and cultured T. rubripes (Cui et al. 2005). Pending taxonomic revision, it is currently considered a valid species (Eschmeyer), and can be distinguished morphologically on the basis of the anal fin colour, which is distinct from T. chinensis (Matsuura pers. comm. 2011).

Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Takifugu pseudommus is uncommon in museum collections, where it is represented by at least eight lots (FishNet2 database searched July 2013).
range: In the Northwest Pacific, T. pseudommus is known from the northern East China Sea, the Yellow Sea, and the Bohai Sea, reaching into the lower reaches of Yangzi and Yellow River and lakes (Nakabo 2002, Su and Li 2002).
useTrade: Takifugu pseudommus is commercially targeted for the consumptive pufferfish trade and commands a high price, although it is less desirable than T. rubripes (Cui et al. 2005). In Japan, pufferfish are caught primarily using modified longlines which are attractive to novice fishermen due to their ease of use (Kawata 2012). Takifugu pseudommus is also cultured for the pufferfish trade. Among the pufferfishes cultured in China for export to Japan, T. rubripes and T. pseudommus are the two most important species (Song et al. 2001). This species is called "Namera-damashi" in Japan.
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. pseudommus, however, it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. pseudommus.

Fugu Fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing  areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further Research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2009), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Takifugu oblongus is widespread in the Indo-West Pacific, where it is common in topical waters and rare in the upper reaches of its distribution (i.e., Japan). It is a coastal and estuarine species which can be found at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 20 metres. It has been associated with mangrove areas, but is also found in cleared areas. It appears to be common in parts of its range, and is common in museum collections. There are no known species-specific threats, however the extent to which T. oblongus is impacted by environmental degradation resulting from large-scale anthropogenic activity within its range is largely unknown. It is unknown whether T. oblongus is targeted by the commercial pufferfish Fugu trade, or whether or not it is the subject of aquaculture. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. oblongus, however, its distribution overlaps with marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takifugu oblongus is a demersal, tropical species which lives in shallow coastal waters but enters brackish waters (Talwar and Jhingran 1991) and can be found in mangrove areas and cleared areas (Shinnaka et al. 2007). This species bio-accumulates tetrodotoxin, and its roe has been implicated in the poisoning deaths of humans (Mahmud et al. 1999), although the toxicity of the particular organs in unknown (Nakabo 2002). It also bio-accumulates saxitoxin, a paralytic shellfish toxin (Ngy et al. 2009). Polychaetes dominate the diet of this species. Takifugu oblongus was confidently placed as a sister species of the remaining species of Takifugu (Yamanoue 2009).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in T. oblongus. However, it is likely to be impacted by the following:

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). Although the species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. oblongus are unknown, it is likely that populations of this minor commercial species are impacted by this fishery.

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). As culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aqua-cultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991).
