The range of this species overlaps with several protected areas in the region (e.g. Lizhiping National Nature Reserve). It is listed as a class II protected species under China's wild animal protection law. Captive breeding is currently being undertaken in Germany and the Netherlands.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of wetlands elsewhere in its range is needed. Additionally, it is recommended that community education and outreach programs be created and implemented,

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population size and trends is recommended. Further research on harvest and use trends is also recommended. There is a potential need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of over-collection and habitat loss.

rationale: Takifugu obscurus is known from the Yellow Sea, East China Sea and South China Sea to the Korean Peninsula. It is found in rivers in China. It is found at depths ranging from one to at least 20 m. This is a euryhaline species which lives in the bottom layer of inshore and inland waters. Spawning occurs in estuaries, and this species is known to migrate into freshwater to spawn. It is a commercial species which is considered highly-valued, however there is little information available to characterize the fishery. This species has been bred in captivity, and it is unclear whether or not this effort has been for the purposes of stock enhancement. There is little species-specific population information available. This species' dependence on freshwater systems to spawn and its predictable, seasonal mass spawning migrations into freshwater systems render it particularly vulnerable to overfishing. Seasonal fishing prohibitions and the presence of both fresh and marine water preserves in parts of its range may offer this species some protection. Takifugu obscurus is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Takifugu obscurus is a demersal,  anadromous species which undergoes annual seasonal migrations into freshwater systems to spawn. In the Yangtze River basin, the spawning period for T. obscurus is from March until April. This species maintains a sex ratio of approximately 1: 1. This species reaches sexual maturity between 25 and 28 cm (SL). The ovaries and blood are extremely toxic, while the liver, skin, and intestine are highly toxic. The flesh and testes are innocuous (Nakabo 2002).

This species lives in the bottom layer of inshore and inland waters, and grows 20–40 cm in length. Most of the growth takes place in the sea but they spawn in brackish and fresh water. During the spawning season, which is from late spring to early summer, the sexually mature fish run into river estuaries and spawn in inland waters including rivers, lakes, and ponds. The fingerlings grow in the inland water and either return to the sea the next spring or they there for a few months before returning to the sea. In the sea they grow to sexually mature fish over several years, and then return to the inland water again to spawn (Kato et al. 2005).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in T. obscurus. However, it is likely to be impacted by the following:

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). Although the species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. obscurus are unknown, it is likely that populations of this minor commercial species are impacted by this fishery. 

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). As culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aqua-cultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefore likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea, all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population: There is little species-specific population information available for wild populations of T. obscurus.
range: In the Western Pacific, Takifugu obscurus is known from the Yellow Sea, East China Sea and South China Sea south to the Korean Peninsula. It is found in rivers in China (Nakabo 2002). It is found to depths of at least 20 m, and may be found deeper.
useTrade:
Takifugu obscurus is a popular food fish in China and fetches a premium price owing to its high quality meat (Yang and Chen 2008). This is a species of interest for intensive aquaculture in China (Zhou and Jia-Xin 2003).

Aquaculture
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Takifugu pufferfishes, principally represented by the tiger puffer, T. rubripes, are raised in floating net pens in Japan, Korea, and China (Belle and Nash 2009). The total wild catch of pufferfish species in Japan has been relatively stable, ranging from 7,800 to 11,000 tonnes from 1995 to 2002. The four most common species consumed in Japan areT. rubripes, T. snyderi, T. chinensis, and T. porphyreus. Aquaculture efforts focus on T. rubripes, which ranks fifth among marine aquacultured species (the top aquacultured species in Japan are: Yellowtail (Seriola quinqueradiata), Red Sea Bream (Pagrus major), coho Salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) and Japanese flounder (Paralichthys olivaceus). Although highly valuable (the market price of T. rubripes is 1.5 times that of Japanese flounder, three times that of yellowtail or seabream), the value began to decrease rapidly from the late 1990s onwards due to importation of Tiger puffer from China. In Japan, the majority of fingerlings produced in commercial hatcheries are then raised in floating net cages for direct consumption. About 15 million fingerlings are produced by commercial hatcheries for aquaculture, 1.5 times higher than the amount produced for release for stock enhancement by semi-governmental hatcheries in 1999. One of the most serious problems in the net cage aquaculture of tiger puffer is high (over 50%) mortality from outbreaks of parasitic diseases (Ogawa and Inouye 1997).

Tiger puffer (T. rubripes) was introduced to China from Japan (Lin and Huang 2007). To meet increasing demand for pufferfish, China began large-scale artificial breeding of pufferfish in the 1990s. An annual output of about 4,000 tonnes of T. rubripes, which was introduced from Japan to China (Lin and Huang 2007) is exported to Japan and South Korea. Additionally, an annual output of about 6,000 tonnes of T. obscurus was also produced for export in China. Pufferfishes are still landed in China, mostly in Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong and other places. Nationwide, the total output of pufferfish is now around 20,000 t per year (Ma et al. 2011)
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. obscurus, however, it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. obscurus. Additionally, T. obscurus has been bred in captivity to meet increasing demand and to enhance existing stocks.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations (UN) Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China Sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Takifugu obscurus can be found in both freshwater and marine protected areas. According to the protection regulations for wetlands in the Poyang Lake of Jiangxi Province (2004) and the implementation of Chinese Fishery Lawin Jiangxi Province (1987), fishing is is banned from March 20th to June 20th every year in Poyang Lake. This corresponds with the spawning migration of this species in China, although whether or not this species spawns in the lake is unknown. Fishing has also been banned for two months from June 1st to July 31st each year since 1987 along the Xiajiang reach, Xingan reach, Jishui reach and Jian reach of the Ganjiang River, where this species has been recorded. However, this does not correspond to the freshwater spawning migration of this species (Huang et al. 2010).

Further research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: The species is assessed as Least Concern as it is common and has a large distribution. Loss of seagrass beds is a significant concern, however the species is not entirely dependent on this habitat. Focused population surveys and seagrass habitat monitoring are needed to ensure the continued abundance of this species.
habitat:
Syngnathus schlegeli is common in estuaries and in association with Zostera seagrasses and other aquatic vegetation. Juveniles associate with drifting seaweed (Safran 1990, Safran and Omori 1990).

Ovoviviparous, the male carries the eggs in a brood pouch which is found under the tail (Breder and Rosen 1966). The breeding season occurs from March to November, although it can be shorter in some localities (Sogabe et al. 2012).
threats: Syngnathus schlegeli has no known direct threats, however habitat loss and degradation are occurring and may pose a substantial threat to the species' survival over the long term. Throughout most of the species range seagrass loss is occurring due to unsustainable fishing techniques (such as trawling and dynamite fishing), aquaculture operations (most notably shrimp), and extensive coastal sea filling (Zheng et al. 2013). Habitat monitoring is needed to determine the extent of seagrass loss, and how this loss impacts on populations of S. schlegeli.
population: No population estimates exist for S. schlegeli, however the species appears to be relatively common (Sogabe et al. 2012).
range: Syngnathus schlegeli is distributed along the eastern coast of China, starting in the Gulf of Tonkin in Vietnam, northward to Vladivostok, Russia and Japan. This includes the island of Taiwan, the Ryukyu Islands, the main islands of Japan, and the Korean Peninsula (Masuda  et al. 1984, Dawson 1985).
useTrade: <span class="sheader5">This species is used in traditional Chinese medicine (Tang 1987), however the level of offtake from wild populations is unknown.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Microphis insularis is a freshwater pipefish species that is endemic to the Andaman Islands. It has been assessed as Vulnerable due to its restricted extent of occurrence (less than 20,000 km²), the fact the species is found in less than ten locations, and the presence of ongoing threats to the species. These threats include a continuing decline in habitat quality due to increasing human population and riparian development.
habitat: Microphis insularis is a demersal and potamodromous species which inhabits rivers and streams (Dawson 1985). Little is known about feeding, but the species likely feeds on small crustaceans and/or fish larvae as other pipefishes do (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). It is an ovoviviparous fish, and males carry the eggs in a brood pouch under their tail prior to giving live birth (Breder and Rosen 1966, Dawson 1985). They grow to be about 16 cm in length, with males brooding around 10 cm (Dawson 1985).
threats: Microphis insularis is likely threatened by invasive species, flow alteration, and habitat degradation (Rajan and Sreeraj 2014). Increasing human settlement in the Andaman and Nicobar islands from the mainland, as well as refugees from Bangladesh and Sri Lanka, have lead to damaging activities such as exploitation and clearing of mangroves for agriculture and housing, illegal logging, and development of aquaculture. Development of tourism and recreational activities also exerts stress on the freshwater natural resources of these islands.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Microphis insularis. The species is noted as being 'very rare' (Palavai and Davidar 2009), and populations are inferred to be declining as a result of ongoing habitat degradation (see Threats section). Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Microphis insularis is endemic to streams and rivers in the Andaman Islands (Dawson 1984, 1985).
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in trade, but pipefishes in general are taken for the aquarium and traditional medicine trades (Vincent et al. 2011). This species may be involved but levels of offtake are unknown.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place. This species does not occur in any protected areas, and it is not mentioned in any international legislation and/or trade agreements.

rationale: Due to minimal available information, Syngnathus euchrous is assessed as Data Deficient. Further research is required in order to properly assess this species against the IUCN Red List criteria. Mangrove and macroalgal habitat have both declined in the region, and further research is needed in order to determine the relative importance of each habitat type to the various life history stages of S. euchrous. Dedicated population estimates and habitat monitoring are needed to accurately assess this species.
habitat:
Syngnathus euchrous is found in eelgrass beds, mangroves, drifting algae and off rocky shores (Fritzsche 1980, Eschmeyer 1983, Whitmore et al. 2005).

Within the range of S. euchrous, Zostera marina is the most abundant species of eelgrass (Green and Short 2003). Also within this range, the dominant species of algae are Macrocystis pyrifera (Giant Kelp) and Nereocystis luetkeana (Bull Kelp), neither of which has been assessed for the IUCN Red List. There are three species of mangroves within the range of S. euchrous, as recorded in Whitmore et al. (2005): Red Mangrove (Rhizophora mangle), Black Mangrove (Avicennia gerninans), and White Mangrove (Laguncularia racemosa). These species are all listed as Least Concern on the IUCN Red List (IUCN 2013).

Like other pipefishes, S. euchrous feeds on zooplankton such as small crustaceans. Males carry the brood pouch under their tail and give birth to live young (Foster and Vincent 2004).
threats:
The main threat to wild populations of Syngnathus euchrous is habitat loss and degradation from coastal development, sedimentation and pollution. Mangroves are in decline in the region and further losses are expected in the future (Whitmore et al. 2005).

Macroalgae has also declined in the region due to the historical depletion of Sea Otters (Enhydra lutra - assessed as EN by Doroff and Burdin 2013) through hunting. A lack of otters has set in motion a predatory release on sea urchins which allows uncontrolled grazing and subsequent loss of kelp forests. Other threats to the kelp forests include pollution (including thermal pollution and toxic chemicals), sedimentation and nutrient runoff (from sewage, development, agriculture, dredging and freshwater intrusion), introduced species (e.g. Sargassum muticum from Japan outcompetes the native kelp species), climate change (e.g., El Niño/La Niña events; increasing severity of storms), and incidental physical damage (i.e., propeller cuts from boats) (Steneck et al. 2002, Springer et al. 2007).

The species is not targeted in a fishery and trade appears minimal.
population:
The only recorded observation of Syngnathus euchrous, since its discovery by Fritzsche in 1980, is documented in a study of species biodiversity in northern Mexico in 2005 (Whitmore et al. 2005). The study lists S. euchrous as occurring in the area, but gives no indication of population abundance or frequency. Although not previously known to occur in mangrove ecosystems, that study reported S. euchrous in mangroves between Bahia Magdalena and Punta Abreojos, Baja California, Mexico.

The current population status of S. euchrous is unknown.
range: Syngnathus euchrous occurs in the Eastern Pacific ocean from Redondo Beach, southern California, USA (Fritzsche 1980) to Bahia Todos Santos, Baja California Sur, Mexico (Whitmore et al. 2005).
useTrade: Trade in pipefishes within the range of Syngnathus euchrous occurs at low levels. In Mexico, dried pipefish (from unknown species) were sold as curios in local markets and live for use in aquaria, but both at minimal quantities (Vincent et al. 2011). Because the species of pipefishes in this study were not identified, the proportion of this harvest that can be attributed to S. euchrous is not known. In either case, the overall amount of pipefishes traded in the area in general is low enough to infer a minimal impact on wild populations of S. euchrous.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions in place for this species. Its range overlaps with many protected areas. Habitat protection and monitoring are the most important measures to ensure the health of S. euchrous populations.

rationale: This species is restricted to the upper Gulf of California. It is a shallow water species that occurs in estuarine habitats that are increasingly disturbed by coastal development and aquaculture. However, very little is known about the population status of this species and the impact of current threats. It is therefore assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Syngnathus carinatus is found on sand substrata, estuaries, beaches, and soft substrata (L. Findley pers. comm. 2007). Little is known about its feeding, but it likely consumes prey similar to that of other pipefishes, including mysids, gammarid shrimps, and harpacticoid copepods (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). They are ovoviviparous, and males brood the embryos beneath their tail prior to giving live birth (Breder and Rosen 1966, Dawson 1985). This species is found at depths to 36 m.
threats: Coastal development such as marina construction and aquaculture development has caused much of the estuarine habitat of this species to be degraded (L. Findley pers. comm. 2007). In addition, the damming of the Colorado River and water divergence from other rivers has placed estuaries in the region at risk due to hypersaline conditions (Rowell et al. 2008, A. Cisneros-Montemayor pers. comm. 2016).
population: Syngnathus carinatus is not abundant. There have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates to date. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Syngnathus carinatus is endemic to the northern Gulf of California (Fritzsche 1980, Dawson 1985).
useTrade: This species has not been specifically identified in trade, but pipefishes in general are often targeted and/or caught as bycatch in shrimp trawls and traded for use in the aquarium trade, as curios, and for traditional medicines (Vincent et al. 2011). This species may be involved but levels of offtake are unknown.
conservationActions: This species occurs in at least one marine protected area with questionable enforcement (the Alto Golfo de California Biosphere Reserve; L. Findley pers. comm. 2007).

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable under criterion B1 on the basis of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 17,880 km<sup>2</sup> and six threat-based locations. A continuing decline is projected in the area, extent and quality of habitat due to expansion of aquaculture activities in lakes, pollution from aquaculture feeds, domestic and agricultural wastes, unregulated/illegal fishing activities, soil erosion and extensive run-off, sedimentation. Research gaps on population size and trends, life history and ecology need to be addressed.
habitat: This species is found in freshwater lakes and streams (Larson 2010). It feeds on shrimp larvae (Gindelberger 1981). Males guard its eggs during the three day hatching period and until after the yolk sac is exhausted (Gindelberger 1981).
threats: Threats include soil erosion and extensive run-off, sedimentation, unsustainable aquaculture operations, and pollution from domestic and agricultural wastes, and unregulated/illegal fishing activities (Guerrero 1999, Japan International Cooperation Agency 2000, Regis and Dela Cruz 2006, Cruz et al. 2015, Legaspi et al. 2015, River Basin Control Office 2020).
population: Data on the population size and trend throughout its geographic range are not available. This was the most common fish sold in markets in the 1980s (Gindelberger 1981).
range: This species is apparently known only from freshwater lakes (Lake Bato, Lake Buhi, Lake Bulusan, Manapao Lake) and streams in Camarines Sur, Albay and Sorsogon provinces of the Bicol region, southern Luzon, Philippines (Larson 2010, Herre 1953, Alcabedos et al. 2017). A single specimen from Mindanao, Philippines reported by Seale and Bean (1907) and the specimens from old harbour canal in Batavia, Jakarta, Indonesia reported by Koumans (1940) are thought to belong to another species (Larson 2010).
useTrade: Information on the use and trade of this species is not known.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures specific for this species. However, Lake Bulusan is within the Bulusan Volcano Natural Park, which has been declared as a protected area (Biodiversity Management Bureau 2016). Research on population status, life history and ecology is needed.

rationale:
The Estuary Stingray (Hemitrygon fluviorum) is endemic to northern and eastern Australia where it ranges from Darwin, Northern Territory to Wagonga Inlet, southern New South Wales. It is demersal in freshwater, mangrove-fringed rivers, estuaries, and shallow inshore waters at depths <40 m. It appears to be an ecological specialist with a very patchy occurrence and probably limited habitat.

This species is a very minor bycatch of prawn trawl fisheries on the Queensland east coast but is not at risk from trawl fisheries across northern Australia as they do not trawl in its shallow inshore habitats. It is both discarded from some commercial fisheries and killed when captured in others. The species is bycatch of recreational fisheries and mostly is destroyed when captured and is persecuted by oyster fishers.

It was reportedly once common in parts of New South Wales, but is now uncommon along the New South Wales coast. There is anecdotal evidence of a historic and more recent decline in abundance and area of occupancy due to nearshore development across ~25% of its range, i.e. across the southern portion of its range. Across the remainder of its range, it is either unfished or lightly fished, and habitat degradation is less of a threat. Taking a precautionary approach which considers the historic and more recent declines in abundance and area of occupancy in part of its range, and that is appears to be an ecological specialist with a very patchy occurrence, it is suspected that the Estuary Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (52 years) due to a decline levels of exploitation and habitat degradation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2cd).
habitat: The Estuary Stingray is demersal in shallow inshore waters, mangrove-fringed rivers, and estuaries at depths <40 m (Pogonsoki et al. 2002, Pierce et al. 2011, Last et al. 2016b, Grant et al. 2019). It is also known to ascend rivers to beyond the tidal limit (Whitley 1940). It appears to be an ecological specialist with a very patchy occurrence and probably limited habitat. It reaches a maximum size of 93 cm disc width (DW) and possibly up to 160 cm DW, males mature at 41 cm DW and females mature at 63 cm DW (Pierce and Bennett 2010b, Last et al. 2016b). Reproduction is viviparous with litter size unknown, an annual reproductive cycle and a size-at-birth of ~11 cm DW (Pierce and Bennett 2010b). Female age-at-maturity is 13.4 years and maximum age is 21 years, resulting in a generation length of 17.2 years (Pierce and Bennett 2010b).
threats:
The species is taken as a minor part of the bycatch in inshore commercial fisheries, including demersal prawn trawl fisheries in New South Wales and Queensland, and by commercial tunnel net in Queensland (Courtney et al. 2007, Jacobsen et al. 2018, P. Kyne unpubl. data 2015). The species has not been recorded in the elasmobranch bycatch of the Northern Prawn Fishery and the Torres Strait Prawn Fishery that operate across northern Australia (Stobutzki et al. 2000), likely because of its close inshore shallow water habitat that is not trawled by these two fisheries. It has been reported as a very minor component of all bycatch (<0.1%) in the Queensland East Coast Banana Prawn Trawl Fishery (Stobutzki et al. 2000). It is not utilized commercially with regulations preventing retention in Queensland, and it is discarded. At-vessel mortality (AVM) and post-release mortality for this species is unknown, although AVM it is suspected to be moderate; Stobutzki et al. (2002) found an at-vessel mortality of 53–59% for two species of stingrays captured in the Northern Prawn Fishery. In some inshore commercial fisheries, there is the practice of 'spiking' incidentally caught stingrays (using a metal bar or stick with a sharpened point attached to pierce the animal's chondrocranium and remove it from nets, sorting trays, etc.) that is source of mortality.

The species is a bycatch of inshore recreational line fishing as it readily takes cut fish baits and is thus prone to capture. Incidental capture by recreational fishers is likely a significant threat to the species as fishers often destroy any stingray catches (Pogonoski et al. 2002, P. Kyne unpubl. data 2015). The Estuary Stingray has been reported to feed voraciously on farmed oysters (Whitley 1940, Last and Stevens 2009), and is persecuted by commercial shellfish farmers in New South Wales and southern Queensland estuaries.

Habitat degradation and loss are also a threat to this species due to its occurrence in shallow inshore, riverine, and estuarine habitats. There has been significant habitat loss and alteration along parts of the Australian east coast as a result of the reclamation of large areas of shallow muddy tidal bays and mangroves for the development of urban areas, canal estates, marinas, and large-scale developments such as the Port of Brisbane and Brisbane Airport expansions. For example, over 20% of the original mangrove habitat of Moreton Bay in southern Queensland has been lost to such development since European settlement (Greenwood 1993).
population:
This species was once considered common, but there is anecdotal evidence of a decline in abundance and area of occupancy for this species in parts of New South Wales and southern Queensland (Pogonoski et al. 2002, Kyne et al. 2003). Historic accounts report that the Estuary Stingray was an extremely common species in the bays and estuaries of New South Wales and southern Queensland. It has not been reported from Port Jackson and Botany Bay, New South Wales, where it was once common, since the 1880s. In more recent years, i.e., since 2000, it has been reported on the central New South Wales coast (Pierce and Bennett 2010a). Records and occurrence appear to be very patchy, with most records from rivers, estuaries, bays and harbours (Pierce and Bennett 2010a). The species is still locally common in some southern Queensland estuaries and bays (i.e., Hervey Bay, parts of Moreton Bay) (Pierce et al. 2011). It also has been reported to persist in highly modified habitats for long periods of time (>100 years) (Pierce and Bennett 2010a). It is a very minor component of commercial prawn trawl fisheries in Queensland where an ecological risk assessment of the southern Queensland East Coast Otter Trawl Fishery assessed this species as at intermediate risk based on its level of resilience to fisheries and the fishing pressure on the species (Jacobsen et al. 2018). It is not at risk from prawn trawl fisheries across northern Australia as it is not encountered by those fisheries, likely as they do not trawl in shallow inshore habitats. However, there is no information on population trends across the northern part of its range.

Overall, historic and more recent anecdotal declines in abundance and area of occupancy have occurred in ~25% of its range (the southern part of its range) due to the combined threats of bycatch in commercial fisheries, destruction of incidental catches by recreational fishers and during some commercial fishing activities, persecution by shellfish farmers, and habitat degradation and loss due to nearshore coastal development. Across the rest of its range, bycatch mitigation measures have been in place since 2000, it is either unfished or lightly fished, and habitat degradation is less of a threat. Taking a precautionary approach and considering the historic and more recent declines in abundance and area of occupancy in the southern part of its range and that is appears to be an ecological specialist with a very patchy occurrence, it is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 20–29% over the past three generation lengths (52 years) due to levels of exploitation and a decline in area of occupancy due to habitat degradation.
range: The Estuary Stingray is endemic to northern and eastern Australia in the Western Central and Southwest Pacific where it ranges from Darwin, Northern Territory to Wagonga Inlet, southern New South Wales (Pierce and Bennet 2010a, Gladstone et al. 2012, Last et al. 2016b). It was previously considered to also occur across southern Papua New Guinea and Indonesian West Papua, however these records represent another species, the Merauke Stingay (Hemitrygon longicauda) (Last et al. 2016b).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation actions for the Estuary Stingray. Elasmobranchs cannot be retained in the Queensland prawn trawl fishery or the Northern Prawn Fishery and so incidental captures are discarded. The use of Turtle Excluder Devices (TEDs) is mandated in all Australian prawn trawl fisheries and has been shown to be an effective way to reduce the catches of large rays in prawn trawls (Campbell et al. 2020); large individual Estuary Stingrays may be excluded from capture. There is a possession limit of one shark or ray for recreational fishers in Queensland. The species likely occurs in a number of marine protected areas in New South Wales and Queensland waters, although zoning plans for these parks and reserves restrict fishing activities in only small areas and do not generally protect sufficient areas of the habitat of this species. The zoning plan for the Moreton Bay Marine Park, Queensland includes closed areas representing 16% of the area of the Park. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: This species is widespread and very common throughout the Indo-Pacific. There are no known major threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Pterois antennata is a reef-associated species found at depths of 2 to 50 meters, and even up to 76 meters (Poss 1999). This species is either solitary or is sometimes found in small groups, and can reach a maximum length of 15 centimeters SL (H. Motomura unpublished data). It is uncommon during the day due to the fact that they hide under rock and coral formations, and become active at night in order to hunt. This species feeds on shrimp and crabs (Poss 1999).
threats:
The level of exploitation in fisheries and the aquarium trade is not suspected to be a major threat at this time. Due to its affinity with coral reefs, we suspect that this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.  However, this species also occupies rocky reefs, and therefore significant global population declines are not suspected.

As of 2008, 15% of the world's coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being "Effectively Lost" (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008). Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).
population: This species is very common throughout its range (H. Motomura pers. comm. 2015). There are 290 museum records of this species that were collected from Oceania (Accessed through Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.net, 2015-01).
range: Pterois antennata is widely distributed throughout the Indo-West Pacific, from east Africa and South Africa to French Polynesia, north to southern Japan and south to Australia (Allen and Erdmann 2012), but is absent from Hawaii (Poss 1999). It is found at depths of 1 to 76 m (Poss 1999).
useTrade: This species is found in subsistence fisheries, but does not support large scale fisheries due to its small size and dangerous spines. It is also commonly found in the aquarium trade (Poss 1999).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Nerophis ophidion is listed as Least Concern as it is widespread, common throughout its range and the threats are not yet significant enough to cause rapid declines in the populations of the species. The species is dependent, although not exclusively, upon a seagrass habitat which is undergoing a continuing decline in the region. Although this seagrass decline in Europe was estimated to be 29% measured over 127 years from 1879 until 2006, the decline should be measured over the last 10 years to be considered as relevant for the Red List assessment. The species also resides in algal habitats. It is expected that further declines in the remaining seagrass habitats in Europe could result in the species becoming threatened and ongoing monitoring of populations and habitat trends is recommended.
habitat:
Nerophis ophidion inhabits marine neritic areas with seagrasses to depths of about 15 metres. It preys on crustacean zooplankton from seagrass canopy leaves, including ostracods, amphipods, gastropods and decapods, as well as benthic cnidairians and copepods (Franzoi et al. 2004, Gurkan et al. 2011). It has a generation length of one year.

A cryptic species, N. ophidion has a semi-prehensile tail that assists it in seagrass mimicry. The species is associated with the eelgrass Zostera marina and algae such as Fucus spp. and Laminaria spp. (Goncalves et al. 2011). One study also found that N. ophidion is associated specifically with the seagrass Cymodocea nodosa (Malavasi et al. 2007).

The species exhibits strong sexual dimorphism with the females being substantially larger than males (Malavasi et al. 2007). Males have been shown to limit the reproductive rate of females and, as a result, the behavioural sex roles are reversed in that females compete for male mates (Berglund and Rosenqvist 1993). Unlike many of the pipefishes, males brood their young externally without the presence of a brood pouch (McCoy et al. 2001) and instead have the eggs attached via mucous (Carcupino et al. 2002). An extended courtship ritual occurs prior to egg transfer (Vincent et al. 1995) and males have been documented carrying eggs from April to October (Riccato et al. 2003).
threats:
The threats to Nerophis ophidion include habitat loss and degradation. Seagrasses have declined substantially across Europe (Airoldi and Beck 2007) and increases in filamentous algae that often accompany coastal degradation from development and pollution are detrimental to the species (Sundin et al. 2011). The species is dependent, although not exclusively, upon a seagrass habitat which is undergoing a continuing decline in the region. Although this decline was estimated to be 29% measured over 127 years from 1879 until 2006, the decline should be measured over 10 years to be considered as relevant for the Red List assessment (Waycott et al. 2009). Close monitoring of seagrass habitat is needed to determine regional-scale declines over shorter time frames.

Nerophis ophidion is not an exploited species.
population: Although much is known about the reproductive biology of Nerophis ophidion, no studies have yet focused directly on population sizes in the wild. The species is common throughout its range, however abundance estimates are rare. Repecka et al. (2003) determined that the species was present in only three percent of beach seines between 1989 and 2001 on Lithuanian shores.
range: Nerophis ophidion is widespread from the Gulf of Bothnia in the Baltic Sea (Haahtela 1974) and the North Sea, the British Isles, along the Iberian Peninsula, and in the Mediterranean and Black Seas. It is not found outside of pan-Europe. It is found at depths down to 15 m.
useTrade: The species is not known to be traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: Further research should be conducted to determine the species' population size, trends and threats. Monitoring of the species' preferred seagrass habitat should be conducted to determine the extent of its decline. Its range overlaps with many protected areas, with varying levels of efficacy. The species is considered Least Concern in the Baltic Sea (HELCOM 2013).

rationale: Archamia buruensis has been assessed as Least Concern. This broadly distributed species is known to be common in areas of its range. It is able to occupy to a range of habitat types. There are no known direct threats acting on this species, although it is likely to be undergoing localised declines due to habitat degradation.
habitat:
Archamia buruensis occurs in brackish and marine waters on inner coral reefs and mangroves, to a depth of 6 m. It is found over both hard and soft substrates. Individuals exhibit distinct pairing during courtship and spawning, and males mouthbrood the fertilised eggs until hatching.

This species also occurs in the lower reaches of freshwater streams.
threats: This species is not known to be harvested for commercial trade, either as a food source or for aquariums. It is likely that in areas of this species' distribution it is undergoing localised declines due to habitat degradation. Mangrove forests have also undergone widespread decline due to deforestation for timber, shrimp aquaculture, and land reclamation. This not only removes available habitat space for species utilising mangroves, but causes siltation of neighbouring coral reefs and consequently the loss of this habitat. At present this species is not thought to be seriously impacted by these threats as these are localised and not known across the entire distribution range.
population: This species is common in some areas such as Madang, Papua New Guinea, and northern Palawan in the Phillipines, occuring in small groups (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2009).
range: Archamia buruensis is distributed from Indonesia to Fiji, and north to Taiwan. Listed localities are: South China Sea, Indonesia, Phillipines, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Santa Cruz Islands, Fiji (Gon and Randall 2003).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Archamia buruensis, however the distribution of this species may fall within a number of marine protected areas.

rationale: Cyprinodon dearborni is broadly distributed throughout coastal habitats in Venezuela and the islands of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao in the Netherland Antilles. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 163,122 km2. This species is dominant in coastal habitats throughout Caribbean drainages in Venezuela, and there is currently no indication of major population declines. Therefore, C. dearborni is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Cyprinodon dearborni occupies a range of coastal estuarine habitat, including lagoons, quiet backwaters, and mangrove pools (Pérez et al. 2012, Hylkema et al. 2015). This species is capable of temporary emersion, and can persist in thin films of water for several days when evaporative processes reduce available water in salt marshes and inland lagoons (Turko and Wright 2015). This species can withstand a broad range of salinities, and most often occurs in hypersaline lagoons (Feltkamp and Kristensen 1970). Diet is comprised of detritus, unicellular algae, small macroalgae, zooplankton (Artemia), small crustaceans and bryozoans (Feltkamp and Kristensen 1970, Carmona 1983, Cervigón 1991). Maximum reported body size is approximately 6.1 cm total length (TL) (Cervigón 1991).

Hypersaline estuaries are common on the northern coast of South America, due to their shallow depth (<1 m), rain regime with little rainfall and fresh water inputs, very high sunlight throughout the year, high water temperatures and consequently high evaporation. The salinity of these water bodies can vary between 36 ‰ to more than 60 ‰ in marginal areas of the lagoons, and between 80 ‰ and close to 140 ‰. In areas referred to as “Salinas”, depth can be just a few centimetres (Mago 1965, Kristensen 1970, Kristensen and Hulscher-Emeis 1972, Boer et al 1973, Cervigón and Gómez 1986, Cervigón 1991, Cervigón and Ramírez 2003, 2012).

Cyprinodon dearborni does not occur in freshwater rivers (lotic ecosystems) or freshwater inland lagoons (lentic ecosystems). In a number of studies, this species has been reported from lagoons that vary dramatically in salinity depending on the season. However, it is rarely found at salinities lower than 35 ‰ for any extended periods of time (Hulscher-Emeis 1972, Chung 1997, López et al. 1996, Marín 2000, Toledo et al. 2000, Torcatt 2015).

Females mature at an average size of 2.5 cm and an average age of 86 days (Carmona 1983, Cervigón 1991). Fecundity increases with size, ranging from 87 oocytes in females of 20 to 29 mm TL and 298 oocytes in females greater than 40 mm TL. Embryogenesis is temperature dependent and is completed in three days at 35 ° C and in six days at 26 ° C and is not affected up to a salinity of 51 ‰. There is diurnal territorial behaviour among males, for the defence of a mating and spawning area, as well as parental care by these of the fertilized eggs. The larvae are born with 3.42 and 3.96 mm TL and the yolk sac is reabsorbed five days after hatching and larval development is completed in 44 days at 12.5 mm TL.
threats:
In Venezuela, deforestation rates are exceeding 164,000 hectares annually, primarily resulting from agricultural expansion (Mazón et al. 2017). Coastal pollution including the discharge of heavy metals into coastal waterways is probably negatively impacting aquatic habitat in Laguna de Chacopata, Laguna de Los Patos, and in other regions characterized by urbanization and industrial processes (Toledo et al. 2000). In the Western region, north of Lake Maracaibo and the Gulf of Venezuela, as well as the coasts of the Falcón states, and the central eastern coasts of the Miranda, Anzoátegui, Sucre and Nueva Esparta states (Isla de  Margarita and Coche), oil spills, deforestation (slash and burn) of forests in the headwaters of the basins and mangrove forests, alteration of natural drainages (reservoirs, dredging and canals, dikes, channels, artificial lagoons), erosion and sedimentation, destructive floods, physical modification of Salinas associated with shrimp aquaculture and salt exploitation, contamination by domestic and industrial effluents, use of agrochemicals in upper and middle river basins, extraction of mineral material, and improper disposal of artificial solid waste (domestic and industrial waste) all continue to impact habitat quality (Rodríguez Altamiranda 1999, Conde and Carmona-Suarez 2003, Medina and Barboza 2006, Colonnello and Lasso-Alcalá 2011, Flores 2016, Suarez 2016, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2018).

The non-native Oreochromis mossambicus was introduced in 1964 in Laguna de los Patos (Sucre state) (Carvajal 1965) and its impact on native species has been well documented, displacing 80% of native species in a decade (Aguilera and Carvajal 1976). Likewise, this species has been recorded in some coastal lagoons on the Isla de Margarita (Lasso-Alcalá et al. 2008). Oreochromis nilotucus has been recorded in peripheral lagoon systems of Lago de Maracaibo, as well as in the Ciénagas de El Gran Eneal and Los Olivitos in the Gulf of Venezuela, though its impact on the native species has not yet been evaluated (González-Bencomo and Borjas 2003, Andrade et al. 2005, Lasso-Alcalá et al. 2008). Eleotris picta is an estuarine piscivore registered in a locality near the Morrocoy National Park and the “Cuare” Wildlife Refuge (Falcón state), where C. dearboni is present (Pezold and Cage 2002).

In the Netherland Antilles, naturally occurring freshwater habitat is vulnerable to human impact, including water extraction, impoundment, channelization, and contamination (Debrot 2003). There is anecdotal evidence suggesting that loss of connection with coastal habitat reduces the success of this species in inland waters due to alterations in food availability (Feltkamp and Kristensen 1970). The economies of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao are driven largely by tourism, and continued coastal development will likely impact the availability and quality of habitat (Nijman et al. 2009).

The Mozambique Tilapia (Oreochromis mossambicus) has established throughout coastal habitats on Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao, where it comprises a dominant portion of ichthyofaunal biomass and has apparently reduced the abundance of native species (Debrot 2003, Debrot et al. 2011, Buurt and Debrot 2012). Similarly, the Guppy (Poecilia reticulata) is established on all three islands, where it has been widely introduced as a biological control to mosquito larvae (Debrot 2003). There is a single collection of Xiphophorus helleri reported from Bonaire, but there is currently no evidence to suggest permanent establishment (Hulsman et al. 2008).

Despite inferred continuing decline in habitat quality, there is currently no indication that existing threats have resulted in major declines in population size or range extent.
population: The total population size of this species is unknown. However, it is reported as common to dominant throughout much of the western Caribbean province of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2007, 2011). Population trend is suspected to stable in the absence of major documented declines.
range:
Cyprinodon dearborni is broadly distributed throughout coastal habitats in Venezuela (Esmaeili et al. 2018), and the islands of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao in the Netherland Antilles (Hulsman et al. 2008, Smith et al. 2011). Its reported coastal distribution extends from the Guajira Peninsula in eastern Colombia eastward to Isla de Margarita, Venezuela (Haney et al. 2009). The type locality of this species is Willemstad, Curaçao (Esmaeili et al. 2018). Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 163,122 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records.

In Colombia, this species is reported by de Beaufort (1940) from a single collection locality on the Península de la Guajira (station 114; 11.710, -72.664).

In western Venezuela, this species occurs in coastal lagoons of Pájaro (Goajira Península), Laguna Borrachón, Salina Rica, Salina Santa Rosa, Laguna Las Peonías, adjacent to Lago de Maracaibo, (Zulia State), and Tucacas salt flats, near the current Morrocoy National Park (Falcón State) and different lagoons and Salinas adjacent to Puerto Cabello (Carabobo state) (Beaufort 1940, Schultz 1949, Andrade 1984, Moscó and Viloria 2000). In the Gulf of Venezuela, it has been recorded from Laguna de Carapátida, the hypersaline lagoons of Sauca and Punta Caimán (Golfete de Coro), the Paraguaná Peninsula, and in the lagoon system of the “Cuare” Wildlife Refuge in the State of Falcón (Schultz 1949, Valdéz and Aguilera 1987, López et al. 1996, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2015).

In the Netherlands Antilles, this species is known from Willemstad Bay, Curaçao, and from numerous coastal lagoons, salt flats and closed bays of Aruba, Curaçao (María Pompuna, Saint Joris Bay, Zaquito), Bonaire (Pos Francés and Pos Lansberg, Salinas Plenchi, Oranje Pan, Pekelmer, Goto, Slagbaai, Bartool, Cay) and Klein Bonaire (Salina klein Bonaire) (Meek 1909, Metzelaar 1919, Beaufort 1940, Hummelinck 1940, de Boer et al. 1973).

In the eastern region of the coasts and islands of Venezuela, this species has been collected from numerous hypersaline littoral lagoons on Isla de Margarita (Laguna de La Restinga, Punta de Mangle, Punta de Piedras Los Portillos, Boca de Palo) and Isla de Coche (salinas) (Cervigón 1966, 1991, Cardona 1983, Cervigón and Gómez 1986, Ramírez Villarroel 1994a, 1994b, Nirchio 1996, González and Nirchio 1997, Cervigón and Ramírez 2003, 2012,)  and in lagoons of the Archipiélago de Los Roques (Laguna del Gran Roque, Cayo Sal) (Martín Salazar 1956, Cervigón and Ramírez 2003, 2012). Likewise, it is widespread throughout coastal lagoons to the northwest of Barcelona (Anzoategui State) (Schultz 1949), Salinas to the West of Cumaná (Laguna de Los Patos: Sucre State), in areas near the sea of Laguna de Unare (Anzoategui State) (Mago 1965, Marín 2000), in Laguna de Los Patos (Chung 1997, Toledo et al. 2000, Alfonsi et al. 2003) and in the Laguna de Bocaripo (Chacopata and Pérez et al. 2012).

According to the databases of the national museums of Venezuela (Museo de Historia Natural La Salle: MHNLS, Museo Oceanológco Benigno Román: MOBR, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de Guanare: MCNG, Museo de Biología Universidad Central de Venezuela: MBUCV and Museo de la Estación Biológica de Rancho Grande: EBRG, Colección Regional de Peces, Universidad Centrocidental Lisandro Alvarado: CP-UCLA), this species has 70 records in coastal marine lagoons or coastal lagoons hypersaline in the Isla de Margarita, Coche, Archipiélago de Los Roques, and continental coasts of the Zulia, Falcón, Miranda, Anzoátegui and Sucre states.

The presence of Cypinodon dearborni in Trinidad and Guyana, as suggested by Wildekamp (1995) and Haney et al. (2009), is unlikely, given high rainfall in the region that is not conducive to the development of hypersaline estuaries where this species lives. Additionally, in the most recent and complete listings for that region (Ramjohn 1999, Lasso et al. 2009, 2010, Vari et al. 2009, Phillip et al. 2013, Lemopoulos and Covain 2018), Cyprinodon dearborni has not been recorded.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions:
In Venezuela, some 400 areas have been decreed under the Special Administration Regime Areas, among which 98 protected areas stand out, such as two biosphere reserves, 43 national parks and 36 natural monuments, seven refuges and a fauna sanctuary (Flores 2016). However, only 32 have management plans and use regulations, and none have defined management programs (Flores and Aponte 2016). Therefore, their effectiveness is highly speculative. Some have suggested the need for modification and expansion of existing protected area networks to improve their effectiveness for aquatic conservation (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011).

The range of this species extends into a number of these coastal protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020), including Médanos de Coro and Morrocoy National Parks (Falcón State), Archipiélago de Los Roques (Francisco de Miranda State), Laguna de Tacarigua (Miranda State), Laguna de La Restinga (Margarita Island, Nueva Esparta State), and Laguna Las Marites Natural Monuments (Margarita Island, Nueva Esparta State), Ciénaga de Los Olivitos (Zulia State), and Cuare (Falcón State) Wildlife Refuges, Hueque-Sauca, Tucurere (Falcón State) and Ciénaga de La Palmita and Isla de Pájaros (Zulia State) Wildlife Reserves, and Cabos, Puntas, Islands and Lagoons of Isla de Margarita (Nueva Esparta State) and Playa Norte (Falcón State) Protected Zones.

rationale: This species has a wide distribution, with no known major widespread threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Heterobranchus longifilis is a demersal, potamodromous species. It is uncommon and inhabits large rivers (Eccles 1992). This species is the largest freshwater species in southern Africa. It is found in quiet waters with deep pools and stretches, not necessarily associated with vegetation, in larger waterways and main river channels (Teugels et al. 1990). It is an onmivorous scavenger most active at night, feeding on any available food, including invertebrates and insects when small, fish and other small vertebrates when large. It scavenges off large carcasses and offal from riverside villages (Skelton 1993). It undergoes a spawning migration from the normal dry season habitat into the tributary rivers and floodplains during the rainy season (Teugels et al. 1990), with eggs and juveniles being found among plants roots in shallow water. It lives for 12 or more years. It is caught from deep water by trammel or sinking gill-nets and is a popular angling target in the Zambezi River.
threats: The species has declined through much of its range. The main threat is unregulated and expanding gill-net fisheries and angling. In eastern Africa populations are threatened by potential overfishing, and loss of wetland habitat. In northern Africa, general threats include dams, water pollution (agriculture, domestic and commercial/industrial), groundwater extraction and drought.
population: This species is uncommon, although the exact population size and trend are unknown.
range:
This is a very wide-ranging species with an almost Pan-African distribution.

Central Africa: It is known from throughout the Congo River basin. In Lower Guinea, it occurs in the Cross and Sanaga in Cameroon, and the Ogowe in Gabon.

Eastern Africa: This species is present in Lake Tanganyika, Malagarasi River, Lake Rukwa drainage, Rufiji and Wami (Eccles 1992), Lower Shire River, Lake Rukwa system, Lake Edward, Murchision Nile, and Lake Turkana. Currently there are no specimens of this species in scientific collections from Lake Turkana, but local fishermen have confirmed its presence in the northen part of the lake (Seegers et al. 2004).

Northern Africa: It is present but rare in Lower Egyptian Nile (Cairo). This species is known from the upper Egyptian Nile (Luxor and Aswan), as well as Lake Nasser (also known as Lake Nubia).

North-eastern Africa: This species is found in Ghazal and Jebel systems, White Nile, Nile and Lake Nasser, Sudan. It is also known from Baro and Omo Rivers, Ethiopia.

Southern Africa: It is known from middle and lower Zambezi and north into central Africa. There are also records of a Heterobranchus species from the Rovuma River.

Western Africa: This species is known from the Gambia, upper Senegal, Niger, Benue, Lake Chad, Volta and coastal basins from Guinea to Nigeria, including the delta of Niger and the Cross River.
useTrade: This species is harvested for human consumption and has recently been introduced into aquaculture. It is a popular angling target in the Zambezi River.
conservationActions: Research into its population, life history, harvest and potential impacts is recommended. Sustainable management of riverine fisheries will probably help this species, as well as a catch and release policy for tourist anglers.

rationale: This species has a wide distribution, with no known major widespread threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This species is demersal and potamodromous, and inhabits channels, lakes and irrigation canals. It prefers sandy bottoms but also found in rocky to muddy bottoms. Zones with vegetation in calm waters provide shelter to larvae and young. Adults inhabit deep water, while juveniles are found in shallow water (Froese and Pauly 2003). It is not present in the littoral rocky habitat (Witte and de Winter 1995). It is a voracious predator which predominantly feeds on Tilapia spp. and Alestes spp. (Reed et al. 1967) and shrimps, although the juveniles feed on larger crustaceans and insects and are planktivorous (Bailey 1994). It has a long spawning season from February to August. It reproduces around the year, with peaks in the rainy season. It probably spawns in shallow sheltered areas. Juveniles occur over wide depth range but the highest concentration of small juveniles are found in littoral and sub-littoral zones (Witte and de Winter 1995). There is sexual dimorphism with females larger than males.

This species was introduced to Lake Victoria mainly from Lake Albert. Nile Perch contributed to, through predation and competition for food, the decimation of the unique flock of endemic haplochromine cichlids in Lake Victoria.
threats: This is a highly commercial species, and is suffering from over-exploitation in much of its native range, and to a lesser extent, pollution. Increasingly eutrophic conditions are threatening native populations in Lake Albert. However, these are not considered to be major threats to the population overall.
population: For the majority of its range, there are no data on population trends. In Egypt, its catch was increased from 840 tonnes in 1995 to be 8,453 tonnes in 2004. This is may be due to increasing fishing effort and/or more advanced fishing gear technologies.
range:
Lates niloticus is widely distributed in the rivers and lakes of tropical Africa, occurring commonly in all major river basins including the Nile, Chad, Senegal, Volta and Congo.

Central Africa: In Lower Guinea it is known from the Sanaga and Cross and coastal rivers of Cameroon. It has been introduced, at unknown date, from Sudan to Congo where it is now reproducing and established.

Eastern Africa: This species is present in Lake Albert, the Albert and Murchison Niles and Lake Turkana. It is now fully established in Lakes Victoria, Kyoga and Nabugabo, and the Victoria Nile, through introductions. According to Hartley (1984) an unpublicised introduction of L. niloticus took place in Lake Naivasha in the early 1970s and since the early 1980s several perch have been caught. No information is available on its present status but it probably did not establish in the lake.

Northern Africa: This species is known from upper Egyptian Nile, as well as Lakes Wadi El-Rayan and Burollos, and Nozha Hydrodrome. It is present in the brackish waters of Lake Mariout, near Alexandria.

North-eastern Africa: It is found throughout the Nile drainage, Lakes Chamo and Abaya as well as Baro and Tekeze basins in Ethiopia. It is also Setit in Eritrea.

Western Africa: This species is found almost everywhere in western Africa. It is widely distributed in the Volta basin (Dankwa et al. 1999) and present in Black Volta, White Volta and the Oti (Dankwa 1984).
useTrade: This species is well marketable as a food fish. Its total production in the River Nile in 1996 was about 795 tons, contributing about 1.3% of the total Nile catch. Its production in Lake Nasser was 904 tons, and in Wadi El-Rayan was 44 tons in the same years (Bishai and Khalil 1997).
conservationActions: No conservation actions are known to be in place for this species. More research is needed into the population and range, biology and ecology, habitat status and threats, as well as monitoring and potential conservation measures. Policy-based actions at multiple levels are required, along with harvest management, to reduce the impact of overfishing.

rationale: Prochilodus mariae is usually abundant and widely dispersed in drainages of the Orinoco where it is reported in several protected areas. Therefore, it is evaluated as Least Concern. However, fisheries landings have decreased notably over time, as the fishing fleet has increased in boats, fishermen and equipment, and is expected to continue decreasing in the near future. Additionally, there are many environmental stressors (e.g. deforestation and sedimentation) with negative effects on river integrity and fish populations within its distribution. Monitoring is therefore recommended.
habitat:
Prochilodus mariae is freshwater, benthopelagic and potamodromous fish, and occupies (in different moments) all freshwater habitats in the mountains, foothills and plains. This species generally can be found in the flooded forests and lakes associated with the rivers of the Orinoco basin and within the main rivers during migration (Barbarino-Duque et al. 1998). In the ribazon, it occurs with several species, such as Brycon, Piaractus, Mylossoma, Leporinus, Oxydoras, Brachyplatystoma, Hemisorubin, and Pseudoplatystoma.

The species has two migrations per year; the first for reproduction when the rains increase water levels in April and May, and a second when the water descends in November and December and the fish move from the lagoons to the main rivers and canals to avoid the warming waters (Galvis et al. 2007, Zapata-Padilla and Usma-Oviedo 2013). In the rainy season the species reproduce and spends in the savannas flooded with lentic bodies (lagoons, "préstamos", "esteros" and "bajíos"). As the dry season begins, the vast majority of the population moves upstream (called ribazón in Venezuela and subienda in Colombia) to the Andean foothills and (in minor quantities) to the mountains in the Guiana Shield, where it remains until the rains return. It travels high into the mountains and surprisingly reaches small streams with hardly any water (Taphorn 1992). In these small rivers it remains until the rainy season increases the flow considerably, at which time it descends to the plains (usually in the midst of floods) and in the course of this it reproduces. It demonstrates long distance, longitudinal and local migration estimated at between 100 and 500 km distance in several tributaries of Orinoco, principally in Andean versants.  In the migrations events, Barbarino et al. (1998) estimated an density of 863,200 ind/ha in Apure river (lowlands) and 198,000 ind/ha for the Guanare river (upper llanos).

The species is a iliophagous and detritivorous fish. The diet includes protozoa and bacteria from sludge and detritus, epibenthic algae and plankton (Taphorn 1992). Immature individuals consume more algae and less mud (fine amorphous detritus) than adults; the latter eat diatoms and filamentous algae (Barbarino et al. 1998).

In the Meta river the maximum length of the species is 45 cm standard length (Ramírez-Gil et al. 2015), but it can reach around 500 mm SL and 3 kg. However the average is much lower, probably associated with fishing pressure. The species has larger sizes in flood areas and lagoons than in rivers. The females at age at 23 cm SL in Apure river (Barbarino et al. 1998), and they reach a fertility of 824,265 eggs in the lower Orinoco (Nova and Ramos 1982). In upper plains of Apure (caño Maraca) the species has a generation length of 24 months and fecundity of 28,950 eggs/female with mean length of 260 mm standard length (Winemiller and Taphorn 1989). It is estimated that the reproduction is massive and occurs in the channel of rivers and during flood events. The fertilized eggs are carried away by the current and are deposited in flooding plains where then the larvae hatch.
threats: Drainage basin degradation and land use change in the Orinoco basin are a result of massive deforestation (Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010), causing significant erosion in the upper basins and the fragmentation and loss of streams and rivers due to sedimentation (Dudgeon 2008). The loss of these piedmont rivers has an important effect on the life cycle of P. mariae (Lilyestrom and Taphorn 1978, Winemiller et al. 1996). Another threat in this area is tree clearance in riparian zones, often illegal, which changes light regimes and can increase mortality rates of fish larvae due to increased ultraviolet radiation. Nutrients formerly from wood and debris is also removed from the ecosystem. The loss of this wood debris may also impact rates of predation as schools of fish in open water seek out debris for shelter (Wright and Flecker 2004). In Venezuela, the several dams in Andean and coastal ranges impede upstream migration of Prochilodus mariae, alongside many species of pimelodid catfishes. However, the main current and future threat to the species is the commercial fishery, which occurs with greater intensity in the Apure river basin and in the lower and middle Orinoco. The reduction of Prochilodus mariae by fisheries could disrupt carbon flow in river and probably alter the ecosystem metabolism (Taylor et al. 2006), including the loss of its role as habitat modifiers and maintainers for other species.
population: This species is very abundant and temporarily can dominate in number and biomass in foothill rivers (e.g. Las Marías river in Apure drainage; Flecker 1996). Following data collection between 2004 and 2009, the species has exhibited overall declines in landing numbers and over-exploitation is cited as the key driver of these declines. However, it should also be considered that subpopulations vary extensively year to year as a result of environmental factors, such as high rain years. Simultaneously the average size of this species has also decreased over time suggesting unsustainable fishing methodologies (Lasso et al. 2011). Even though the fishing records are variable, the evidence and general trends indicate that the population of the species is declining and this has been true for decades (e.g. Barbarino-Duque et al. 1998, Novoa 2002).
range:
The type locality for Prochilodus mariae is Barrigón, Río Meta in Colombia (Eigenmann 1922). The species is endemic to the lagoons and rivers in Orinoco Basin in Colombia and Venezuela (Castro and Vari 2003). In Colombia, the species is registered in the rivers Guayabero, Guaviare (inírida), Duda, Guejar, Metica, Meta, Manacacías, Cusiana, Chitamena, Cravo Sur, Pauto and Arauca, among others. For Venezuela, the species occurs in the rivers Arauca, Capanaparo, Cinaruco, and Apure (Caparo, Uribante, Ticoporo, Santo Domingo, Guanare, Portuguesa, Morador, Cojedes, Apure polders, Caicara, Maporal and Guaritico creeks). In the Guiana Shield, there are records from the upper Orinoco (Inírida, Atabapo, Mavaca, Ventuari, Ocamo, Matacuni), upper Rio Negro (Casiquiare), Manapiare, Cuchivero, Caura (Nichare, Tawadu), lower Orinoco and Orinoco delta. Records from the Amazon River basin (Peru, Colombia) are considered misidentifications. The species is reported in 459 sites with an elevational distribution ranges from 8-1,083 m above sea level.

The geographic attributes for Prochilodus mariae in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: Prochilodus mariae is one of the most important species in the fisheries of the Orinoco basin, and it is also described as the most important commercial fish in the Apure drainage (Taphorn 1992), with Colombia landings exceeding 130 tons per year (although the species is less valuable then its relative Prochilodus magdalenae; Lasso et al. 2011). Novoa and Ramos (1982) reported that P. mariae accounts for large volumes of the total commercial fish landings in the medium and lower Orinoco ports, but it is in the Apure and Arauca basins where extraction is greatest. The species is extensively cultivated in fish farms in Colombia and in Venezuela. This species is one of the main food fish targeted by subsistence fishermen in Orinoco (McIntyre et al. 2007).
conservationActions: Currently, Colombia and Venezuela have a minimum size of 27 cm for Prochilodus mariae (Novoa 2002, Carolsfeld et al. 2004), but it is necessary to update this according to the variations in annual volumes in fisheries. It exists in various protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). In Colombia, it is recorded in PNN El Tuparro, Tinigua and Sierra de la Macarena, DMI Ariari-Guayabero, EFI Ramsar site, and Ramsar Río Bita (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2006, Mesa et al. 2017, Villa-Navarro et al. 2017, 2020, DoNascimiento et al. 2018). In Venezuela, it occurs in National Parks Santos Luzardo (Capanaparo-Cinaruco), Tapo Caparo, Aguaro-Guariquito, Tapo-Caparo, Yapacana, Caura and Tapirapecó, Wildlife Refuge Caño Guaritico, Esteros de Chiriguare, and Esteros de Camaguán (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2003, Taphorn et al. 2005). The impact of harvest of this species should be monitored over time and assessed to determine if fluctuations are the result of natural patterns or due to human interference. Where possible degraded habitats should be restored, and the drainage of seasonally flooded lands should be minimized in order to protect the important breeding grounds of this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable on the basis of its declining distribution range with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 6,339 km<sup>2</sup>, area of occupancy (AOO) of 640 km<sup>2</sup>, as well as a decline in its EOO, AOO, habitat and the number of its subpopulations, all of which are primarily due to a massive loss or degradation of peat swamp forests on a range-wide scale.
habitat: This species is a pelagic miniaturized minnow (with maximum standard length of adult recorded 11.6 mm and is one of the world's smallest vertebrates) that is narrowly adapted (stenotopic) to the highly acidic blackwater streams in peat swamp forest (Kottelat et al. 2006, Giam et al. 2012). Continuing decline of habitat is likely to occur as inferred based on the rates of ongoing deforestation and habitat degradation that already occurs throughout Sundaland (Giam et al. 2012, Miettinen et al. 2012).
threats: Blackwater habitats where the species of Paedocypris can be found are already heavily degraded or even entirely destroyed, thus local extirpation of many subpopulations has occurred and the available habitat is shrinking. The remaining peat swamp forests are under tremendous threat from anthropogenic activities - hence the major threat to the species on a range-wide scale - such as deforestation, conversion into plantations (primarily oil palm plantation) and farms (largely shrimp farms), water extraction and draining (Kottelat et al. 2006, Giam et al. 2012). The species is also likely to be threatened by over-fishing as it has been recorded as being sold in the aquarium trade. The type locality was visited in 2018 and found to have been converted to oil palm plantation (H.H. Tan pers. comm. 2019).
population: Population size is unknown. The trend is likely decreasing primarily due to a massive conversion of peat swamp forests in Southeast Asia, of which more than 60% had already been lost by 2010 (Miettinen et al. 2012). The degradation of peat swamp forests has resulted in a population that currently remains in patches, many of which are separated from each others by long distance. No information on population viability is available and so it is not possible to say whether the species is severely fragmented. Moreover, Giam et al. (2012) projected mean probabilities of global extinction for this species based on three scenarios of land-use change from 2010 to 2050. The percentage range used here is set based on the two scenarios with the least and moderate impacts to the species: the scenarios with the slowest deforestation rate and with business-as-usual scheme, giving around 0.25-27.11%.
range:
This miniaturized minnow is known from blackwater habitats of the peat swamp forests in Sarawak, Malaysian Borneo where it occurs north of Sibu (Kottelat et al. 2006, Giam et al. 2012). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 6,339 km2 (based on total area within a minimum convex polygon around sites where the species has been recorded and where the potential habitat suitable for the species may be located), but the area occupied within this EOO (area of occupancy; AOO) is estimated as 640 km2 (based on a 2x2 km2 grid overlay on the range map). It is estimated that the species has been experiencing continuing decline in AOO and EOO due to the fact that more than 60% of peat swamp forests in Southeast Asia were lost by 2010 (Miettinen et al. 2012). Across the species range, there are 6-10 patches of blackwater habitat, each of which appears to be affected relatively independently by the major threat to this species (habitat loss or degradation). Therefore, the population is likely to occur in 6-10 locations.

Populations of a Paedocypris species south of Sibu are similar morphologically to P. micromegethes but ongoing genetic analysis suggests they represent a different undescribed species (H.H. Tan pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: The species of Paedocypris have been recorded as being sold in the aquarium trade with a seemingly sporadic availability.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas. Conservation actions are necessary to protect remaining peat swamp forests and to restore degraded blackwater habitats. Further studies are required to determine the population size and species range.

rationale: Tondanichthys kottelati is endemic to Lake Tondano in North Sulawesi, Indonesia. The population size and trend is unknown for this species. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is only 50 km2. Pervasive threats include high levels of agricultural pollution, sedimentation, heavy metals and damming infrastructure on the main stream of the river, and they continue to result in habitat quality declines throughout the entirety of the lake. Therefore, this species is assessed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: This species occurs in the freshwater Lake Tondano. This lake is the largest in the North Sulawesi province and is 12 km long north to south and 3 km wide at the northern end, with an area of 4,638 ha (Sinolungan et al. 2008). Tondanichthys kottelati is only known from immature specimens so there is no information on its mode of reproduction, but it is assumed to be viviparous, giving birth to live young, as this is common in closely related species (Reznick et al. 2007).
threats: Lake Tondano has high levels of sedimentation, heavy metals and chemical pollution (Wantasen and Luntungan 2019), and erosion caused by extensive deforestation for agricultural expansion. There are also very high nutrient inputs from fertiliser run off in the surrounding agricultural land, sewage disposal from nearby human settlements, fish farming for species of carp and tilapia, and the farming of an estimated 42,000 Manila ducks along the shore (Sinolungan et al. 2008, Evers 2014).
