These rising catches are unsustainable and instead arise from shifts in fishing effort into deeper waters due to decreased catch closer to shore (Dharmadi unpubl. data 2020). Finally, research surveys from 1976 to 1997 shows more than a 90% decline in ray catch per unit effort throughout the Java Sea in 20 years (one generation length) (Blaber et al. 2009). With the increased catch through parts of Indonesia, there has also been increased effort and therefore, catch per unit effort (CPUE) is likely decreasing, suggesting an overall decrease in the population of chondrichthyans (White and Dharmadi 2007). Considering these catch trends, the suspected population reduction of Whitenose Whiprays in Indonesia is 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (75 years).

There are no species-specific ray landings in Thailand, however, data are available on combined ray landings from 1998 to 2018. Ray landings peaked in 2003 with over 18,000 t reported but rapidly decreased and have been under 4,000 t since 2011, a decrease of ~78% in 8 years (Krajangdara 2019) and 100% when scaled to three generation lengths (75 years). 

In Myanmar, there is limited species-specific landings data available, and the nation provided no data to FAO on landings between 1956 and 1972, making specific inference on the state of populations difficult. However, reconstructed marine fisheries landings data are available from 1950, including estimates of IUU fishing (Booth and Pauly 2011). In general fisheries catches (all species, not just rays) increased steadily from about 200,000 t in 1950 to about 700,000 t in the late 1990s. From the late 1990s a rapid increase in landings from offshore fishing saw an increase in annual landings to almost 1.5 million t. Estimates of shark and ray landings from 1950 to the late 1990s varied between 15,000 t to 35,000 t with no substantial trend. However, from the late 1990s landings increased to around 40,000 t per year. This increase in landings is assumed to reflect the increase in offshore fishing that occurred during this period. These are substantial catches (this level of catch places them in the top 20 shark fishing nations globally) for a nation with a relatively small EEZ. Despite the increase in shark and ray landings during the period since 1950 there are significant concerns about the status of many species. Trawl surveys in Myanmar undertaken by the Norwegian research vessel 'Dr Fridtjof Nansen' in 1978–80 and 2013 showed a 50% decline in catch rates of elasmobranchs between surveys (Krakstad et al. 2014), with a noted shift from larger long-lived species to smaller short-lived species. Declines in ray catch rates declined more than for sharks. Surveys of local markets from 2006 to 2010 (San San Khine 2010) demonstrated that landings are dominated by small short-lived species, which is typical of over-exploited elasmobranch communities (Lam and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2011). These same surveys also reported a 49% decline in the landings during this period, despite no reduction in fishing effort.

In Bangladesh, questionnaires of local fishers revealed a steep decline in rays in the past 10 years (A.B. Haque unpubl. data 2020). Fishers reported that when fishing for larger rays ten years ago, a 7-day trip would yield over 1000 individuals. Recent 7-day fishing trips now only yield 2–5 large ray individuals. This has led to fishers using other net types because of the large decline in ray catches (A.B. Haque unpubl. data 2020). Actual levels of exploitation are high across the range of this species and declines in whiprays or rays can be considered representative of population reduction of the Whitenose Whipray. Overall, it is suspected that the Whitenose Whipray has undergone a 50–79% population reduction over the last three generation lengths (75 years).
range: The Whitenose Whipray is found in the Eastern Indian and Western Central Pacific Oceans from Bangladesh to Java, Indonesia and to Viet Nam (Last et al. 2016, A.B. Haque unpubl. data 2020).
useTrade: The Whitenose Whipray is used for its meat and skin (A. Bin Ali and Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). The meat is consumed fresh or salted and dried. This species is also landed and sold in the markets in Singapore, which are landed from Indonesia and Malaysian waters (N. Clark-Shen pers. comm. 06/05/2020). Larger rays, like this species, are very desirable in Bangladesh for their meat and skin. Ray meat is consumed locally and exported. The skins from large rays are exported to Myanmar to be made into accessories (e.g. handbags). Smaller rays are retained for their meat but the skins are too small to be utilized. Small rays are often dried whole for local consumption and export. There has been some increase in the demand for ray meat in cosmopolitan areas and restaurants (A.B. Haque unpubl. data 2020).
conservationActions:
No specific measures are in place. In Viet Nam, there is a prohibition on destructive fishing practices, and some fisheries regulations, however, enforcement and compliance are limited (Teh et al. 2014). There are at least three Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) (Hon Mun, Cu Lao Cham, and Con Dao) with an aim to preserve 2% of the marine area (FAO 2020).

In Indonesia in 1980, trawls were banned, however, large numbers of mini or baby trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country (Chong et al. 1987). In 2015, an additional ban on seine nets (Cantrang) was to be fully implemented in February 2020 (Ambari, 2019). There are currently plans in place to lift both these bans in the near future, where the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (MMAF) plan will allow the operation of the fishing gear with restrictions on the area of fishing pressure (Dharmadi unpubl. data 2020). Throughout Indonesia there are 196 MPAs making up 239,428 km² that may provide some refuge to this species (CTI 2020). In Malaysia there are 51 MPAs making up 5,462 km² that may provide some refuge to this species (CTI 2020). Most MPAs in the region are not well enforced and unlikely to provide any tangible relief from fishing pressure.

In Thailand, all commercial fishing vessels greater than 10 gross t are prohibited to fish within three nautical miles from the shore (DoF 2015). There has been limited management of shark and rays in Myanmar. In 2001 the government banned the capture and sale of whale shark (Notification 2/2001), and in 2004 established two shark reserves in the Myeik Archipelago where targeting sharks is prohibited (Notification 2/2004) (Howard et al. 2015). Rays are protected from targeting by the shark reserves. In 2008 a nationwide ban on the targeting of sharks was announced. Despite the nationwide ban sharks and rays continue to be captured in large numbers, partly because there is little or no enforcement, and little knowledge of it in fishing communities (T. MacKeracher pers. comm. 2020).

To conserve the population and to permit recovery, a suite of measures will be required which may include species protection, spatial management, bycatch mitigation, and harvest and trade management measures (including international trade measures). Effective enforcement of measures will require ongoing training and capacity-building (including in the area of species identification). Catch monitoring is needed to help understand population trends and inform management.

rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern, as it is abundant in areas of suitable habitat and populations are believed to be stable. However, more research is needed to study how habitat loss is impacting known populations.
habitat: This species is found on bushes along the banks of tidal rivers in Myanmar, including mangroves in brackish water (Wogan et al. 2008), and is reported to dive into the water when threatened (Smith 1943). This snake is a mangrove specialist and, unusually for an arboreal snake, feeds only on fish. It can occur in somewhat degraded habitat, however as it requires a large enough area of mangrove habitat to support fish populations, it will not persist in sites where the mangrove zone is only a few trees thick (G. Wogan pers. comm. February 2012).
threats: This species may be threatened by loss of mangrove forest, as people within its range rely heavily on mangrove resources and this may be reducing suitable habitat for this snake. Mangroves are among the most threatened habitat types in Southeast Asia, and are at risk within this snake's range primarily from firewood collection, which may leave remaining mangrove stands too small to support populations of this snake (G. Wogan pers. comm. February 2012).
population: The species was reported to be abundant on bushes along the banks of tidal rivers in Myanmar (Smith 1943). More recent research confirms that the species is common where present (R. Lucas, unpubl. thesis, J. Slowinski pers. comm. to I. Das 2000), suggesting a population that is stable where suitable habitat is present. The snake's habitat requirements are however highly specific, making it potentially highly susceptible to the loss of its mangrove habitat.
range: This species has been recorded disjunctly in northeastern India (Darjeeling and Assam) and in Myanmar (Smith 1943, Wogan et al. 2008). It may also occur in Bangladesh. The snake's presence in India is doubtful, and recent surveys in the area have not recorded it (Chettri and Bhupathy 2007). The snake's occurrence in Myanmar's Rakhine state is uncertain as it is based from an old record and has not been confirmed in recent surveys (Theobald 1882, G. Wogan pers. comm. 2011).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: Taxonomic study is needed to determine if the Myanmar and Indian populations are conspecific. The disjunct distribution and different ecologies (lowland coastal mangroves in Myanmar, inland upland habitat in India) suggests that they are not conspecific. Wall (in Smith 1943) commented on this unusual distribution. The species has been recorded for some protected areas in Southern Myanmar.

rationale: Centropomus armatus is widespread throughout the Eastern Pacific from the mouth of the Gulf of California southward to central Ecuador. Range-wide population size and population trend are unknown, but localized studies report this species as abundant at many localities where it occurs. Potential regional or localized threats to this species include overfishing, coastal development and destruction of mangrove habitat resulting from shrimp aquaculture and extraction of mangrove forests for use as firewood and charcoal, and coastal pollution from agricultural runoff and industrial discharge. However, there is no indication of major declines in habitat quality or population status. As such, C. armatus is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This species is found in mangrove and estuarine areas over soft substrates, in both marine and brackish waters (Vega 2004, Murase et al. 2014). Temporal variations in abundance are influenced by the combined effects of tidal and diel variation, with the highest reported abundances from samples taken at night during neap tides (Castellanos-Gallindo and Krumme 2013, Pulmanns et al. 2018). C. armatus was most abundant in Chacahua Lagoon, Oaxaca, during periods characterized by low salinity (Mendoza et al. 2009). In the Gulf of Tehuantepec, it is reported from salinities between 20.7-33.4 ppt (Romero-Berny et al. 2018).

Diet is comprised primarily of crustaceans, fishes, and mollusks (Vergara-Chen et al. 2014, Pulmanns et al. 2018). Reproduction occurs throughout the year, with high peaks during the months of July and November (Vega 2004). Length at first maturity is approximately 22.3 cm TL and maximum size is 37 cm TL (Alvarez-Lajonchere and Tsuzuki 2008).

Average capture size in the Golfo de Montijo, Panamá was approximately 31 cm and the weight was approximately 352 g (Vega 2004).
threats:
On a range-wide scale, there are no known major pervasive threats to this species. Although not considered a major threat to populations at this time, this species is important in commercial fisheries (Vega 2004). Anecdotal reports from fishermen in the Gulf of Fonseca suggest harvest reductions resulting from fishing pressure in coastal populations of the close congener Centropomus robalito (Campbell 2015). However, the range-wide impacts of artisanal and small-scale commercial harvest on the total population size of C. armatus are largely unknown and require further study. Coastal pollution of heavy metals and metalloids (including cadmium and lead) from mining operations and nutrient and pesticide runoff from intensive agricultural and pond aquaculture, including associated harmful algal blooms (HABs) have been documented in the Gulf of California (Gil-Manrique et al. 2017, Paez-Osuna et al. 2017) and may present a potential threat to habitat quality in the northern range extent of this species. However, the impacts of environmental pollutants on C. armatus range-wide require further research.

Localized coastal development and associated destruction of mangrove forests has the potential to reduce suitable habitat. Intensive shrimp aquaculture in coastal areas (especially in Sinaloa) may lead to destruction of mangrove habitat, and increase nutrient loading in adjacent lagoons (Alonso-Perez et al. 2003, Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2005). In Guatemala, Honduras, and Panama, coastal mangrove forests are threatened by the expansion of aquaculture infrastructure, coastal development, and extractive exploitation for use in firewood and charcoal production (Recio et al. 2016).

These potential threats are ongoing and expected to continue, especially in Mexico and parts of Central America where fisheries and aquaculture practices may be unsustainable, or where coastal governance is lacking (Mondoux et al. 2008, Campbell 2015, Gonzalez-Bernat et al. 2017).
population:
On a range-wide scale, the total population size and population trend of this species are unknown.

However, C. armatus is abundant in many parts of its range. In the lower San Pedro Mezquital River, Nayarit, C. armatus is one of the most broadly distributed species (Gonzalez-Diaz et al. 2015). This species is common in mangroves in the Golfo de Nicoya (Rojas et al. 1994) and Golfo Dulce (Feutry et al. 2010), Costa Rica.  In Panama, it is the most frequently captured snook species in subsistence and commercial fisheries (Vergara-Chen 2014) and is one of the most abundant centropomids in the Gulf of Montijo, Panama (Vega 2004). It was the second most abundant species sampled in Malaga Bay, Columbia (Castellanos-Gallindo and Krumme 2013).

 This species is considered uncommon in Ecuador and is reported at densities of 0.26-1.47 ind/100m2 in Palmar (Shervette et al. 2007). This species has not been observed in the southern part of the Gulf of California, despite extensive collections.
range:
Centropomus armatus is endemic to the Eastern Pacific and ranges from Mazatlan, Sinaloa at the mouth of the Gulf of California southward to central Ecuador (Miller et al. 2005, Shervette et al. 2007, Mendoza et al. 2009, Gonzalez-Diaz et al. 2013, McMahan et al. 2013, Murase et al. 2014, Vergara-Chen 2014).

This species has also been reported inland from the lower San Pedro Mezquital River in Nayarit (Gonzalez-Diaz et al. 2015), the Costo-Istmo and Costo-Soconusco drainages in Chiapas (Velazquez-Velazquez et al. 2016), and in creeks upstream of Malaga Bay in Columbia (Castellanos and Krumme 2013).
useTrade:
This species is important in subsistence, artisanal, and small-scale commercial fisheries throughout much of its range (Fernandez et al. 2011, Lopez-Garro and Zanella 2015).

Centropomus armatus has been proposed as an aquaculture candidate (Alvarez-Lajonchere and Tsuzuki 2008). However, to date there are no established culture protocols in place.
conservationActions:
There are no known conservation measures for this species. However, the range of this species includes a number of Marine Protected Areas in the Eastern Pacific region (IUCN and UNEP 2018). If temporal fisheries restrictions are proposed, the months of October and November must be considered to protect spawning aggregations, as these are the periods with the most reproductive activity for this species (Vega 2004).

More research addressing potential threats and their effects on the populations status of C. armatus, population status, and harvest rates would be useful in guiding future conservation action.

rationale: Centropomus ensiferus is widely distributed in coastal waters from the Atlantic coast of southeastern Florida, in the Gulf of Mexico from Tuxpan, Mexico to Rio de Janiero, Brazil, and in the Caribbean from Cuba to the Virgin Islands. Total population size and population trend are unknown. However, this species appears uncommon to rare where it occurs. Potential threats include habitat loss as a result of mangrove destruction and coastal development, introduced species, and localized fishing pressure. However, the overall effect of these threats on the population status and habitat quality of this species are largely unknown. Given a broad distribution and no evidence of major range-wide population decline, C. ensiferus is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This benthopelagic, amphidromous species occurs in fresh to marine waters over shallow soft bottoms within subtropical climates (Gines and Cervigón 1967, Cervigón et al. 1991, Riede 2004). It inhabits estuaries and lower courses of coastal streams and canals throughout Florida and is most abundant around island areas (Robins et al. 1986). Juveniles can be found in mangrove areas and irrigation canals (Keith et al. 2000). Nothing is known regarding spawning activity and no apparent extensive migrations are known. It exhibits an ontogenetic shift from feeding primarily on shrimps and other crustaceans towards small fishes (Engraulidae, Clupeidae) (Keith et al. 2000, Winemiller et al. 2011, Moreno-Sanchez et al. 2015). Maximum reported size is 36.2 cm TL (IGFA 2001) and 1.025 kg (Cervigon 1992). This species is capable of persisting across a wide salinity gradient (Suarez-Bautista and Rodriguez-Forero 2015).
threats: The primarily threats to this species result from coastal development and anthropogenic inputs into coastal waters. However, the range-wide effect of these stressors have not been quantitatively evaluated. Localized coastal development and mangrove destruction has the potential to reduce suitable habitat. Intensive shrimp aquaculture in coastal areas may lead to destruction of mangrove habitat, and increase nutrient loading in adjacent lagoons (Alonso-Perez et al. 2003, Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2005). In Guatemala, Honduras, and Panama, coastal mangrove forests are threatened by the expansion of aquaculture infrastructure, coastal development, and exploitation for firewood and charcoal production (Recio et al. 2016). Localized river regulation, watershed development, contamination, and the impacts of introduced species have the potential to degrade habitat quality in Puerto Rico (Neal et al. 2009). Similarly, habitat quality in the Patuca River may be threatened by flow regulations (Esselman and Opperman 2010). The impacts of established invasive species are unknown, but may reduce suitable habitat and prey availability at certain localities such as Lake Gatun (Sharpe et al. 2017).
population:
The total population size and range-wide population trend of C. ensiferus are unknown.

Localized population trend in Puerto Rico is likely declining (Smith et al. 2008) as a result of river regulation, watershed development, contamination, and the impacts of introduced species (Neal et al. 2009).

This species is widely distributed, but relatively uncommon where it occurs (H. Espinosa Perez pers. comm. 2014). In Sebastian River, Florida, only one individual was captured from a total of 651 sampled fishes (Paperno et al. 2018). Similarly, this species was uncommon to rare during surveys in the Lesser Antilles (Vaslet et al. 2010) and Trinidad (Rostant et al. 2007). This species is still present in Lake Gatun at low abundances, despite potential competitive interactions with the established Cichla monoculus (Sharpe et al. 2017). Catch statistics for this species are often unavailable because they may also include Centropomus parallelus (FAO 2003). However, in the Rio Doce River, Espirito Santo State (Brazil), it represented only 1% of catches (Barroso et al. 2007).
range: Centropomus ensiferus is distributed in the western Atlantic from the northern Indian River Lagoon in southeastern Florida along the U.S., in the Gulf of Mexico from Tuxpan, Mexico along the northern Yucatan Peninsula to northwestern Cuba, in the Caribbean Sea from Cuba to the Virgin Islands (except the Cayman Islands), and along Central and South America from Mexico to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (Poey 1860, Fraser 1978, Menezes and Figueiredo 2003, Miller et al. 2005, Paperno et al. 2018). It has also been recorded from St. Lucia (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It is reported from the Chamelecon, Patuca, and Coco drainages in insular Honduras (Matamoros et al. 2009).
useTrade: This species is taken occasionally in artisanal and recreational fisheries (Perez-Alvarado et al. 2004). Centropomus ensiferus is an important part of subsistence fisheries in Honduras (Esselman and Opperman 2010) and a minor portion of subsistence fisheries in parts of Brazil (Santos et al. 2017) and Lake Izabal (Perez-Alvarado et al. 2004). It is among the top bycatch species captured by the shrimp fishery in Sánchez, Samaná Province, Dominican Republic (Herrera et al. 2011).
conservationActions:
There are no species specific conservation measures targeting C. ensiferus. However, the range of this species includes a number of protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019) that may offer indirect protection against habitat degradation and further coastal development.

More extensive sampling of distribution, population size, and population trend, in addition to research regarding the impacts of potential threats on the population status of this species would be useful in guiding future conservation action.

rationale: Centropomus viridis is widely distributed on the Pacific coast of North, Central, and South America from Baja California southward to Paitas, Peru, including the Galapagos Islands. Based on limited sampling, this species occurs at relatively low abundance in coastal estuaries and bays. Regional and localized threats to C. viridis include subsistence, artisanal, and small scale commercial harvest, environmental pollution, and coastal development. However, there is no indication of major range-wide population decline. As such, C. viridis is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is found in bays, estuaries, mangrove areas and in the lower reaches of freshwater streams. Its diet consists of mobile benthic crustaceans and bony fishes (Vega, 2004, Macal-Lopez et al. 2013). In Costa Rica, it has been reported as far as 80 km inland from the Rio Grande de Terraba (Lopez-vila 2013).
threats:
On a range-wide scale, there are no known major pervasive threats to this species. The regional impacts of artisanal and small-scale commercial harvest on the total population size of C. viridis are unknown. Coastal pollution of heavy metals and metalloids from mining operations and nutrient and pesticide runoff from intensive agricultural and pond aquaculture, including associated harmful algal blooms (HABs) have been documented in the Gulf of California (Paez-Osuna et al. 2017). In the Coatzacoalcos Estuary, individuals displayed elevated concentrations of mercury in their tissues, likely resulting from industrial effluents (Ruelas-Inzunza et al. 2009). However, the impacts of environmental pollutants on C. viridis range-wide require further research.

Localized coastal development and mangrove destruction has the potential to reduce suitable habitat. Intensive shrimp aquaculture in coastal areas (especially in Sinaloa) may lead to destruction of mangrove habitat, and increase nutrient loading in adjacent lagoons (Alonso-Perez et al. 2003, Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2005). In Guatemala, Honduras, and Panama, coastal mangrove forests are threatened by the expansion of aquaculture infrastructure, coastal development, and exploitation as firewood and charcoal (Recio et al. 2016).
population:
Total population size is unknown. On a range-wide scale, there is no evidence of major population decline. This species is represented by a large number of locations.

In the southwestern Gulf of California, this species is considered rare in Balandra and Enfermeria Bay, and relatively common in Zacatecas Bay (Lopez-Rasgado et al. 2012). Limited sampling in El Salvador reports this species at very low abundance (Fuentes et al. 2015). In Panama, it is reported from only two of nine sampling localities (Vega et al. 2006).
range: Centropomus viridis is widely distributed on the Pacific coast of North, Central, and South America. This species occurs from Baja California and Gulf of California southward to Paitas, Peru, including the Galapagos Islands (Miller et al. 2005, Llerena-Martillo et al. 2018). In Costa Rica, it has been reported as far as 80 km inland from the Rio Grande de Terraba (Lopez-vila 2013).
useTrade:
Centropomus viridis is targeted by subsistence, artisanal, and small-scale commercial fisheries throughout much of its native range (Fernandez et al. 2011, Fischer et al. 2015, Ibarra-Castro et al. 2017, Llerena-Martillo et al. 2018). However, quantitative data regarding the total harvest and stock health of this species are lacking.

Pilot-scale studies on the commercial-scale aquaculture of this species are currently underway (Ibarra-Castro et al. 2017). This species has been successfully raised ex-situ (Castro-Ibarra et al. 2017).
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation actions directed towards C. viridis. Successful commercial-scale aquaculture would likely reduce the fishing pressure on wild populations. Currently, ex-situ culture is still at the pilot scale (Ibarra-Castro et al. 2017). The range of this species includes several protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2018).

More information on the total population size, population trend, and magnitude of threats would be useful in identifying a more accurate conservation status.

rationale: Chelonodon laticeps is distributed in the western Indian Ocean, from South Africa north to Tanzania, east to Madagascar. It does not appear to be overly common. It is an inshore and estuarine species typically associated with mangroves and seagrass beds, and can be found at depths ranging from 1 to 10 metres. There have been no documented population declines in C. laticeps, however due to its affinity with mangroves and seagrass beds this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. laticeps, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Chelonodon laticeps is an inshore, demersal species which is most commonly found in mangrove areas and seagrass beds (Matsuura 2002), and is associated with weedy areas of quiet waters (Smith and Heemstra 1986). In South Africa, this species can be found in eelgrass (Zostera capensis) beds (Whitfield et al. 1989). It is predominantly found in open estuaries, which have large catchments and a perennial river flow with a permanent or near-permanent connection to the sea (Harrison and Whitfield 2006). This species is similar to C. patoca. This species reaches a maximum size of 20 cm. 

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in C. laticeps. However, because of its affinity with mangroves and seagrass beds, we infer that C. laticeps may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.

Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction. (Polidoro et al. 2010). In the Caribbean, approximately 24% of mangrove area has been lost over the past quarter-century (FAO 2007).

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).
population:
This species was not abundant in seine catches from the Thukela Estuary, which functions largely as a river mouth and is characterized by large seasonal freshwater discharges, in South Africa (Whitfield and Harrison 2003).

Specimens of C. laticeps are uncommon in museum collections, and is represented by six lots (FishNet2 searched 20 April 2012).

Due to its affinity with mangroves and seagrass beds, C. laticeps may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Chelonodon laticeps only occurs in the western Indian Ocean and is confined to the eastern coast of South Africa, Mozambique, Tanzania and Madagascar (Matsuura 2002, Gullström and Dahlberg 2004, Mwandya et al. 2009). It is found in shallow waters at depths of up to 10 m.
useTrade: This species does not appear to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. laticeps, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Colomesus psittacus is known from the Gulf of Paria to northern Brazil where it is common and locally abundant in mangrove creeks and estuaries at depths ranging from 0 to 32 metres. It appears to be common and abundant in parts of its range. Colomesus psittacus is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There have been no documented population declines in C. psittacus, however due to its affinity with mangroves this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. psittacus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Colomesus psittacus is a diurnal (Krumme 2004), demersal species which is solitary or in groups of two or three individuals, but never in schools (Keith et al. 2000). It is considered an estuarine resident (Barletta et al. 2005) which inhabits shallow inshore waters usually on soft bottoms and is frequently found in freshwater (Uyeno et al.1983). Colomesus spittacus is carnivorous, feeding mainly on molluscs which it crushes with its powerful teeth (Cervigón et al. 1992). In Brazilian mangrove creeks dominated by vast forests of Rhizophora mangle and Avicennia germinans, this species specializes on consuming Cirripedia (Balanus spp.) and Brachyuran crabs (Uca spp., Pachygrapsus gracili) (Krumme et al. 2007). When C. psittacus reaches maturity at a total length of 18 cm, the diet shifts from grazing on sessile Cirripedia to predation on mobile crabs (Giarrizzo et al. 2010). Colomesus psittacus is thought to have relatively continuous reproductive activity in Brazilian mangrove creeks (Giarrizzo and Krumme 2009). Different estuarine habitats are inhabited by different size classes of resident C. psittacus, and are likely connected by regular tidal migrations (Giarrizzo and Krumme 2009). The estimated consumption/biomass ratio of this species in a mangrove estuary in Northeastern Brazil was 8.8, which was relatively low - Q/B ratios varied from between 2.3 for Epinephelus itajara (Lichtenstein 1822) to 67.3 for Cetengraulis edentulus (Cuvier 1829).

The genus Colomesus is restricted to South America (Amaral et al. 2013).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003)
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in C. psittacus. However, because of its association with mangroves, we infer that C. psittacus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. It is taken as bycatch in the laulao catfish (Brachyplatystoma vaillantii) trawl fishery (Jimenez et al. 2013).

Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction. (Polidoro et al. 2010). In the Caribbean, approximately 24% of mangrove area has been lost over the past quarter-century (FAO 2007).

Colomesus psittacus is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there no indications at present time of declines from harvesting.
population:
Colomesus psittacus is a dominant component of northern mangrove estuaries, both numerically and by weight. In mangroves along the north Brazilian coast C. psittacus is one of the dominant fish species of tidal channels year-round (Krumme et al. 2007) accounting for between 19 and 52% of total catch mass (Giarrizzo and Krumme 2009). This species is the second most abundant estuarine species in tidal mangrove creeks of the lower Caeté Estuary, with population density and biomass fluctuating seasonally (Barletta et al. 2003) but with a continuous occurrence (Giarrizzo and Krumme 2009). In mangrove creeks in Northern Brazil, there were no major changes in the mean size of juvenile C. psittacus during the year. Congeners C. asellus and C. tocantinensis are found in freshwater (Amaral et al. 2013). This species exhibited a geographic consistence in abundance in northern Brazilian estuaries (between 7.7% and 11.4%)(Vilar et al. 2013).

Specimens of C. psittacus are very common in museum collections (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2014-03-17).

Due to its association with mangroves, C. psittacus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: In the Western Atlantic, the western extent of Colomesus psittacus is the Parque Nacional Natural Tayrona in Colombia, a region of narrow continental shelf which acts as a biogeographic barrier for many shorefishes (Betancur-R et al. 2010). Its range extends eastward the Gulf of Paria and Orinoco River region on the eastern coast of Venezuela to the Amazon River basin in northern Brazil. It is found as far south as Sergipe in Brazil (Amaral 2013). It is known from marine and freshwaters around Trinidad and Tobago (Tyler 1964, Philip et al. 2013). It is also found in Cuba (Amaral 2013). It can also be found in freshwater, and is known from several hundred kilometres upstream in the Amazon and its tributary river system. Colomesus psittacus is known from the Xingu tributary system of the Amazon River (Camargo et al. 2004).
useTrade: Colomesus psittacus is a component of the aquarium trade, and is exported from Brazil, Colombia, and Peru (Prang 2007). In Brazil, this species is of no commercial interest to fishermen and is rarely marketed due to its toxicity (Krumme et al. 2007). Under the name Baiacu, this species is valued for its medicinal properties. The bile and liver oil are used to treat breast cancer, backache, and warts (Alves and Rosa 2007). The Japanese name for this species is Kuro-obifugu.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Colomesus psittacus however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Contusus brevicaudus is endemic to Australia where it is found from southern Western Australia to New South Wales, including Tasmania, at depths ranging from 0 to 20 metres. Conutsus brevicaudus appears to be common and locally abundant. It is typically observed in estuaries, and is more likely to be found in embayments than upriver into estuarine systems. Contusus brevicaudus is associated with a variety of habitats, including mudflats, seagrass beds, and rocky reefs systems. There have been no confirmed population declines in C. brevicaudus and there are no major threats known. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. brevicaudus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Contusus brevicaudus is a demersal, nocturnal species which is usually observed in estuaries to depths of 20 metres (Kuiter 1993). It is a marine estuarine-opportunist and is more likely to be found in bays than upriver into estuarine systems (Potter et al. 2000). Contusus brevicaudus has been collected during nocturnal trawls over sandy substrates (Hyndes et al. 1999), although it is most frequently found over reefs or in seagrass habitats (Jenkins and Wheatley 1998). During a survey in southern Australia, this species was found over low-relief limestone reefs, and was absent from high-relief limestone reefs and granite reefs (Harman et al. 2003). During another survey, C. brevicaudus was found to be more common over mudflats than in mangrove systems in temperate Australian embayments (Hindell and Jenkins 2004). Contusus brevicaudus uses estuaries as nursery. Spawning is thought to occur in the late spring/early summer in the Leschenault Estuarine system, in southwestern Australia, with recruitment of this species into the large basin and Collie River regions of the Leschenault Estuary occurring in the autumn (Potter et al. 2000). Juveniles are often found in large numbers in estuaries (Hardy 1981).

Fishes of the genus Contusus are generally robust in body, and are known only from Australia and New Zealand (Hardy 1981).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in C. brevicaudus. Over half of Australia's 974 estuaries are in near pristine condition (Turner et al. 2004). However, although no measurable population declines have occurred for this species, it may be experiencing population declines due to its affinity for reefs, mangrove forests and sea grasses and the loss of some of these habitats.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson 2008)

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction. (Polidoro et al. 2010). In the Caribbean, approximately 24% of mangrove area has been lost over the past quarter-century (FAO 2007).

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).
population: Contusus brevicaudus is described as relatively common (Hardy 1981). In the the Leschenault Estuary, in southwestern Australia, this species was the fourth most abundant species and is described as moderately abundant (Potter et al. 2000). On the lower west coast of Australia, C. brevicaudus occurs in highest densities in the spring (Hyndes et al. 1999). This species contributes 11.4% to the total biomass of fishes recorded during a scientific study of the fish faunas in nearshore, shallow and offshore, deeper waters of the Leschenault Estuary between 1993 and 1994 (Platell and Hall 2006). Juvenile C. brevicaudus are abundant along northern Tasmanian beaches during the winter (G. Hardy pers comm. 2011). Specimens of C. brevicaudus are very common in museum collections. It is represented by 123 lots (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2013-04-15). Due to its affinity with mangrove forests, reefs and sea grasses, this species may be undergoing population decline, although no population declines have been observed as of yet.
range: Contusus brevicaudus has been recorded from the south-west of Western Australia between the Swan River mouth and Albany, from the southern and southeastern Australian coast between Eyre Peninsula, South Australia, and Jervis Bay, New South Wales, and from the northern and eastern coasts of Tasmania. It is taken at depths ranging from 0–20 metres.
useTrade: This species does not appear to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. brevicaudus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale:
Anguilla japonica is a facultatively catadromous (Tsukamoto and Arai 2001), semelparous (Tsukamoto et al. 2011) fish species with multiple life stages and is assumed to be panmictic (Ishikawa et al. 2001, Han et al. 2010, Minegishi et al. 2012). These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015).

Available data for glass, yellow and silver eels (see ‘Population’ section) indicate that this species has declined in abundance across its range by at least 50% over the last 24 years (ca. three generations). As such, A. japonica has been assessed as Endangered (EN) under A2bcd. In brackish water areas of Japan, where naturally-recruited wild eels are dominant, declining trends have been observed in yellow and silver eel CPUE data (Kaifu et al. 2018b, Kaifu and Yokouchi 2019). Regression analysis showed that silver eel catches in Okayama prefecture, Japan decreased 99.0% in 13 years (2002–2015), and long-line and set-net CPUEs of naturally-recruited wild yellow eel in the same prefecture also decreased 79.6% and 79.5%, respectively, in 13 years (2003–2016) (Kaifu et al. 2018b). For glass eels, catch data are potentially biased due to illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) exploitation (Kaifu 2019). Thus, landings data of glass eels cannot be accepted as a precise measure of population status (Kaifu 2019). However, due to the large scale of landings data, it can to some extent reflect true changes in fishing yields and is still helpful to understand stock status. Glass eel data gathered from nine prefectures in Japan indicated CPUE has declined by 47.2% over three generations.

Determining changes in abundance is particularly challenging due to a considerable lack of fisheries-independent monitoring data for eels in East Asia. For this assessment, fisheries standardised catch per unit effort (CPUE) was predominantly used and catch data from countries/regions across the distribution of A. japonica were also considered. The quality and quantity of data is disproportionate across the species’ range with the most extensive data sets coming from Japan. It is generally agreed that more fisheries-independent monitoring of eel populations is required throughout the range of the Japanese Eel. However, until such data become available, a precautionary assessment of trends in the fisheries time series data is necessary to highlight potential threats and apparent trends, as a guide for future research and conservation. Furthermore, as with some other anguillid species, the available data relating to A. japonica is predominantly from freshwater, where stocking can occur. In Japan, Japanese Eels are fished in both inland and coastal waters (Hakoyama et al. 2016), therefore coastal areas in Japan offer opportunities to investigate the population dynamics of naturally-recruited wild eels (Kaifu et al. 2018b). There is currently one stock assessment study of A. japonica (Tanaka et al. 2014), although within this, the effects of stocking in inland fisheries were not considered. Data on eel biological characteristics (survival rate, growth rate and sex ratio), essential for assessment of population dynamics, differ significantly between wild and cultured-and-stocked eels.

Across East Asia, A. japonica is an important fishery resource with a long tradition of use and has high economic and cultural value. As such, one proposed driver of declines is unsustainable exploitation for consumption and stocking culture facilities. Another factor that has been proposed as causing declines in the Japanese Eel is short term changes in oceanic conditions (e.g., El Niño, typhoons, mid-scale eddies, bifurcation, global warming) which influence larval survival or transport (Tzeng et al. 2012). These in turn are potentially exacerbated by multiple and more localised threats that include barriers to upstream and downstream migration (e.g. Tatsukawa 2003, Kume et al. 2019, Kume et al. 2020, Shuai et al. 2020), loss of habitat (Chen et al. 2014), pollution caused by industrial and agricultural runoff (Arai 2014), and modifications to coastal, riverine and other habitats (Yoshimura et al. 2005, Itakura et al. 2015a). Our understanding of the individual and cumulative impacts of all these threats is poor and mitigating them in isolation is unlikely to have a significant effect on the species’ status.

There has been progress towards implementing conservation and management interventions within the species range. The capture of silver eel was prohibited or restricted in ten prefectures in Japan, with the intention of preserving spawning eels in these areas. Co-operation between Japan, China and Taiwan, Province of China in relation to improving the status of the Japanese Eel started in 2012, aimed at establishing strengthened fisheries management as well as introducing traceability schemes. In September 2014, a ‘Joint Statement’ was adopted by mainland China, Taiwan, Province of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea, for the conservation and management of the Japanese Eel, through a restriction on the amount of wild-caught glass eels that can be used in aquaculture production (Anonymous 2014). 

Assessment of the species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th of November 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as a leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

The species is catadromous, spending its lifetime in freshwater, estuaries and coastal environments, including rivers, streams, lakes and wetlands, but it migrates thousands of kilometres to spawn. While anguillids are often referred to as ‘freshwater eels’, it is known that they can exhibit inter-habitat migration and movements. The proportion of yellow eels that remain in saline waters, rarely, if ever, entering fresh water, is particularly poorly understood which makes management challenging.

Little is known about the marine component of anguillid life histories in general, but Anguilla japonica stands alone in having a relatively well-studied spawning ecology (Kimura and Tsukamoto 2006, Tsukamoto 2009, Chow et al. 2009, Kurogi et al. 2011, Tsukamoto et al. 2011, Aoyama et al. 2014). The Japanese Eel’s spawning area has been identified as the region along the western side of the seamount chain of the Mariana Ridge (Tsukamoto 1992, 2006, 2009, Tsukamoto et al. 2003). Recent studies, based on data from pop-up archival tags, indicate that A. japonica exhibits diel vertical migrations as it swims to the spawning site that occurs in response to light intensity and water temperature (Manabe et al. 2011, Chen et al. 2018, Higuchi et al. 2018). The speed of migration was found to be between 18.4–40.6 km/d (Chen et al. 2018). The average migration speed in this study was faster than in previous studies – between 2.2 and 15.1 km/d was estimated by Manabe et al. (2011) – possibly due to environmental factors affecting the route (Chen et al. 2018). Eggs and spawning adults have been discovered in the west of Mariana Ridge (Chow et al. 2009, Kurogi et al. 2011, Tsukamoto et al. 2011). The depths where adults and newly hatched larvae were captured indicate that spawning occurs from 150–200 m (Tsukamoto et al. 2011).

Leptocephali develop in the pelagic ocean environment and over the course of five to six months they drift towards their estuarine recruitment areas in oceanic currents (Kuroki et al. 2009, Shinoda et al. 2011). Fukuda et al. (2018) collected metamorphosing leptocephali from the mesoscale eddy region to the East of Taiwan and found the onset of metamorphosis into glass eels occurs when leptocephali reach 67.8 ± 2.7 mm, at an age of 137 ± 15 days. This study also highlighted that A. japonica may recruit through the mesoscale eddies in addition to direct transfer from the North Equatorial Current to the Kuroshio. Models using virtual larvae have also suggested an importance of mesoscale eddies in A. japonica larval migration (Chang et al. 2017). Pigmentation stages of A. japonica glass eels are described by Fukuda et al. (2013). Age upon arrival to estuaries is estimated between 154 and 182 days while age at metamorphosis from larvae to glass eels is between 115–137 days (Cheng and Tzeng 1996). Therefore, time from metamorphosis to estuarine arrival is thought to be between 32 and 45 days (Cheng and Tzeng 1996). A full description of the timing of glass eel recruitment to different geographic regions is given in the ‘Geographic Range’ section. Glass eels utilise flood tidal streams selectively at night to migrate inshore in coastal areas (Fukuda et al. 2016). The subsequent timing of upstream migration of glass eels depends on the water temperature, tidal current and moon phase (Tzeng 1985).

After reaching coastal waters, a proportion of the population then moves upstream to feed and grow. However, some A. japonica, referred to as marine residents or ‘sea eels’, never enter freshwater, and remain in estuaries or nearby marine habitats (Tsukamoto et al. 1998). Analysis of the strontium:calcium ratios within the otoliths of maturing eels reveals a signature of the transition between these environments and it has been estimated that substantial proportions (56–86%) of the eels in some areas might be estuarine/marine residents (Tsukamoto and Arai 2001, Tzeng et al. 2002, Arai et al. 2003, 2008, Kotake et al. 2003, 2005, Tsukamoto et al. 2009, Mochioka et al. 2012, Yokouchi et al. 2012). This suggests that there is flexibility in the continental migration of A. japonica, and an ability to adapt to various habitats and salinities. When newly recruiting juveniles grow to yellow eel stage in saline waters, they are likely to become estuarine/marine residents due to a developmental shift in salinity preference (Fukuda et al. 2019).

During their growth phase, A. japonica feed mostly on invertebrates such as benthic crustaceans and insect larvae, and also on small fishes (Kaifu et al. 2013). Itakura et al. (2015b) found differences in feeding habits of eels in rivers with natural shore areas when compared to revetment areas. Overall, in natural shore areas there was a greater prey diversity consumed. Terrestrial oligochaetes were observed only in the diet of eels from areas with natural shores, whereas bivalves were consumed more in areas where there was revetment. The maximum size this species attains is approximately 100 cm TL and 1.5 kg in weight (Kotake et al. 2007). In a survey of yellow stage A. japonica in nine prefectures in Japan, growth rate (mm/year) was 96.7 ± 38.6 for females (n = 3643), and 120.5 ± 65.4 for males (n = 907) (Yokouchi et al. 2014).

Yellow stage A. japonica have been found to exhibit dormancy in freshwater during winter, with little activity occurring at temperatures below 13°C (Itakura et al. 2017). Eels tracked over the period of a year displayed small ranges and a homing ability that allowed them to return to their original habitat from as far as 1 km away (Itakura et al. 2017). Onset of spawning migration in silver eels has been linked to lunar periodicity, and silver eel activity has been found to be highest during the new moon period (Sudo et al. 2014). Experimental results indicate that silver A. japonica may use geomagnetic cues for orientation back to their natal water for spawning (Nishi et al. 2018).

As with many eel species, the generation times for A. japonica are highly variable depending on sex, individual variation and locality/latitude. For example, Kotake et al. (2007) studied A. japonica from three different latitudes and found that the age of silver males ranged from 4 to 10 years and silver females from 3 to 17 years. Other studies on the average age of silver-phase Japanese Eels, provide estimates of 6.9 and 7.8 years (Kotake et al. 2005), 8.3 and 9.9 years (Yokouchi et al. 2009), and 4.4 and 5.5 years (Xie et al. 2010) for male and female eels, respectively. The mean age of female and male silver eels was estimated at 7.7 and 6.6 years, respectively, based on Kotake et al. (2005), Yokouchi et al. (2009) and Xie et al. (2010), considering sample size of each study. The total average for both male and female silver eels from these studies, considering sample size, was 7.4 years. This gives an estimated generation length of 8.4 years, inclusive of one year for migration – for the purpose of consistency with other assessments, this was rounded to eight years.

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla japonica, as with all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation (Drouineau et al. 2018). The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight, that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel abundance. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of pressures, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to threats in both freshwater and marine environments.

Unsustainable fishing of A. japonica glass eels to stock farming facilities on a national/international scale may constitute a major threat to the population. Farms meet over 90% of global demand for eel products and all seed for farms come from the wild stock (Shiraishi and Crook 2015). Declines in A. japonica have driven culture facilities to source glass eels of other species from elsewhere in Asia (e.g. A. bicolor and A. marmorata), Europe (A. anguilla) and the Americas (A. rostrata) (Han et al. 2002, Gollock et al. 2018). However, the threat from unsustainable fishing persists, as A. japonica remains the preferred species in East Asia, and the species of choice for consumption in Japan (Shiraishi and Crook 2015). High demand for A. japonica glass eels has resulted in dramatic increases in price in recent years (Fisheries Agency of Japan 2019a). In addition, ongoing illegal fishing and trade, mainly in glass eels, makes it difficult to evaluate the true impact of exploitation on the species (Gollock et al. 2018).

Restocking occurs in Japan (Lin et al. 2010), and recent research is beginning to highlight the scale of stocking in certain localities, through quantifying the proportion of stocked eels in inland waters (Ministry of Environment 2016, Itakura et al. 2018, Kaifu et al. 2018b, Kaifu 2019). During the 1960s, dispersal of A. anguilla imported to Japan for farming occurred, either through escape from culture ponds, or by mixing with A. japonica released for stocking. A genetic study by Arai et al. (2017) found A. anguilla was dominant in the uppermost sample site of the Tone river system. Interspecific competition of this species with A. japonica may pose a threat, due to similarities in functional morphology and similar niche preference. This threat will diminish as the number of European Eels in Japanese waters has substantially decreased over time (Okamura et al. 2008) and the species is very unlikely to successfully escape and spawn outside of its natural range. The exotic A. rostrata has also been found in Taiwan, after being imported at the glass eel stage for farming, and subsequently escaping from aquaculture ponds (Han et al. 2002, Tzeng et al. 2009). This could present a risk of interspecific hybridisation, although successful spawning is unlikely due to species specific migration routes (Han et al. 2002, Tzeng et al. 2009).

Environmental fluctuations, such as changes in ocean circulation, and El Niño, have been proposed to influence larval transport and survival, and as a consequence, the recruitment of glass eels to coastal and freshwater habitats (Kimura et al. 2001, Bonhommeau et al. 2008, Miller et al. 2009, Tzeng et al. 2012, Chang et al. 2016, Lin et al. 2017a, Chang et al. 2018, Hsiung et al. 2018, Hsiung and Kimura 2019). However, there remains considerable uncertainty, surrounding the role of changing oceanographic conditions on all anguillid eel population dynamics and further research is required in order to understand the influence of both natural climatic fluctuations and anthropogenic effects.

Anguilla japonica is the native host of the nematode (Anguillicola crassus) that parasitises the swim bladder and has been proposed to affect survivorship and migration behaviour of non-native species. Japanese Eels, however, appear to show more evidence of acquired immunity and significantly reduced pathological effects than the European Eel (Knopf 2006) possibly because of longer historical exposure to this parasite (Münderle et al. 2006).

As with other anguillid eels, the upstream and downstream migration of the Japanese Eel has been impacted due to the presence of barriers in waterways. In Japan, construction of dams has reduced eel catches in some areas (Tatsukawa 2003). On 135 sampling sites in five rivers in Japan, individual density of Japanese Eel was negatively correlated with cumulative height of dams and weirs located in the lower reach of each sampling site (Ministry of the Environment 2016). Other studies investigated young yellow eels in a small river and reported density is negatively correlated with the number of weirs (Kume et al. 2019, 2020). Shuai et al. (2020) reported that dams could have blocked eel’s migration routes and affected their spatial dispersal.

Other threats include the loss of river habitat due to agricultural, urban and industrial development. Chen et al. (2014) used Landsat imagery to determine the amount of Japanese Eel habitat loss caused by human activity in 16 rivers across East-Asia (Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, China). The study revealed a reduction in effective habitat area of 76.8% from the 1970s to 2010s, with the highest reductions in China (81.5%) and Taiwan (49.3%). In Japan, part of the reduction in river habitat has included the extensive revetment of the shorelines of rivers and lakes for flood control purposes (Yoshimura et al. 2005, Itakura et al. 2015a). In a study comparing areas of natural shoreline to those with revetment, there was found to be lower abundance, poorer body condition, emptier stomachs, and reduced prey diversity within stomach contents, in eels sampled in areas of revetment (Itakura et al. 2015b). 

Development has also increased industrial effluent, and agricultural and urban runoff, all of which are known to negatively impact eel numbers through displacement, reduced reproductive success and direct mortality, particularly during the spawning migration (Tzeng et al. 2006, Drouineau et al. 2018). One example is organochlorines, primarily used in pesticides, which have shown to be persistent in aquatic environments even after their ban (Arai 2014). These chemicals are lipid soluble, and therefore accumulation was greater in silver stage A. japonica and eels that had resided for longer in freshwater (Arai 2014). In Lake Shinji, high concentrations of neonicotinoid insecticide effluent from rice paddies has been indirectly linked to the decline in average fishing yields of eel between 1981–1992 and 1993–2004, after its introduction in 1993 (Yamamuro et al. 2019). This may have been caused by a reduction in aquatic invertebrates, a prey source for A. japonica (Yamamuro et al. 2019). 

Predation of A. japonica naturally occurs in both continental and oceanic life stages. Miyake et al. (2018) studied the influence of predation on glass eel recruitment in the Tone River Estuary, through genetic identification of stomach contents. Glass eels were found in the stomachs of the channel catfish (Ictalurus punctatus) – an invasive species in the river system – and blackfin sea bass (Lateolabrax latus) confirming these species are predators of A. japonica. The level of influence of these predators on A. japonica is unknown, although blackfin sea bass occurs commonly in areas where glass eels recruit, and channel catfish may be a new predator, in rivers where its distribution has expanded.

Disease may constitute another threat for A. japonica. Japanese Eel endothelial cells-infecting virus (JEECV) causes viral endothelial cell necrosis (VECNE), which has an experimental mortality of ~60% (Okazaki et al. 2016). Since the 1980s, this has caused economic loss within eel farms (Okazaki et al. 2016). Infection of wild caught A. japonica at both yellow eel (Okazaki et al. 2015) and elver (Okazaki et al. 2016) development stages has now been reported.
population:
Most population genetic studies have previously indicated that Anguilla japonica consists of one genetically homogenous, panmictic population (Ishikawa et al. 2001, Han et al. 2010, Minegishi et al. 2012, Gong et al. 2014). Recent research (Igarashi et al. 2018), however, found genetic differences among eels captured in different rivers in Japan, providing some evidence to the contrary. However, Gong et al. (2019) did not find any genetic population differentiation between eels from China and Japan, suggesting the weight of evidence still supports panmixia at present.

Several studies using microsatellite analysis have suggested that Japanese Eel elvers show little genetic variation between years. A genetic study carried out by Tseng et al. (2003), for example, suggests that the effective population size (EPS) of the Japanese Eel is declining and the authors speculate that historically this has been due to large scale oceanographic changes. While EPS does not offer a true measure of the number of mature, reproductive individuals in the population, a reduction in this value suggests an overall loss of adaptive genetic variation.

Catch effort can be variable in fishing data, and under-reporting and, in some cases, an absence of reporting of landings, is a serious problem across the range of A. japonica. Thus, landings data of glass eels cannot be accepted as a precise measure of population status (Kaifu 2019). However, due to the large scale of landings data, it can to some extent reflect true changes in fishing yields and is still helpful to understand stock status.

To date, there is only one published stock assessment study of A. japonica. This study, by Tanaka et al. (2014), estimated stock size through ‘exploitable’ (yellow and silver) eel CPUE for Japanese inland waters, glass eel CPUE in Japan, and an age- and sex-structured model. Results from this study estimated that stock size of individuals aged ≥1 year had recovered since 1990 from less than 10,000 tonnes (t), to 18,700 t in 2010, equating to 24% of the carrying capacity. A study by Kaifu (2019) discussed some of the challenges facing a stock assessment of A. japonica. Illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) glass eel catches occur in Japan, making it difficult to assess the stock using this life stage, as the catch cannot be translated directly into recruitment (Kaifu 2019). For example, glass eel catch during the 2014 fishing season (1 November 2013 to 31 October 2014) totalled 17.4 t in Japan, but the total reported catch was only 8.0 t, 46.0% of the actual (Kaifu 2019). Other challenges arise when using catch statistics for yellow and silver eels. Particularly in inland waters where fisheries occur in Japan, stocking is known to take place, which biases eel abundance and their natural biological parameters. Using recently developed methods based on otolith stable isotope ratios (Kaifu et al. 2018a), research is beginning to highlight the scale of the presence of stocked eels in inland waters, and the necessity for their consideration within stock assessments (Ministry of Environment 2016, Kaifu et al. 2018b, Itakura et al. 2018, Kaifu 2019).

Glass Eels:

The data sets used in the analysis were as follows: Ministry of Agriculture, Forest and Fisheries (MAFF) compiled glass eel data (Japan), CPUE (catch/fisherman) data sets collected from nine Japanese prefectures; Chiba, Aichi, Tokushima, Oita, Kagoshima, Shizuoka, Mie, Kochi, and Miyazaki. Glass eel catch in these prefectures accounted 70.5% of the entire reported glass eel catch in Japan in 2018 fishing season (November 2017 to October 2018).

According to MAFF statistics, inland and coastal area glass eel catch reported in Japan in 1995 and 2019 – three generation lengths difference - was 20.0 t and 3.7 t, respectively, with large fluctuations between years. Indeed, at the time of writing, the catch in 2020 was higher than in 2019. However, fisheries catch does not necessarily reflect the abundance of the population because of potential fluctuation of fisheries effort.

Glass eel CPUE (glass eel catch per fisherman) in nine different Japanese prefectures (data from Tanaka (2014) updated based on communications with the nine prefectures) in 1994 and 2018 was 0.4483 and 0.2365, respectively. CPUE has decreased by 47.2% over 24 years (three generations). Based on GLM analysis, the glass eel CPUE in the nine prefectures has significantly decreased for both periods of 1977–2018 and 2003–2018 (Kaifu and Yokouchi 2019).

The estimate of exploitation rate of glass eel (or elver) in an estuary in northern Taiwan indicated that this life stage was heavily fished, which will influence the population size of yellow/silver eels in the river (Tzeng 1984, Lin et al. 2015, 2017b, Lin and Tzeng 2018).

Yellow/Silver Eels:

The most recent FAO statistics (in 2017) suggest that landings are as low as 119 t although there is no indication of effort from these data (FAO 2019). In 2013 the Japanese Eel was assessed as 'Endangered' on the Japanese Red List (published by the Ministry of Environment, based on the catch data of inland eels compiled by the MAFF). This report indicated a 72–92% decline in the species over three generations (12–45 years). Total annual yellow and silver eel catch across the 47 prefectures significantly decreased from 1,413 t to 71 t during 1987–2017, a reduction of 95.0% over three generations (Anon. 1958–2018). A recent study using otolith Strontium isotope ratios (87Sr/86Sr) reported that the otolith ratios of spawning adult Japanese Eels captured at the spawning area were most similar to the ratios of Japanese water, rather than that of Korea, mainland China and Taiwan waters (Otake et al. 2019). This indicates population dynamics of yellow and silver eels in Japan might be an appropriate indicator of the whole population dynamics of A. japonica. Although the MAFF data suggest widespread declines across the 47 prefectures of Japan (Anon. 1958–2018), the data only consider eels in inland waters, i.e. rivers/lakes, and it is estimated that  56–86% of Japanese Eels remain in estuarine/saline waters throughout their lives (Tsukamoto and Arai 2001, Tzeng et al. 2002, Arai et al. 2003, Kotake et al. 2003, 2005, Tsukamoto et al. 2009, Mochioka et al. 2012, Yokouchi et al. 2012). It has been suggested that a latitudinal cline exists, in the degree to which Japanese Eels utilise either freshwater or saline environments in Japan and Taiwan (Tsukamoto et al. 2009). In southern regions, a higher proportion of eels enter freshwater habitats, whereas in northern regions more eels remain in saline habitats (Tsukamoto et al. 2009). This behaviour appears to coincide with productivity, and therefore food abundance, which is greater in marine environments in the north, and similarly in freshwater environments in the south (Tsukamoto and Arai 2001, Tsukamoto et al. 2009).

It is suggested that eel stocking in Japan has biased assessments of the population dynamics of this species (Kaifu 2019). Otolith stable isotopes have been recently used to determine the proportion of stocked eels in some locations in Japan. In Okayama prefecture, 98.1% of sampled eels in three rivers where stocking had occurred were identified as stocked individuals (Kaifu et al. 2018b). In the Tone River watershed, wild eel proportions differed with site, and dominance of stocked eels was highest closest to release sites, suggesting reduced dispersal of these individuals (Itakura et al. 2018). A study by the Ministry of Environment of Japan found 62% of eels (n = 92) captured from 10 water systems in Japan to be stocked after application of a discrimination model (Ministry of Environment 2016, in: Kaifu 2019). Stocking affects population dynamics by introducing additional individuals into wild eel populations. Moreover, in an age-based cohort model, stocking-related ageing error strongly affected estimates of total biomass (Kullmann et al. 2018). Data on eel biological characteristics, such as survival rate, growth rate and sex ratio, are essential for assessments of their population dynamics (e.g. Tanaka 2014); however, these characteristics can differ significantly between naturally recruited wild and cultured-and-stocked eels (Kaifu et al. 2018b, Kaifu 2019). Therefore, yellow and silver eel population dynamics should be investigated where the possible bias of eel stocking is expected to be relatively low to minimise error.

Japanese Eels are fished in both inland and coastal waters in Japan, while eel stocking has been conducted only in inland waters. The standardised yellow and silver eel CPUE was significantly decreased in four of the six fisheries cooperative associations in coastal and estuarine areas of Japan (Kaifu and Yokouchi 2019). Significant relationships between CPUE and year were not found for the other two associations. Catches between 2003 and 2016 in coastal waters of Okayama Prefecture, where naturally-recruited wild eels are dominant, peaked in November and December (Kaifu et al. 2018b). This is when Japanese Eels start their spawning migration, although monthly catch and peak values were found to decrease over time, and longline and setnet CPUE decreased between 2003 and 2016 by 79.6%, and 79.5% respectively (Kaifu et al. 2018b). In addition, a survey of 1,509 fisheries cooperative associations in Japanese coastal waters where stocking of eels has not taken place reported that 93.4% of the 227 fisheries cooperative associations that confirmed they catch eels stated that they believe the Japanese Eel stock to be declining or relatively declining (Kaifu and Yokouchi 2019).

Han and Tzeng (2006) report an 81–88% female bias in sex ratio of yellow and silver eels caught at one locality, the Kaoping River, in south-western Taiwan. Furthermore, in the lower reaches of this river, density was revealed to be 0.01 eels/m² in 2001 and 2002 and the estimated abundance of eels in Kaoping River ranged from 7,137 to 31,360 individuals in 2001, and from 3,324 to 22,040 individuals in 2002 (Han and Tzeng 2006). Studies have found males to dominate at higher densities and so the low density and female bias in this River supports this theory (Han and Tzeng 2006).

When considering all the available data on its multiple life-history stages, A. japonica is estimated to have suffered at least a 50% population decline over a period of three generations (24 years; see ‘Habitat and Ecology’).
range:
It is known that Anguilla japonica occurs as a native species in Japan, China, Taiwan, Province of China (hereafter referred to as Taiwan) and Republic of Korea (hereafter referred to as South Korea). The range of this species extends from the Pacific coast of Japan and south to Hainan Island covering large areas of mainland China, Taiwan and South Korea. There are some records of recruitment along the coasts of the Sea of Japan, Yellow Sea and in low abundance in Northern Luzon Island, Philippines, the Chao Phraya basin in Thailand and Cambodia. It is thought that these vagrant individuals might not contribute greatly to the population as they are outside the influence of currents that are essential to the successful completion of the life cycle.

Eggs and preleptocephali for this species have been collected in the North Equatorial Current (NEC) along the western side of the West Mariana Ridge (14–17oN, 142–143oE) to the west of the Mariana Islands and were captured during new moon periods (Tsukamoto 2006, 2009, Tsukamoto et al. 2011, Aoyama et al. 2014). Timings of egg and preleptocephali catch also overlapped with catch of breeding-condition adult eels from the same area, confirming this area, west of the Mariana Islands, as the spawning location for this species (Chow et al. 2009, Kurogi et al. 2011, Tsukamoto et al. 2011). The possible spawning depth of adult eels has been suggested to lie in a vertically narrow depth stratum of 150–200 m, just below the upper limit of the thermocline sitting at 150 m (Tsukamoto et al. 2011). The NEC and Kuroshio Current are the predominant transport mechanisms for this species (Tzeng et al. 2012) but the latitude of spawning events, varies between years depending upon oceanic conditions (Kimura and Tsukamoto 2006, Miller et al. 2009, Aoyama et al. 2014). Spawning is thought to occur between April and August (Shinoda et al. 2011). The early, vagrant recruitment of Japanese glass eels occurs around the north-eastern coast of Luzon Island in the Philippines in late October and then in greater abundance in Taiwan in early November, with the main fishing season there being between November and February (Han 2011). After two to four weeks, recruitment occurs in the Fujian Province of China and the Pacific coast of southern Japan, where the main fishing season is between December and February (Han 2011). In the Zhejiang and Guangdong Provinces of China, Jeju Island, and Pacific coast of central Japan, the main fishing season occurs between January and March (Han 2011). From February to April, recruitment is concentrated in the southern Jiangsu Province of China (around Yangtze River estuary), the southern coast of South Korea, and east coast of Japan (Han 2011). In the northern Jiangsu Province of China and the west coast of South Korea, the main fishing seasons are between March and May (Han 2011). The final recruits occur on the north-western coast of South Korea and the Yalu River estuary in northern China between April and June (Cheng and Tzeng 1996, Han 2011, Han et al. 2019). However, recruitment peaks have been observed in June in 2010 and 2011 in the Pacific coast of central Japan (Aoyama et al. 2012). The results indicate that variations in the recruitment season may occur.  

The natural range of A. japonica within countries such as Japan is difficult to determine because of widespread restocking activities. Recently, coastal regions of Kyushu, Seto Inland Sea, and in Honshu, the Pacific side south of Aomori Prefecture, and the Sea of Japan side south of Kyoto Prefecture, were identified as the main areas of distribution for naturally recruited yellow-phase A. japonica in Japan (Yoneta et al. 2019).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from glass to silver, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan, South Korea and China. A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

Together with A. anguilla (the European Eel), A. japonica has one of the longest histories of fishing, stocking and farming for consumption purposes of all the Anguilla species.
