Low methyl mercury concentrations in sampled fish tissues suggest that the majority of discharged mercury is in inorganic form (Marshall et al. 2020). Domestic wastewater discharge and solid waste are additional contaminants in this watershed (Puño 2014). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the Tumbes basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013). Gambusia affinis is naturalized in the Tumbes River (MacDonald Lopez 1995), but its impact on native ichthyofauna has not been studied in detail.

Agricultural production and land cover change (e.g., slash and burn agriculture) is ongoing in the middle and lower reaches of the Catamayo River drainage (Ochoa et al. 2016). However, the Catamayo River drainage maintains relatively good hydrological connectivity, and land-use throughout the basin does not appear to significantly impact runoff (González González et al. 2016). One of the main threats in the Catamayo river basin is agricultural irrigation, which has contributed to increases in total and faecal coliforms, soil erosion and destruction of vegetation cover (Gonzales and Chamba 2007).

Despite uncertainties regarding the direct impact, scope, and magnitude of existing threats in the Puyango-Tumbes River drainage, continuing declines in habitat quality are inferred.
population: The total population size of this species is unknown. However, it is anecdotally characterized as rare throughout its known range (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015) and appears infrequently in ichthyological collections (P. Arguello and R. Barriga pers. comm. 2021). In the Tumbes River, ichthyological sampling yielded 68 individuals, comprising 6.93% of relative fish abundance (Valenzuela Reyna 2014). In the Viche River, similarly low abundances are reported (Angulo Collahuazo 2020). Population trend is suspected to be in decline based on continuing declines in habitat quality and availability.
range:
Paracetopsis atahualpa is distributed along the Pacific slope of southern Ecuador and northern Peru, from the Catamayo River drainage southward to the Tumbes River drainage (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). The type locality of this species is the Tumbes River at Cabo Inga (Vari et al. 2005).

There is only one known georeferenced locality for this species, which would give a minimum extent of occurrence of 4 km2; but it is known to be more widespread than this despite the lack of further georeferenced records. However, the extent of occurrence is unlikely to exceed 9,038 km2, which is the combined surface area of the two neighbouring drainages. The Puyango-Tumbes River drainage has a surface area of approximately 4,850 km2, 60% of which is contained within southern Ecuador, and 40% of which is contained northwestern Peru (Marshall et al. 2018). It extends 160 km from El Oro Province southward to the Tumbes Region in northwestern Peru (Marshall 2018). The Catamayo River has a length of 120 km, whose watershed covers an area of 4,184 km2. Based on the scope of threats in the Catamayo and Tumbes River drainages, this species is assigned to two threat-based locations. This species occurs across an altitudinal range of 25-700 masl.

There is anecdotal evidence to suggest that continuing declines in EOO, AOO, and the number of threat-based locations where this species occurs are occurring as a result of continuing loss in habitat quality and availability (R. Barriga pers. comm. 2021).
useTrade: There is limited information regarding the use and trade of this species (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). In northern Peru, adults are included in subsistence fisheries (Valenzuela Reyna 2014). However, the annual volume of harvest is unknown.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards P. Atahualpa. It is  feasible that this species could be found in the Arenillas Ecological Reserve. Range may also extend into private protected areas such as Buenaventura Ecological Reserve (Jocotoco) and La Ceiba (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020, P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021). However, given limited ichthyological survey in this region and few georeferenced collection records, range extent within existing protected area is unknown. Additional research regarding distribution, population size, population trend, and the direct impact of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the extinction risk of this species.

rationale: Eretmobrycon festae is broadly distributed throughout Pacific slope drainages in Ecuador and northern Peru. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 58,105 km2. Population size is likely very large, as this species comprises a dominant portion of the ichthyofauna in several major river drainages. Population trend is suspected to be stable in the absence of documented decline, and persistence in highly disturbed habitat (e.g., roadside drainage ditches) has been observed. Therefore, E. festae is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species forms large schools along river banks, where it is often observed with Brycon alburnus (Revelo and Laaz 2012). Altitudinal migrations have been observed in April (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Occurrence in highly disturbed habitat (e.g., drainage ditches along roadways) suggests resilience to habitat degradation (Revelo and Laaz 2012). Reproductive females release approximately 280-300 eggs in submerged aquatic vegetation, where they are fertilized externally and hatch in approximately 72 hours (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). This species is omnivorous (Revelo and Laaz 2012).Maximum reported body size is 6.9 cm (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015).
threats:
There is currently no evidence that existing threats to aquatic habitats in Ecuador and northern Peru has significantly contributed to declines in the population size or range extent of E. festae (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Altitudinal migrations are likely interrupted by large damming projects (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015).

The Guayas River basin is subject to a number of anthropogenic stressors on local and regional scales (Loh et al. 2014, Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, 2018). In a basin-wide ecological water quality analysis, poor water quality was consistently detected around arable land and adjacent to residential areas (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016). The Guayas River basin supports much of the Ecuador’s industrial scale agricultural production, has contributed to high concentrations of pesticide pollutants throughout the watershed (Deknock et al. 2019, Cambien et al. 2020), and continues to drive deforestation as agricultural land-use expands (Borbor-Cordova et al. 2006, Aguirre et al. 2021). The agricultural industry in the Guayas River basin is based on monoculture systems, and contributes to the production of about 20% of bananas and 83% of rice for Ecuador (INEC 2016). Mining activity near the Guayas or Santa Rosa River basins presents a threat to aquatic species, including areas such as Ponce Enriquez where the mercury toxicity threshold was three times higher than the threshold recommended for the protection of aquatic life (Appleton et al. 2001).

Similarly to the entire Ecuadorian Pacific slope, several species of African tilapia have been introduced into the Guayas River basin (Aguirre et al. 2021). These exotic species show tolerance to wide variations in water quality, strong ecological adaptability, phenotypic plasticity and reproductive efficiency, which contributes to their successful competition with native species (Stickney 1993). However, the direct impact of these species on native ichthyofauna have not been evaluated in detail and additional research will be necessary to determine the direct impacts of these invaders.

Gold mining is the primary economic activity in the upper basin of the Puyango-Tumbes River basin (Marshall et al. 2018, Schudel et al. 2018, Marshall et al. 2020). Amalgamation processing occurs primarily in the municipality of Portovelo, Ecuador, where byproducts and wastewater is discharged directly into the Puyango watershed (Marshall et al. 2018). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013).
population: Eretmobrycon festae is locally abundant throughout the Guayas River basin on the Pacific slope of Ecuador (Alvarez-Mieles et al. 2013, Aucapiña Franco 2017). It was the most abundant species reported from ichthyological sampling in Bolívar province (Laaz and Torres 2011). Population trend is suspected to be stable in the absence of major threats, and documented persistence in highly disturbed habitat (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015).
range:
Eretmobrycon festae is relatively broadly distributed throughout freshwater drainages on the Pacific versant of Ecuador and northern Peru (Barriga 2012). The type locality of this species is the Vinces River, Ecuador (Lima et al. 2003). Specifically, it is distributed throughout the Guayas, Chone, and Puerto Viejo river drainages (Barriga 2012, Revelo and Laaz 2012), including a number of rivers in Bolívar province (Laaz and Torres 2011). In northern Peru, it has been collected from a number of localities within the Tumbes River drainage (Valenzuela-Reyna 2014, Ruiz-C et al. 2018). Additional records exist from the Patía, Esmeraldes and Santiago rivers in northwestern Ecuador (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). However, additional morphological and molecular study of these populations is necessary to confirm their identity to the species level (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). This species occurs at an altitudinal range of 36-800 masl. 

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 58,105 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020).
useTrade: This species is targeted in ornamental and subsistence fisheries, typically by use of cast net (Revelo and Laaz 2012). In the coastal towns of Babahoyo, Tarifa, Samborondón, and Salitre, they are served fried and are known as chicharron (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). These fish are often used as a bait item to target larger species (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards E. festae. The range of this species likely extends into some protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020), including privately owned areas that are characterized by protective forests, such as the Palenque River and Jauneche scientific stations (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021). Given the high relative abundance, broad distribution, and lacking evidence of population decline, this species is of relatively low conservation concern.

rationale: Eretmobrycon peruanus is restricted to Pacific slope drainages from the Tumbes River drainage in northwestern Peru southward to drainages around the capital city of Lima. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 87,101 km2. Total population size and population trend are unknown. However, this species is fairly uncommon in the limited number of ichthyological survey that has been conducted in this region. Major pervasive threats include mining and ore processing, land-use changes and pollution associated with agricultural production and cattle ranching, and coastal aquaculture, and the establishment of non-native fishes. However, the direct impact, scope, and magnitude of these pervasive threats have not been evaluated in detail. Given a relatively broad range and lacking evidence of major population decline associated with locally and regionally pervasive threats, E. peruanus is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Eretmobrycon peruanus occurs in calm, slowly flowing waters at depths ranging from 30-56 cm over substrates of gravel, sand and stone (Yolvin Marcial 2016). Diet is comprised of aquatic insects and zooplankton (Yolvin Marcial 2016).
threats:
Gold mining is the primary economic activity in the upper basin of the Puyango-Tumbes River basin (Marshall et al. 2018, Schudel et al. 2018, Marshall et al. 2020). Amalgamation processing occurs primarily in the municipality of Portovelo, Ecuador, where byproducts and wastewater is discharged directly into the Puyango watershed (Marshall et al. 2018, Aguirre et al. 2021). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013). In the Catamayo river basin, extensive agricultural irrigation has contributed to increases in the presence of total and fecal coliforms, soil erosion and destruction of vegetation cover (Gonzales and Chamba 2007).

The non-native Nile Tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus) and Guppy (Poecilia reticulata) have established in the lower reaches of Pacific draining Peruvian and Ecuadorian rivers (Ortega et al. 2007, Aguirre et al. 2021). However, the direct impact of these species on native ichthyofauna has not been evaluated in detail.

Despite uncertainties regarding the direct impact, scope, and magnitude of existing threats, continuing decline in habitat quality as a result of anthropogenic activities is inferred. Quantifying these threats will help clarify the conservation status of this species.
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. From a total of nine survey localities along the Tumbes River drainage, this species was present only at Rica Playa in San Jacinto district, with nine individuals captured (Valenzuela Reyna 2014). This species comprised 6% of relative fish abundance in the Moche River, La Libertad district (Yolvin Marcial 2016).
range:
Eretmobrycon peruanus is restricted to Pacific slope drainages from the Tumbes River drainage in northwestern Peru southward to drainages around the capital city of Lima (Román-Valencia et al. 2011). Historical records of E. peruanus northward throughout Pacific drainages in Ecuador (e.g., The Chira and Catamayo river basins), the Amazon drainage in Ecuador, and Pacific drainages in southern Colombia are morphologically distinct species (Román-Valencia et al. 2011). However, this species is still regularly reported from Ecuador (García-Melo et al. 2019), and further molecular analysis may be needed to clarify range extent. This species occupies an altitudinal range of 300-1500 masl. 

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 87,101 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020), and the reported distribution of this species based on morphological analysis and comparison to close congeners and previously unrecognized distinct species (Román-Valencia et al. 2011).
useTrade: This species is not utilized in any commercial capacity (Valenzuela Reyna 2014).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards E. peruanus. However, the range of this species likely extends into a number of protected areas, including Cerros de Amotape and Huascarán National Parks (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). In Ecuador, this species likely occurs in private protected areas such as Buenaventura Ecological Reserve (Jocotoco) and La Ceiba (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021). Additional research regarding population size, population trend, life history and ecology, and the direct impact of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

rationale: Phenacobrycon henni is endemic to the Pacific slope of Ecuador, where it is known from the Guayas River drainage. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 4,804 km2. Total population size and population trend are unknown, but this species appears uncommon. Given such few collection records, the number of threat based locations where this species occurs cannot be determine with accuracy. However, continuing decline in habitat quality throughout the Guayas River drainage is inferred, based on severe anthropogenic degradation associated with agricultural practices, urban development, and industrial operations. Given a relatively restricted known range, anecdotal reports that this species is uncommon, and several regionally pervasive threats that are producing inferred continuous declines in habitat quality, P. henni is assessed as Near Threatened under criterion B1ab(iii). Additional research regarding distribution, population size and population trend, and the scope and direct impact of existing threats may quality this species for a higher threatened category.
habitat: This species has been reported from river backwaters and isolated pools in the Vinces and Cristal rivers (Roberts 1973), inhabiting areas near shrelines that are comprised of gravel, sand, and stone (R. Barriga pers. comm. 2021). Diet is comprised of a broad variety of terrestrial and aquatic invertebrates (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Maximum reported body size is 5.3 cm total length (TL) (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Gill glands are present in males, which serve as a secondary sex character and are used in chemical signalling (Bushmann et al. 2002).
threats:
Western Ecuador is heavily impacted by anthropogenic factors, including habitat transformation for the development of agricultural fields and towns, the building of dams and creation of artificial reservoirs, habitat deterioration due to pollution, mining and severe river bank modification (Aguirre et al. 2014).

The Guayas River basin is subject to a number of anthropogenic stressors on local and regional scales (Loh et al. 2014, Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, 2018). In a basin-wide ecological water quality analysis, poor water quality was consistently detected around arable land and adjacent to residential areas (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016). The Guayas River basin supports much of the Ecuador’s industrial scale agricultural production, has contributed to high concentrations of pesticide pollutants throughout the watershed (Deknock et al. 2019, Cambien et al. 2020), and continues to drive deforestation as agricultural land-use expands (Borbor-Cordova et al. 2006, Aguirre et al. 2021). Intensive grazing is a standard practice for cattle farming in the lower reaches of the drainage (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). The basin supports a human population of approximately 5.5 million inhabitants (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). Population growth and associated increases in urban expansion and industrial processes have degraded habitat quality around urban population centres (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, Rivera Vera 2017). The agricultural industry in the Guayas River basin is based on monoculture systems, and contributes to the production of about 20% of bananas and 83% of rice for Ecuador (INEC 2016). Mining activity near the Guayas or Santa Rosa River basins presents a threat to aquatic species, including areas such as Ponce Enriquez where the mercury toxicity threshold was three times higher than the threshold recommended for the protection of aquatic life (Appleton et al. 2001).

Similarly to the entire Ecuadorian Pacific slope, several species of African tilapia have been introduced into the Guayas River basin (Aguirre et al. 2021). These exotic species show tolerance to wide variations in water quality, strong ecological adaptability, phenotypic plasticity and reproductive efficiency, which contributes to their successful competition with native species (Stickney 1993). However, the direct impact of these species on native ichthyofauna have not been evaluated in detail and additional research will be necessary to determine the direct impacts of these invaders.

Despite uncertainties regarding the scope and magnitude of existing threats, continuing decline in habitat quality is inferred.
population: Total population size and population trend are unknown. However, this species is anecdotally reported as uncommon in the Guayas River Basin, and is represented by approximately 13 collections lots with various specimens (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015).
range:
Phenacobrycon henni is endemic to the Guayas River drainage on the Pacific slope of Ecuador (Barriga 2012, Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). The type locality of this species is Vinces, Ecuador (Weitzman 2003).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 4,804 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around a limited number of georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020). Given limited sampling effort in this region, and uncertainty regarding the direct impact and scope of existing threats, the number of threat-based locations where this species occurs cannot be determined with accuracy. This species occurs at an altitudinal range of 7-300 masl.
useTrade: This species is not utilized (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards P. henni. No georeferenced collection records have been reported from within the boundaries of a protected area to date, but range may extend into some privately managed protected areas such as Palenque River and Pedro Franco Dávila protective forests  (R. Barriga pers. comm. 2021). Additional research regarding distribution, population size, population trend, life history and ecology, and the scope and magnitude of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

rationale: Rhoadsia altipinna occurs at low elevations from the Guayas River drainage southward to the Tumbes River on the Pacific slope of western Ecuador and northwestern Peru. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 97,772 km2. This species is highly abundant in western Ecuador and often comprises a dominant portion of the ichthyofauna based on the total number of individuals. Population may be declining locally, but is suspected to be relatively stable range-wide. Despite a number of pervasive threats in western Ecuador and northern Peru, this species remains abundant and does not appear to be under significant threat. Therefore, R. altipinna is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This omnivorous, benthopelagic species occurs in rivers with moderate water velocity and rocky substrates (Revelo and Laaz 2012). In the Santa Rosa River drainage, this species was more common in pool mesohabitats when compared to riffle mesohabitats (Aguirre et al. 2016). Maximum reported body size is 17 cm, but adults more commonly reach 10 cm standard length (SL) (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Weight-length relationships have been established in the Atacames and Súa watersheds, based on extensive sampling of 1,720 individuals (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2019).
threats:
Western Ecuador is heavily impacted by anthropogenic factors including habitat transformation for the development of agricultural fields and towns, the building of dams and creation of artificial reservoirs, habitat deterioration due to pollution, mining and severe river bank modification, and heavy fishing pressure (Aguirre et al. 2014).

The Guayas River basin is subject to a number of anthropogenic stressors on local and regional scales (Loh et al. 2014, Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, 2018). In a basin-wide ecological water quality analysis, poor water quality was consistently detected around arable land and adjacent to residential areas (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016). The Guayas River basin supports much of the Ecuador’s industrial scale agricultural production, has contributed to high concentrations of pesticide pollutants throughout the watershed (Deknock et al. 2019, Cambien et al. 2020), and continues to drive deforestation as agricultural land-use expands (Borbor-Cordova et al. 2006, Aguirre et al. 2021). Intensive grazing is a standard practice for cattle farming in the lower reaches of the drainage (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). The basin supports a human population of approximately 5.5 million inhabitants (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). Population growth and associated increases in urban expansion and industrial processes have degraded habitat quality around urban population centres (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, Rivera Vera 2017). The agricultural industry in the Guayas River basin is based on monoculture systems, and contributes to the production of about 20% of bananas and 83% of rice for Ecuador (INEC 2016). Mining activity near the Guayas or Santa Rosa River basins presents a threat to aquatic species, including areas such as Ponce Enriquez where the mercury toxicity threshold was three times higher than the threshold recommended for the protection of aquatic life (Appleton et al. 2001).

Gold mining is the primary economic activity in the upper basin of the Puyango-Tumbes River basin (Marshall et al. 2018, Schudel et al. 2018, Marshall et al. 2020). Amalgamation processing occurs primarily in the municipality of Portovelo, Ecuador, where byproducts and wastewater is discharged directly into the Puyango watershed (Marshall et al. 2018, Aguirre et al. 2021). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013).

Despite inferred and continuous declines in freshwater habitat quality, population trend is suspected to be stable or declining slowly.
population:
The total population size of R. altipinna is unknown. However, it is one of the most common species of fishes on the Pacific coast of Ecuador (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). This species was dominant in the Abras de Mantequilla wetland, despite a number of localized pervasive threats (e.g., hydroelectric damming, intense fertilizer use, deforestation, and agricultural expansion) (Alvarez-Mieles et al. 2013), and in the Ruidoso River (Aucapiña Franco 2017). In the Santa Rosa River, it was the second most abundant species (Aguirre et al. 2016). In the Viches River, it comprised 16.9% of relative fish abundance by number of individuals captured (Angulo Collahuazo 2020).

Population may be declining locally in the Jubobes River Basin due to the loss of natural refuges, habitat, and riparian vegetation associated with hydroelectric development (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). However, this species does not appear to be threatened on a range-wide scale and population trend is suspected to be stable or declining slowly.
range:
Rhoadsia altipinna occurs at low to moderate elevations from the Guayas River drainage (Barriga et al. 2012) southward to the Tumbes River (Valenzuela Reyna 2014), on the Pacific slope of western Ecuador and northwestern Peru (Loh et al. 2014) and including the Catamayo, Chira, and Jubones rivers (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Range may extend northward into the Esmeraldes river drainage (Glodek 1978), but records in this drainage may also represent the close congener R. minor (Loh et al. 2014).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 97,772 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020). Given its relatively broad range. R. altipinna likely occurs in greater than ten threat-based locations. Altitudinal range extends from 25-1,400 masl.
useTrade: This species is not utilized in any commercial capacity, though it has potential as an ornamental species due to the bright coloration of males (Revelo and Laaz 2012). This species may be useful as a sentinel species in areas that are affected by mercury pollution associated with mining and amalgamation processes (Sánchez 2019).
conservationActions: This species is currently of relatively low conservation concern, given high population abundance and a broad range that extends into a number of protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020), including Abras de Mantequilla wetland (Nugra et al. 2015), a designated Ramsar site, and private conservation areas such as the Palenque River and Pedro Franco Dávila protective forests (P. Arugello pers. comm. 2021). Additional research regarding the direct impact of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

rationale: Andinoacara rivulatus is distributed throughout the Guayas, Santa Rosa, Zarumilla, and Tumbes river drainages on the Pacific slope of Ecuador and northern Peru. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 49,481 km2. Despite several locally and regionally pervasive threats that are producing inferred continuous declines in habitat quality, their direct impacts on A. rivulatus have not been evaluated in detail. There is currently no indication of major range-wide population decline. Therefore, A. rivulatus is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This omnivorous, benthopelagic freshwater fish is relatively common in coastal and premontane rivers.

Eggs are deposited onto hard substrates and are fertilized externally (Wijkmark et al. 2012). Exogenous feeding begins at 3 days post hatch, and young resemble juveniles by approximately 28 days post hatch (Moshayedi et al. 2017).
threats:
Western Ecuador is heavily impacted by anthropogenic factors including habitat transformation for the development of agricultural fields and towns, the building of dams and creation of artificial reservoirs, habitat deterioration due to pollution, mining and severe river bank modification, and heavy fishing pressure (Aguirre et al. 2014, 2021).

The Guayas River basin is subject to a number of anthropogenic stressors on local and regional scales (Loh et al. 2014, Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, 2018). In a basin-wide ecological water quality analysis, poor water quality was consistently detected around arable land and adjacent to residential areas (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016). The Guayas River basin supports much of the Ecuador’s industrial scale agricultural production, has contributed to high concentrations of pesticide pollutants throughout the watershed (Deknock et al. 2019, Cambien et al. 2020), and continues to drive deforestation as agricultural land-use expands (Borbor-Cordova et al. 2006, Aguirre et al. 2021). Intensive grazing is a standard practice for cattle farming in the lower reaches of the drainage (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). The basin supports a human population of approximately 5.5 million inhabitants (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). Population growth and associated increases in urban expansion and industrial processes have degraded habitat quality around urban population centres (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, Rivera Vera 2017). The agricultural industry in the Guayas River basin is based on monoculture systems, and contributes to the production of about 20% of bananas and 83% of rice for Ecuador (INEC 2016). Mining activity near the Guayas or Santa Rosa River basins presents a threat to aquatic species, including areas such as Ponce Enriquez where the mercury toxicity threshold was three times higher than the threshold recommended for the protection of aquatic life (Appleton et al. 2001).

Similarly to the entire Ecuadorian Pacific slope, several species of African tilapia have been introduced into the Guayas River basin. These exotic species show tolerance to wide variations in water quality, strong ecological adaptability, phenotypic plasticity and reproductive efficiency, which contributes to their successful competition with native species (Stickney 1993). However, the direct impact of these species on native ichthyofauna have not been evaluated in detail and additional research will be necessary to determine the direct impacts of these invaders.

Gold mining is the primary economic activity in the upper basin of the Puyango-Tumbes River basin (Marshall et al. 2018, Schudel et al. 2018, Marshall et al. 2020). Amalgamation processing occurs primarily in the municipality of Portovelo, Ecuador, where byproducts and wastewater is discharged directly into the Puyango watershed (Marshall et al. 2018). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013).

Despite inferred and continuous declines in freshwater habitat quality, population trend is suspected to be stable or declining slowly.
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. This species is common in coastal and premontane rivers throughout much of its range (Revelo and Laaz 2012). In other ichthyological surveys, it comprised only a small percentage of the relative fish abundance (Laaz and Torres 2011, Valenzuela Reyna 2014). Fishermen from the lower Guayas river Basin have anecdotally reported reductions in the number of specimens caught, suggesting that population is being affected, but more information is needed to determine the current population status of this species (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021).
range:
Andinoacara rivulatus is distributed throughout the Guayas, Santa Rosa, Zarumilla, and Tumbes river drainages on the Pacific slope of Ecuador and northern Peru (Revelo and Laaz 2012, Wijkmark et al. 2012, Aguirre et al. 2014), including the Ruidoso River (Aucapiña Franco 2017). This species is replaced in the Esmeraldes River drainage by the close congener A. blombergi (Wijkmark et al. 2012), and south of the Tumbes River drainage by the close congener A. stalsbergi (Musilová et al. 2009). This species occurs at an altitudinal range of 5-1200 masl. 

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 49,481 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020), and considering recent revisions to the range etent of this species that excludes the Esmeraldes Basin in northern Ecuador and drainages south of the Tumbes River in Peru (Musilová et al. 2009, Wijkmark et al. 2012).

Invasive populations associated with ornamental releases are established elsewhere, including in Mexico and Indonesia (Contreras-MacBeath et al. 2014, Serdiati et al. 2020).
useTrade: This species is important in subsistence and artisanal fisheries, where it is targeted with a variety of fishing gears (Revelo and Laaz 2012). A large body of literature has developed around the aquaculture of this species, and it is widely cultured for food and as an ornamental species (Revelo and Laaz 2012).
conservationActions:
There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards A. rivulatus. However, range extends into a number of protected areas, including Parque Lago and Abras de Mantequilla (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Additional information regarding distribution north of the Guayas and south of the Esmeraldes River drainage, population size, population trend, and the direct impact of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

In 2020, the Ministry of Production, Foreign Trade, Investment and Fisheries of Ecuador established fisheries regulation that prevents the capture of food fishes from the main tributaries of the Guayas River basin during the months of January and February of each year (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021). A minimum harvest size is also established to prevent artisanal fisheries from harvesting sexually immature individuals (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021).

rationale: Pseudocurimata peruana is restricted to the Catamayo, Chira, Puyango, and Tumbes river drainages along the Pacific slope of Ecuador and Peru. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 8,802 km2. Total population size is unknown. However, this species is anecdotally reported as rare by local residents. Population trend is suspected to be in decline, based on reported decreases in abundance as a result of damming activities. Primary threats include a large damming project in the Catamayo-Chira River drainage, mining activities in the headwater of the Tumbes River drainage, widespread agricultural production and cattle grazing, and the establishment of non-native species. Therefore, continuing decline in Area of Occupancy, habitat quality, and the number of mature individuals is inferred. However, uncertainties regarding the scope and direct impact of existing threats prevents an accurate estimation of the number of threat-based locations where this species occurs. As such, P. peruana is assessed as Near Threatened under criterion B1ab(ii,iii,v).
habitat: Very little is known about the biology and ecology of this species (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). It is likely detritivorous and benthopelagic (Eigenmann 1922). Maximum reported body size is 12.7 cm total length (TL) (Eigenmann 1922).
threats:
Gold mining is the primary economic activity in the upper basin of the Puyango-Tumbes River basin (Marshall et al. 2018, Schudel et al. 2018, Marshall et al. 2020). Amalgamation processing occurs primarily in the municipality of Portovelo, Ecuador, where byproducts and wastewater is discharged directly into the Puyango watershed (Marshall et al. 2018, Aguirre et al. 2021). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013). There is anecdotal evidence that a large damming project in the Catamayo-Chira drainage has reduced the local abundance of this species (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). The primary threat in the Catamayo river basin is agricultural irrigation, which has contributed to increases in fecal coliforms, soil erosion and destruction of vegetation cover (Gonzales and Chamba 2007).

The non-native Nile Tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus) and Guppy (Poecilia reticulata) have established in the lower reaches of Pacific draining Peruvian rivers (Ortega et al. 2007, Jácome et al. 2019). However, the direct impact of these species on native ichthyofauna has not been evaluated in detail.

Despite uncertainties regarding the direct impact, scope, and magnitude of existing threats, continuing decline in habitat quality as a result of anthropogenic activities is inferred. Quantifying these threats will be necessary to clarify the conservation status of this species.
population: The total population size of this species is unknown. There is anecdotal evidence suggesting that the Catamayo-Chira Dam has significantly impacted this species, and local residents report it as rare (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Therefore, population trend is suspected to be in decline. In a basin-wide ichthyological survey of the Tumbes River, a total of eight individuals were collected at a single sampling locality, comprising 0.81% of total fish abundance (Valenzuela Reyna 2014). Similarly, this species is one of the most uncommon Pseudocurimata species held in the Ecuadorian fish collection (MEPN) (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021).
range:
Pseudocurimata peruana is restricted to the Catamayo, Chira, Puyango and Tumbes river drainages along the Pacific slope of Ecuador and Peru (Barriga 2012, Valenzuela Reyna 2014, Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Occurrence southward to the Piura River is cited by Vari (2003), however no georeferenced collection records from the Piura River are publicly available (GBIF 2020).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 8,802 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around all georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020). Given uncertainties regarding the direct impacts and scope of existing threats, the number of threat-based locations where this species occurs cannot be determined with accuracy. Additional survey will be necessary to clarify the extinction risk of this species. This species occurs at an altitudinal range of 70-900 masl.
useTrade: The use and trade of this species has not been evaluated in detail (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). It may be included in subsistence fisheries, given the importance of close congeners as a food source for inland communities (Revelo and Laaz 2012).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards P. peruana. Additional research regarding distribution, population size, population trend, life history and ecology, and the scope, magnitude, and direct impact of existing threats is necessary to clarify the extinction risk of this species. It is likely that this species occurs in the Arenillas Ecological Reserve. In addition, its extension could extend into private protected areas such as Buenaventura Ecological Reserve (Jocotoco) and La Ceiba (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021).

rationale: Pseudocurimata troschelii is distributed throughout the Guayas River drainage on the Pacific slope of southern Ecuador and the Tumbes and Zarumilla River drainages in northwestern Peru. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 50,409 km2. Total population size and population trend are unknown. However, this species is anecdotally reported as common throughout its range. Land-use changes associated with agricultural expansion, cattle grazing, and coastal pond aquaculture are prevalent throughout the region. Additional threats include mining activities, urban expansion, and pollutants from urban, industrial, and agricultural sources. Despite uncertainties regarding the direct impacts of existing threats, continuing decline in habitat quality is inferred. However, there is currently no indication of major range-wide population decline, and the range of this species extends into a number of protected areas. Therefore, P. troschelii is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This detritivorous, benthopelagic species is common in rivers characterized by high water velocity (Revelo and Laaz 2012). Maximum reported body size is 21 cm total length (TL) (Revelo and Laaz 2012).
threats:
The Guayas River basin is subject to a number of anthropogenic stressors on local and regional scales (Loh et al. 2014, Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, 2018). In a basin-wide ecological water quality analysis, poor water quality was consistently detected around arable land and adjacent to residential areas (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016). The Guayas River basin supports much of the Ecuador’s industrial scale agricultural production, has contributed to high concentrations of pesticide pollutants throughout the watershed (Deknock et al. 2019, Cambien et al. 2020), and continues to drive deforestation as agricultural land-use expands (Borbor-Cordova et al. 2006, Aguirre et al. 2021). Intensive grazing is a standard practice for cattle farming in the lower reaches of the drainage (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). The basin supports a human population of approximately 5.5 million inhabitants (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). Population growth and associated increases in urban expansion and industrial processes have degraded habitat quality around urban population centres (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, Rivera Vera 2017). The agricultural industry in the Guayas River basin is based on monoculture systems, and contributes to the production of about 20% of bananas and 83% of rice for Ecuador (INEC 2016). Mining activity near the Guayas or Santa Rosa River basins presents a threat to aquatic species, including areas such as Ponce Enriquez where the mercury toxicity threshold was three times higher than the threshold recommended for the protection of aquatic life (Appleton et al. 2001).

Gold mining is the primary economic activity in the upper basin of the Puyango-Tumbes River basin (Marshall et al. 2018, Schudel et al. 2018, Marshall et al. 2020). Amalgamation processing occurs primarily in the municipality of Portovelo, Ecuador, where byproducts and wastewater is discharged directly into the Puyango watershed (Marshall et al. 2018). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013).

The Daule-Peripa reservoir is the most important for the western region of the country. This reservoir is home to relatively large populations of edible fish that are exploited by local fishermen; however, much of the deep water is anoxic and its release has been associated with low levels of oxygen detected in the Daule River (Aguirre et al. 2021).

Despite uncertainties regarding the direct impact, scope, and magnitude of existing threats, continuing decline in habitat quality as a result of anthropogenic activities is inferred.
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. However, it is common in high flow rives throughout its range (Revelo and Laaz 2012). Ichthyological sampling in the Tumbes River in 2012 reported a total of 17 individuals from a single collection locality (Valenzuela Reyna 2014). Monitoring by the Instituto Público de Investigación de Acuicultura y Pesca suggests that species exhibiting migratory behaviours appear to be declining (Aguirre et al. 2021).
range:
Pseudocurimata troschelii is distributed throughout the Guayas River drainage on the Pacific slope of southern Ecuador and the Tumbes and Zarumilla River drainages in northwestern Peru (Vari 1989, Barriga 2012, Revelo and Laaz 2012, Wijkmark et al. 2012, Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 50,409 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around the Guayas, Tumbes, and Zarumilla drainages. This species occurs at an altitudinal range of 15-400 masl.
useTrade: This species is an important component of inland subsistence and artisanal fishery landings, which are an important source of food for surrounding urban and rural communities (Revelo and Laaz 2012).
conservationActions:
There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards P. troschelii. However, the range of this species extends into a number of protected areas along the Pacific coast of Ecuador and Peru (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Additional research regarding population size, population trend, and the impact of harvest would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

In 2020, the Ministry of Production, Foreign Trade, Investment and Fisheries of Ecuador established fisheries regulation that prevents the capture of food fishes from the main tributaries of the Guayas River basin during the months of January and February of each year (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021). A minimum harvest size is also established to prevent artisanal fisheries from harvesting sexually immature individuals (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021).

rationale: Pimelodella yuncensis is distributed throughout freshwater habitat along the Pacific slope of Ecuador and Peru from the Catamayo River southward to the Jequetepeque River. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 67,744 km2. Total population size and population trend are unknown. However, P. yuncensis is poorly studies in the scientific literature and is known from a limited number of collection records. Despite a number of existing threats that continue to impact habitat quality along the Pacific slope of Ecuador and Peru, there is no evidence of major range-wide declines in range extent or population status. Therefore, P. yuncensis is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: The preferred habitat characteristics, life history, and ecology of this species have not been studied in detail. Maximum reported body size is 4.8 cm total length (TL) (Bockman and Guazzelli 2003). This species has omnivorous habits and is found in rivers with sandy and stony substrates (R. Barriga pers. comm. 2021).
threats:
Western Ecuador is heavily impacted by anthropogenic factors including habitat transformation for the development of agricultural fields and towns, the building of dams and creation of artificial reservoirs, habitat deterioration due to pollution, mining and severe river bank modification, and heavy fishing pressure (Aguirre et al. 2014, 2021). The Guayas River basin is subject to a number of anthropogenic stressors on local and regional scales (Loh et al. 2014, Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, 2018). In a basin-wide ecological water quality analysis, poor water quality was consistently detected around arable land and adjacent to residential areas (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016). The Guayas River basin supports much of the Ecuador’s industrial scale agricultural production, has contributed to high concentrations of pesticide pollutants throughout the watershed (Deknock et al. 2019, Cambien et al. 2020), and continues to drive deforestation as agricultural land-use expands (Borbor-Cordova et al. 2006). Intensive grazing is a standard practice for cattle farming in the lower reaches of the drainage (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). The basin supports a human population of approximately 5.5 million inhabitants (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). Population growth and associated increases in urban expansion and industrial processes have degraded habitat quality around urban population centres (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, Rivera Vera 2017). One of the main threats in the Catamayo river basin is agricultural irrigation, which has contributed to increases in total and fecal coliforms, soil erosion and destruction of vegetation cover (Gonzales and Chamba, 2007).

The primary threats to freshwater habitat in western Peru include runoff and pollution associated with urban centers, deforestation and pollution associated with unsustainable agricultural activities, and hydrological modification to support irrigation as urban and agricultural development continue (Ortega and Hidalgo 2008). Specific instances of these stressors are apparent in the Cañete, Lurin, and Piura River drainages (Wiegers et al. 1999, Urteaga-Crovetto 2016). Nearly every Pacific slope drainage in Peru is impacted by these factors to some degree (Ortega and Hildalgo 2008). Gold mining is the primary economic activity in the upper basin of the Puyango-Tumbes River basin (Marshall et al. 2018, Schudel et al. 2018, Marshall et al. 2020). Amalgamation processing occurs primarily in the municipality of Portovelo, Ecuador, where byproducts and wastewater is discharged directly into the Puyango watershed (Marshall et al. 2018). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013). 

The direct impact of existing threats on P. yuncensis have not been evaluated in detail, though continuing decline in habitat quality is inferred.
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. This species is not represented in any recent ichthyological surveys.
range:
Pimelodella yuncensis is distributed throughout freshwater drainages along the Pacific slope of Ecuador and Peru (Barriga 2012, Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). It has been reported specifically from the Catamayo, Guayas, Santa Rosa, Tumbes, and Jequetepeque River drainages (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). The type locality of this species is Pacasmayo (Bockman and Guazzelli 2003). However, it is known from a limited number of ichthyological collection records (GBIF 2020), and is poorly studied in existing scientific literature (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 67,744 km2 based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020). This species occurs at an altitudinal range of 35-1,000 masl.
useTrade: There is no information regarding the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards P. yuncensis. It is likely that this species occurs in the Arenillas Ecological Reserve (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021). In addition, range may also extend into private protected areas such as Buenaventura Ecological Reserve (Jocotoco), and La Ceiba (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021). However, additional ichthyological will be necessary to determine range extent into existing protected area networks. More research regarding population size, population trend, life history and ecology, and the direct impact and scope of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

rationale: Saccodon wagneri is distributed throughout the Guayas, Santa Rosa, and Catamayo River drainages along the Pacific slope of Ecuador, and in the Tumbes River drainage on the Pacific slope of northern Peru. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 29,707 km2. Total population size and population trend are unknown, but this species is abundant in parts of the Guayas River drainage and there is no documented evidence of major population declines. Continuing decline on a regional scale is inferred based on the persistence of several threats throughout Ecuador and in the Tumbes River drainage in northern Peru, but the direct impact and scope of threats need to be evaluated in greater detail. Therefore, S. wagneri is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Saccodon wagneri occurs throughout freshwater rivers and tributary streams along the Pacific slopes of Ecuador and Peru (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Habitat is typically characterized by clear, swiftly flowing water over rocky substrates (Roberts 1974). Maximum reported body size is 10.1 cm standard length (SL) (Pavanelli 2003). Diet is likely comprised of algae (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021).
threats:
Western Ecuador is heavily impacted by anthropogenic factors including habitat transformation for the development of agricultural fields and towns, the building of dams and creation of artificial reservoirs, habitat deterioration due to pollution, mining, and severe river bank modification (Aguirre et al. 2014, 2021).

The Guayas River basin is subject to a number of anthropogenic stressors on local and regional scales (Loh et al. 2014, Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, 2018). In a basin-wide ecological water quality analysis, poor water quality was consistently detected around arable land and adjacent to residential areas (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016). The Guayas River basin supports much of the Ecuador’s industrial scale agricultural production, has contributed to high concentrations of pesticide pollutants throughout the watershed (Deknock et al. 2019, Cambien et al. 2020), and continues to drive deforestation as agricultural land-use expands (Borbor-Cordova et al. 2006, Aguirre et al. 2021). Intensive grazing is a standard practice for cattle farming in the lower reaches of the drainage (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). The basin supports a human population of approximately 5.5 million inhabitants (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). Population growth and associated increases in urban expansion and industrial processes have degraded habitat quality around urban population centres (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, Rivera Vera 2017). Similar threats are present throughout much of the Santa Rosa River drainage (Aguirre et al. 2016). The agricultural industry in the Guayas River basin is based on monoculture systems, and contributes to the production of about 20% of bananas and 83% of rice for Ecuador (INEC 2016). One of the main threats in the Catamayo river basin is agricultural irrigation, which has contributed to increases in total and faecal coliforms, soil erosion and destruction of vegetation cover (Gonzales and Chamba 2007).

The primary threats to freshwater habitat in western Peru include runoff and pollution associated with urban centres, deforestation and pollution associated with unsustainable agricultural activities, and hydrological modification to support irrigation as urban and agricultural development continue (Ortega and Hidalgo 2008). Gold mining is the primary economic activity in the upper basin of the Puyango-Tumbes River basin (Marshall et al. 2018, Schudel et al. 2018, Marshall et al. 2020). Amalgamation processing occurs primarily in the municipality of Portovelo, Ecuador, where byproducts and wastewater is discharged directly into the Puyango watershed (Marshall et al. 2018). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013).
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. From a total of 3,005 fishes collected during ichthyological sampling in Bolivar Province, Ecuador, S. wagneri comprised approximately 20.2% of relative abundance by number of individuals (Laaz and Torres 2011). Recent ichthyological sampling at a number of localities in the Tumbes River basin yielded a single individual (Valenzuela Reyna 2014). There is no documented indication of major, range-wide population declines.
range:
Saccodon wagneri is distributed throughout the Guayas, Santa Rosa, and Catamayo River drainages along the Pacific slope of Ecuador (Barriga 2012, Aguirre et al. 2014, Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015), and in the Tumbes River drainage on the Pacific slope of northern Peru (Valenzuela Reyna 2014).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 29,707 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020). This species occurs at an altitudinal range of 25-800 masl.
useTrade: There is no information regarding the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards S. wagneri. This species has been registered in the Abras de Mantequilla wetland (Nugra et al. 2015), which is a designated Ramsar site. This species likely occurs in the Arenillas Ecological Reserve and range may extend into private protected areas such as Buenaventura Ecological Reserve (Jocotoco), Palenque River and Pedro Franco Dávila protective forests (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021). Additional research regarding distribution, population size, and population status would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

rationale: Pseudopoecilia festae is distributed along the Pacific slopes of Ecuador and northern Peru having been reported from the Guayas, Santa Rosa, and Jubones River drainages. Range extent cannot be determined with accuracy, given limited ichthyological survey in the region and a dearth of georeferenced collection records. Total population size and population trend are unknown. Several locally and regionally pervasive threats in Ecuador and Peru are producing inferred continuous declines in habitat quality, but their scope and direct impact on P. festae have not been studied in detail. Given these uncertainties, P. festae is assessed as Data Deficient until more data become available.
habitat: Pseudopoecilia festae occurs in freshwater habitat along the Pacific slopes of Ecuador and Peru (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Habitat is characterized by a large amount of submerged and riparian vegetation which is used as cover to avoid predators (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). It has also been collected from a section of the Sunes River characterized by shallow rapids with slow velocity and abundant riparian vegetation (Tobes et al. 2020). Diet is comprised of zooplankton and aquatic invertebrates (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Maximum reported body size is 4.5 cm and 3.5 cm in females and males, respectively (Eigenmann 1922). Fertilization occurs internally and males are sexually dimorphic based on the presence of a gonopodium (Tortonese 1949, Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015).
threats:
Western Ecuador is heavily impacted by anthropogenic factors including habitat transformation for the development of agricultural fields and towns, the building of dams and creation of artificial reservoirs, habitat deterioration due to pollution, mining, and severe river bank modification (Aguirre et al. 2014, 2021).

The Guayas River basin is subject to a number of anthropogenic stressors on local and regional scales (Loh et al. 2014, Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, 2018). In a basin-wide ecological water quality analysis, poor water quality was consistently detected around arable land and adjacent to residential areas (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016). The Guayas River basin supports much of the Ecuador’s industrial scale agricultural production, has contributed to high concentrations of pesticide pollutants throughout the watershed (Deknock et al. 2019, Cambien et al. 2020), and continues to drive deforestation as agricultural land-use expands (Borbor-Cordova et al. 2006, Aguirre et al. 2021). Intensive grazing is a standard practice for cattle farming in the lower reaches of the drainage (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). The basin supports a human population of approximately 5.5 million inhabitants (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). Population growth and associated increases in urban expansion and industrial processes have degraded habitat quality around urban population centres (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, Rivera Vera 2017). Similar threats are present throughout much of the Santa Rosa River drainage (Aguirre et al. 2016). The agricultural industry in the Guayas River basin is based on monoculture systems, and contributes to the production of about 20% of bananas and 83% of rice for Ecuador (INEC 2016). Mining activity near the Guayas or Santa Rosa River basins presents a threat to aquatic species, including areas such as Ponce Enriquez where the mercury toxicity threshold was three times higher than the threshold recommended for the protection of aquatic life (Appleton et al. 2001).

The primary threats to freshwater habitat in western Peru include runoff and pollution associated with urban centers, deforestation and pollution associated with unsustainable agricultural activities, and hydrological modification to support irrigation as urban and agricultural development continue (Ortega and Hidalgo 2008). Gold mining is the primary economic activity in the upper basin of the Puyango-Tumbes River basin (Marshall et al. 2018, Schudel et al. 2018, Marshall et al. 2020). Amalgamation processing occurs primarily in the municipality of Portovelo, Ecuador, where byproducts and wastewater is discharged directly into the Puyango watershed (Marshall et al. 2018). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013).

Despite uncertainty regarding the direct impact of existing threats on P. festae, continuing decline in habitat quality is inferred.
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. The only vouchered collections of this species are from its original description (Eigenmann 1922) and two specimens that are housed in the Ecuadorian ichthyological holdings (MEPN) (P. Arguello pers. comm. 2021).
range:
Pseudopoecilia festae is distributed along the Pacific slope of Ecuador, including the Guayas and Santa Rosa River drainages (Barriga 2012, Aguirre et al. 2014, Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). This species has also been reported from the Jubones River in northern Peru, where it is considered non-native. Range extends northward to the Chico Chaune River in Ecuador (Lucinda 2003).

There are currently no georeferenced collection records of P. festae, and therefore Extent of Occurrence, Area of Occupancy, and the number of threat-based locations where this species occurs cannot be determined with accuracy. Additional ichthyological survey will be necessary to determine the conservation status of this species. This species occurs in an altitudinal range of 50-300 masl.
useTrade: This species is not utilized in subsistence fisheries (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). It is used as a biological control for insects in rice crops (R. Barriga pers. comm. 2021).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards P. festae. This species has been registered in Abras de Mantequilla, a designated Ramsar site (Nugra et al. 2015). More comprehensive ichthyological surveys in this region will be necessary to determine range extent, abundance, and population trend. Further research regarding the scope and direct impact of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

rationale: Listed as Endangered due to a small estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 2,082 km<sup>2</sup>, only two known threat-defined locations, and continuing declines in the extent and quality of habitat and extent of occurrence.
habitat: This is a montane species that inhabits areas of moist evergreen forest (Rowley et al. 2010). Reproduction occurs from July to May. It is a phytotelm breeder and will produce clutches of up to 250 eggs in foam nests on the interior walls of tree-hollows, where the larvae hatch and fall to the water-filled hollow basin. Nests are generally 30-120 cm above the ground. The species is unique among Rhacophorus in that its tadpoles and early-stage metamorphs are oophagus and females are known to deposit trophic eggs into the nest in order to feed young (Rowley et al. 2012, Vassilieva et al. 2014). The tadpoles do not appear to feed on any alternative foodstuffs (Vassilieva et al. 2014).
threats: This species is currently only recorded from two small geographic areas and depends on wet, dense montane rainforest (Rowley et al. 2010). Contraction and degradation of suitable habitat are therefore threats to its survival and are ongoing even within protected areas of its range in the form of established aquaculture, agriculture (primarily coffee), road development, and harvest of both timber and non-timber forest products (Doung 2011, J. Rowley pers. comm. February 2014).
population: The species has been rarely observed during amphibian surveys within its range, but is likely to be difficult to detect due to its arboreal nature. As such, no information on population size exists for this species.
range: This species is known to occur between 1,470 and 2,004 m asl within two protected areas in southern Viet Nam: Bidoup-Nui Ba National Park, Lac Duong District, Lam Dong Province (Rowley et al. 2010) and Ta Dung Nature reserve, Dak Glong District, Dak Nong Province (Rowley et al. 2012). Further surveys are likely to expand the known range to adjacent parts of the Langbian Plateau including Chu Yang Sin National Park to the northwest, and Phuoc Binh National Park to the southeast (Rowley et al. 2010). The species is likely to have occurred more widely in the past, prior to habitat loss and fragmentation in the area. The area of its range, which is taken as a proxy for extent of occurrence, is estimated to be 2,082 km2. The species occurs in two geographically distinct, threat-defined locations, separated by an area of unsuitable habitat at lower elevations.
useTrade: There are no records of use or trade of Rhacophorus vampyrus.
conservationActions: All records of this species are from within protected areas (Bidoup-Nui National Park and Ta Dung Nature Reserve). It is likely that the species' range also extends outside of these, both into other protected areas (Chu Yang Sin National Park and Phuoc Binh National Park) as well as unprotected areas (Rowley et al. 2010). Addressing the lack of data is the first step towards ensuring the species' conservation; further research is needed on its population trends, ecology, habitat requirements and threats. It may also be prudent to explore strategies for increasing the scope of protection in the species' known range.

rationale:
This is an amended version of the 2015 assessment to accommodate the change in genus from Himantura to Urogymnus.

The Mangrove Whipray (Urogymnus granulatus) is a large-bodied (to 141 cm disc width), uncommon stingray, with a widespread distribution in the eastern Indian and western Pacific oceans, from Sri Lanka and eastern India, through to Indonesia. It also occurs along the northern coast of Australia and throughout some of the Pacific Islands. The species appears to prefer shallow inshore waters, including mangroves, estuaries, sand flats and broken rocky-sandy substrate, although adults may move offshore to at least 85 m depth. The species' preference for inshore habitats and the fact that it is apparently uncommon compared to other Himantura species, makes it particularly vulnerable to widespread and intensive artisanal and industrial fisheries operating throughout large areas of its range, as well as habitat destruction and pollution. Significant destruction and degradation of mangrove areas and targeting of juveniles in shallow waters are thought to have significantly affected this species.

It is caught irregularly by tangle net, bottom trawl (including large numbers of trawlers targeting rhynchobatids in the Arafura Sea) and longline fisheries and retained for human consumption. Levels of exploitation are very high throughout its range in Southeast Asia and in many parts of the Indian Ocean, hence it is under a severe level of threat within most of this range. Although no species-specific data are available, overall catches of stingrays are reported to be declining in areas of Southeast Asia for which information is available, with fishermen having to travel further and further to sustain catch levels. Species that inhabit a similar habitat to this species (such as the Sicklefin Lemon Shark (Negaprion acutidens)) are now rarely observed in Indonesia due to high levels of exploitation, and significant declines are also inferred to have occurred in the Mangrove Whipray in Indonesia and other areas. Given the continuation of high levels of exploitation throughout its range in Southeast Asia where the species is caught in multiple types of fisheries, along with evidence for declines in catches of rays, the level of decline (>30% over the last three generations) and exploitation can be inferred from overall declines in fish catches in the region, as well as from habitat loss (in particular mangroves).

n Australia, the Mangrove Whipray is considered at minimal threat throughout its wide range as there is no information to suggest that this species has declined in this area. Fisheries in northern Australia are generally well managed and the introduction of turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) have significantly reduced the bycatch of large stingrays. There are also significant marine protected areas in this species' range. This large species may have limiting life history characteristics that would make it biologically susceptible to depletion in fisheries and therefore, efforts should be made to assess and monitor mortality in fisheries and population trends throughout its range. The Mangrove Whipray is assessed as Vulnerable globally based on inferred levels of decline and exploitation across a large part of its range, but is considered to be Least Concern in Australia.
habitat:
The Mangrove Whipray appears to prefer shallow inshore waters, including mangroves, estuaries, sand flats, and broken rocky-sandy substrate, although adults may move offshore and it has been recorded to a depth of at least 85 m (White et al. 2006; B.M. Manjaji-Matsumoto and W. White, pers. obs. 2007). This species also appears to be solitary rather than forming aggregations, like some other stingrays (B.M. Manjaji-Matsumoto, pers. obs. 2007). Reproduction is viviparous with histotrophy (White et al. 2006). The species reaches a maximum reported size of 141 cm disc width (DW),  >275 cm total length (TL) (White and Dharmadi 2007, W. White, pers. obs. 2007) and size at birth is reported at 14-28 cm DW (Manjaji 2004, White et al. 2006). Manjaji (2004) reports that males mature at 55-65 cm DW, but the biology and life-history characteristics of this species are generally poorly known. A generation length of 20 years can be estimated based on the Blackspotted Whipray (Maculabatis astra) (Jacobsen and Bennett 2011), but noting that the Blackspotted Whipray grows to a much smaller maximum size (80 cm disc width) than the Mangrove Whipray (141 cm DW).

Davy et al. (2015) examined the movement patterns of juveniles (29.5-44.0 cm DW) at Orpheus Island, Australia between March and December 2012, with the majority of individuals showing high site fidelity, and were found to seek refuge within mangrove roots; presumed to be to reduce predation risk. The preference for nearshore habitats may increase its susceptibility to habitat loss (mangroves) and fisheries interactions (Davy et al. 2015).
threats:
The Mangrove Whipray is a rare species that is caught infrequently by tangle net, bottom trawl, and, to a lesser extent, longline fisheries in Indonesia (White et al. 2006; W. White, pers. obs. 2007) and in other parts of its range (Moore 2012). In these areas, most bycatch by commercial fisheries (especially trawlers) are landed and sold as food fish. The Mangrove Whipray and other stingrays are an important retained bycatch of the commercial gillnet fishery in Indonesia that targets rhynchobatid rays in the Arafura Sea (Last and Compagno 1999; W. White, pers. obs. 2007). Catches in inshore waters have declined and these vessels are having to travel farther to sustain catches; the rhynchobatid fisheries are very intensive in this region, thus the level of exploitation is extremely high. There is also evidence that fisherman in these regions increasingly illegally fish in Australian waters (Chen 1996; W. White, unpubl. data).

This species' preference for shallow inshore waters makes it particularly sensitive to extensive and intensive artisanal and industrial fisheries operating throughout large areas of its range, as well as habitat destruction and pollution (B.M. Manjaji-Matsumoto and W. White, pers. obs, Vidthayanon 1997, Davy et al. 2015). Juveniles and sub-adults are targeted in mangrove areas and destruction of mangrove forests are having a significant effect on this species (W. White, pers. obs. 2007). Mangrove forests throughout Southeast Asia and large areas of the Eastern Indian Ocean have been deforested and degraded (FAO 2007). In this region, ~1.9 million hectares of mangroves have been logged during the last 25 years (FAO 2007). More than 90% of this loss has been caused by destruction of mangrove area in Indonesia, Pakistan, Vietnam, Malaysia, and India (areas where this species occurs) through conversion of land for shrimp farms, excessive logging, conversion of land for agriculture or salt pans and degradation through oil spills and pollution (FAO 2007). Even in well-managed mangrove areas that are protected from destruction, for example, the UNESCO Biosphere Reserve in Ranong, Thailand (designated in 1997), this species may still face threats from local fisheries on which the people living in the reserve primarily depend (FAO 2007).

The Sicklefin Lemon Shark (Negaprion acutidens) occurs at similar depths to this species' preferred bathymetric range; the Sicklefin Lemon Shark is rarely observed in recent times in Indonesia due to the very high level of exploitation of inshore waters and its slow growth rate (White et al. 2006). The Mangrove Whipray is apparently uncommon compared to other large Himantura species in this region, making it particularly susceptible. Given that this is a large stingray, probably with 'slow' life-history characteristics also, by comparison it is inferred that this species has also declined significantly in these areas. Artisanal inshore fishing pressure is also very intensive off eastern India (Flewwelling and Hosch 2006). Fisheries throughout India operate on an open access basis and inshore marine species are thought to be fully or overexploited, with extensive use of illegal mesh sizes reported, and increasing bottom trawl effort (Flewwelling and Hosch 2006). Demersal species, such as this, suffer more fishing mortality than pelagic species on the eastern coast of India (Flewwelling and Hosch 2006). India's inshore fisheries are generally characterised by declining catch rates, declining recruitment and biomass, and a shift from regular landing patterns (Flewwelling and Hosch 2006). Although no species-specific data are available on catches, it is inferred that this species has also suffered declines as a result of high levels of inshore exploitation in these areas also.

In Australia, catch data for this species are relatively limited, though large specimens were previously reported as bycatch in the Australian Northern Prawn Fishery. However, with the introduction of turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) in the fishery, the ray bycatch has declined by 36.6% and there is likely to have been significant reductions in the catch and associated mortality of the Mangrove Whipray (Brewer et al. 2006).

No data or information is available on catches in the Pacific Islands, but this species may be taken as bycatch in inshore subsistence and artisanal fisheries there also.
population: Globally, shark and ray landings have declined by at least 20% since 2003, but the Indo-Pacific is amongst the regions where this decline has been more severe (Dulvy et al. 2014). Catches of sharks and rays in Southeast Asia are very high but are declining and fishers are travelling much further from port in order to increase catches (Chen 1996). Net and trawl fisheries in Indonesia (especially the Java Sea) and elsewhere are very extensive and as a result, many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009). Batoids are heavily exploited (White and Dharmadi 2007) and datasets from as early as 1963–1972 show the considerable decline in batoids in the Gulf of Thailand (Pauly 1979). Trawl and gill net fisheries are also moving further afield. For example, in Jakarta the gillnet fishery at Muara Baru travels to waters around Kalimantan due to the decline in local populations (W.T. White, unpubl. data). While species-specific data on long-term declines in elasmobranchs in the Southeast Asian region are lacking, declines of the Mangrove Whipray in Southeast Asia and elsewhere in the Indo-West Pacific are inferred given the widespread historical and continuing declines of demersal fisheries in this region (Stobutzki et al. 2006). Furthermore, the extensive loss and degradation of habitats such as coastal mangroves are another key threat to coastal and inshore species; Southeast Asia has seen an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2010).
